PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Government was advised by the United States Administration early this morning of immediately impending military action against Libya. President Reagan has since confirmed that the United States has taken military action against targets which it regards as supporting terrorism. The Australian Government has counselled restraint by both the United States and Libya in the course of the developing tensions between them. It deeply regrets that this conflict has taken place and urges both sides to suspend hostilities and engage in genuine efforts to bring about the peaceful resolution of their differences. This will mean that the United States terminate its military engagement against Libya. It also means, as an absolute essential, that Colonel Gaddafi terminate his Government's indiscriminate export of terrorist activity against civilians and civilian targets, especially United States civilians.

SPEECH.PARA: The United States has said that its action was motivated not only by evidence of Libyian involvement in and direction of past terrorist activities but also by indications of Libyan planning being well advanced for further operations against American citizens in a number of countries. The United States' military action was explained to us not in terms of revenge or reprisals but in terms of demonstrating that terrorism will incur a significant cost. The Government accepts that there is a substantial body of evidence of Libyan involvement in and direction of international terrorism. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and I have been privy to apparently compelling evidence of a direct line of command between Libya and the Berlin nightclub bombing.

It is a matter of serious concern that following the Gulf of Sidra episode-where Libya attacked American forces exercising in international waters and the United States retaliated-Libya's policy of extreme hostility against the United States has continued. The Government, in response to a request from President Reagan in January, took a number of economic measures against Libya and reduced Libya's official representation in Australia as part of collective international measures to demonstrate to Libya that its behaviour in support of international terrorism is totally unacceptable to the international community. The Government has expressed a desire to work with Western and other governments for a concerted approach to dealing with international terrorism. The Minister for Foreign Affairs is pursuing this matter with Western and other governments and will be reporting back to Cabinet on measures to promote a sustained long-term effort to defeat the threat of international terrorism.

The Government is profoundly concerned that the situation has reached the point where Libyan action have driven the United States to regard it as essential that it take military action. Australia works persistently for a peaceful world. We are opposed to the use of violent means to resolve differences between nations, and in particular to the resort to terrorism. Terrorism recognises no rules and respects no moral standards. The victims are almost always innocent victims. Australians have already been victims of this sort of activity, and that is another reason why we are implacably opposed to this sort of behaviour. Let me sum up the Government's position:
We wish to see restraint and an early end to hostilities.
We hope that the conflict will not widen and escalate.

We are fully conscious of the intractable and bitter conflicts of the Middle East, and the need for them to be resolved if the Middle East is to cease to be a source of violence and terrorism not only in that region but throughout the world. We look for such a resolution.
But an essential requirement for ending the fundamental confrontation between Libya and the United States must be that Libya completely and convincingly disavows recourse to terrorism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition thanks the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for his statement of the Government's attitude towards the American military action against Libya. I have to say on behalf of the Opposition that we regret that the Government has felt itself unable to express support for the United States action. I would like to say on behalf of the Liberal and National parties that, regrettable though this chain of events and the development of circumstances may be, we express our support for the action of the United States as being a justifiable act of self-defence against the background of all the circumstances that have been so clearly demonstrated over the past months.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister and his Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) apparently have irrefutable evidence of a link between the Libyans and certain terrorist acts including, in particular, the terrorist bombing attack on a discotheque in Germany a couple of weeks ago, yet this Government feels itself unable to express support for the action that has been taken by the United States. It ought to be remembered, in addressing this issue, that evidence has come to the notice of the United States Administration. Apparently, that is accepted by the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister. The House ought to recall the earlier attempts by the United States to bring about action designed to dissuade the Libyans from continuing their terrorist activities. I remind the House of the request for economic and other sanctions made by the United States to her allies in January this year-the House will be aware of the very lukewarm and inadequate response that was given-and I remind the House also of other attempts by the United States to bring about a change in the attitudes of the Libyans.

When considering this matter we should all remember that no country and no citizens of any country are immune from terrorism and that, over the past 12 months, Australian citizens in other parts of the world have suffered at the hands of indiscriminate acts of terrorism. The basis of the United States action, which we believe is properly grounded in an understanding of the United Nations Charter, is an act of defence against a country which has palpably and clearly exported terrorism as an instrument of foreign policy for a considerable period. We trust that the action taken by the United States will demonstrate to Libya and to other countries that might export terrorism in an indiscriminate and cruel fashion that international terrorism cannot be tolerated by the civilised world.

We must understand that terrorism will continue while safe havens for terrorists exist. Col- onel Gaddafi, the leader of Libya, is on record as supporting the activities of terrorist murderers. Libya has engaged in state-supported terrorism. This country has provided safe havens for members of Terrorism Incorporated and the acts of terrorism perpetrated by Gaddafi's Libya have been aimed both at his own people and at individual citizens of other countries-men, women and children-in an indiscriminate manner.

Gaddafi has directed his aggression against Arab and African nations as well as European nations. As I mentioned a moment ago, last year a number of Australians were victims of terrorist murders, attacks and kidnaps. The United States Administration is now saying: `Thus far you have gone in your acts of terrorism but no further'. We on this side of the House believe that, in all the circumstances, regrettable though the developments may be, President Reagan deserves the support of all who are committed to a world free of terrorism and deserves the full support of the present Australian Government. We regret that the present Australian Government has felt itself unable to give that support and, like so many other significant foreign policy issues, finds itself impaled on an ideological fence on a matter of great significance as far as international affairs are concerned.

So, I say to the Prime Minister and to the House that we regret very much the failure and the inability of the Hawke Government to give support to President Reagan, and I express on behalf of the Liberal and National parties understanding and support of the action properly and justifiably taken by the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. I ask him, as the Minister responsible for Commonwealth construction projects, what action he has taken so far and what action does he intend to take to exclude the Builders Labourers Federation from Commonwealth construction projects and to prevent that union from continuing to represent in any way builders labourers employed on Commonwealth construction projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the end of last year, on the instruction of the Cabinet and the Government, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and I, with our departments, had discussions with various organisations representing the industry and reached agreement on what has become known as the code of conduct; a form of compensation arrangements, and a procedure for declaring some companies to be of `special notoriety' if they continue to do business with the deregistered Builders Labourers Federation. That code of conduct has been in operation for the last few months. It has been used against several well known companies. Upon receiving their signatures on correspondence which indicated that they would comply with the code of conduct, those companies have been released from the designation of companies of special notoriety.

ANSWER.PARA: Companies which have contracts or will be seeking contracts with the Department of Housing and Construction for the construction of Commonwealth projects, will be required to abide by the code of conduct in future, in the public sector and the private sector. This means that once the Builders Labourers Federation is deregistered they will not be allowed to recognise or do business with that union in its deregistered state, and if they do conduct business with that union in its deregistered state they will not be eligible for future Government contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What does the Prime Minister hope to achieve during his forthcoming visit to Washington and Europe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This visit comes at a very critical time for Australia's rural sector. The situation in the rural areas is such that extraordinary action is needed at this time. It is for that reason that I am setting aside other priorities to maximise Australian pressure for action in this area. A major factor contributing to the Australian rural crisis is the corruption of international markets. The massive agricultural export subsidies provided by the European Economic Community and others are well entrenched and it will take all of Australia's diplomatic capacity to bring about any substantial change in direction. All Australians, irrespective of party or of location, share in the prosperity of our rural sector. As I have had reason to say on many occasions, rural exports account for some 37 per cent of Australia's total exports which by any measure constitutes a vital contribution to our national well-being. My visit is, therefore, one of vital importance to all Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: Following on the intensive efforts of both Mr Dawkins and Mr Kerin, I will seek to bring home to the most senior members of the United States Administration and Congress, and to European leaders, the need to get agricultural markets functioning efficiently. More specifically, in Washington I will seek assurances from that Government that, in the manner of implementing its farm legislation, Australia, as a friend and ally of the United States, should be insulated as much as possible from the direct effects of that legislation. I shall seek assurances that the United States agricultural export subsidy programs will be targeted at markets previously lost by the United States to other subsidisers and away from markets served by Australia as a non-subsidiser. While in Washington, I shall also seek international support for agriculture as a key item in the forthcoming round of multilateral trade negotiations. More specifically, we shall want to see established as an objective of the round the gradual phasing out of agricultural export subsidies. This interest in bringing about meaningful and purposeful multilateral negotiations of international agricultural trade rules will also be an important part of my discussions with the leaders of the United Kingdom, Italy, Greece and the European Commission. With them I shall also be pressing Australia's concerns about the damaging effects that the EC's common agricultural policy is having on Australian agriculture.

The coincidence of my departure today and Mr Kerin's presentation of the Government's economic and rural policy package is significant. This Government is bringing a comprehensive approach to address the needs of the rural sector. We shall spare no effort to see that our efficient and competitive producers enjoy the returns that are their right.

—Can the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the House of the Government's attitude to calls from the Opposition and others for increased flexibility in the labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of calls from members of the Opposition and others for increased flexibility in the wage system. Let me say a couple of things about that. It must be understood that we have had substantial wage flexibility at the aggregate wage level under the system that has been brought in by this Government. Through the operations of the wage indexation system the full impact of Medicare on the consumer price index was reflected in the wage outcome. The same can be said with the accord mark 2, which substantially adjusted aggregate wage policy to the devaluation, but of course it is also being said that we need more than that, that we need to have relative wage flexibility increased as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me point out a couple of facts. Under the present system there is scope for differential wage increases in respect of anomalies and inequities under the work value principle and also, of course, part or complete incapacity to pay a national wage increase is being adopted in some industries, but there is also reason to believe that calls for increased flexibility of the wage system may be overstating considerably the importance of relative wage flexibility. In looking at the evidence for that, let me take the House to a few relevant points. The Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems said in its report that it did not believe that relativities were a sensitive signalling device. It said this was because wage relativities do not respond readily to changes in the underlying conditions of demand and supply, and that the allocation of labour is insensitive to change in relativities between the wage levels of major categories of labour. That was a fairly emphatic statement after a detailed investigation of this matter by a very important body, but at the international level the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has reached a similar conclusion. In its `Employment Outlook' for September 1985 the OECD said:

While one would expect a flexible wage structure to aid labour market adjustment it is not clear how important this is in practice. Even in a situation of a relatively inflexible industrial wage structure labour mobility may occur smoothly on the basis of expected life-time earnings and availability of job opportunities.
That was an important statement from the OECD, which also said, in particular reference to Australia:

In countries pursuing consensus policies to achieve aggregate wage moderation care is also needed to ensure that attempts to substantially increase relative wage flexibility do not compromise this goal.

That, of course, has been a major factor in this Government's consideration in pursuing the wage policy that it has; that is, we can see some advantages in increased wage flexibility, but not to the point where it would in any way endanger the macro wage outcome. A further area of relevance to this point is a survey which was conducted by the Business Council of Australia early this year. That survey of employers concluded:
. . . the operation of the current wage fixing principles was not a major causal factor in the development of labour market skill shortages . . .
In a letter to my Department the Business Council stated:

Where shortages have emerged, wage flexibility and remuneration differentials are not a major contributing factor. Accordingly, there is little justification for `freeing-up' the system solely on the grounds of trying to alleviate shortages of labour in a relatively narrow range of specific occupations in particular areas.

There are three very important areas of evidence that call for increased relative wage flexibility, which perhaps considerably overstate the importance which might be found in such a development. I agree that there are people with a different point of view and that some see advantages in pursuing the kind of policy that is proposed by the Opposition. In that respect, I notice that in the Australian of 5 April there was a quotation that indicated there was strong support for following the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia from a particular source. The article said, when talking about this person:
He also said that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, now had a strong supporter for his proposed introduction of individual contracts between unions and employers.
``We might have something in common,'' he said. ``I think some of the Libs' concepts have got something going for them.''
The person who was being talked about and who made that remark was Mr Norm Gallagher, the Secretary of the Builders Labourers Federation. With friends like that, who needs a Liberal wages policy?

SPEECH.PARA: Previous Liberal-Country Party governments have responded to successive rural recessions with measures of a largely ad hoc nature. Some of these responses have been of assistance to the sector and have become part of the fabric of farm policy. Others have been ineffective for any purpose other than as a placebo or an ideological fix. They have not seriously addressed the problems; they have quickly disappeared as the crisis has passed-as did the beef incentive payment scheme, for example.

The Hawke Government's approach is different. We have analysed the nature of current rural problems very carefully. We have not restricted ourselves to farm policy. We have also looked at economic and industry policies and at policies directed toward non-farm, rural and provincial Australia. My speech today is a summary of the comprehensive analysis of farm and rural policies as set out in the accompanying Government statement on economic and rural policy. We have found cases where our policies should be changed. But the broad thrust of our policies has emerged intact.

Many of us in this House have had experience of previous farm crises. My own experience on a farm goes back to the 1950s and 1960s. Most of us can recall the late 1950s drought, wheat quotas, the wool crisis, the dairy crisis and beef crisis of the 1960s and 1970s and, of course, the 1982-83 drought. In times of crisis in rural and provincial Australia reaction by farmers is at first slow; institutions and governments also are slow to act. But once the seriousness of the situation is realised, and because personal stress brings out basic political attitudes, it is usual for there to be dissent, unrest and exploitation of these attitudes by the opportunists.

Farmers are not whingers; they are gamblers. Farmers are realists; they rarely make extreme demands. Farmers feel they are victimised because they work in some isolation, in a setting where they cannot control the weather, the middlemen, the markets, the unions and the governments.

We now have a situation, quite apart from political attitudes and exploitation, which is termed a so-called rural revolt. However, at the end of the day once the emotion has been expended, once the simple-minded simple solutions have been disproved, once the demagogues have been dismissed, I have always found that it has been necessary to analyse calmly what the problems are, and what can be done, in terms of overall economic and social policy. This statement is about reality, analysis and directions.
The Place of Primary Production in Australian Society

The first reality I want to identify clearly is the place of primary producers in particular, and country dwellers in general, in Australian society and the Australian economy. Some 36 per cent of Australians live and work outside our major capital cities. Some 7 per cent directly depend on the primary industries of agriculture, forestry and fishing for their livelihood. Thirty per cent of all Australia's small businesses are in primary production. Of course, farms and other small businesses are not in the same situation. Farmers compete on world markets, while most other small businesses complete against each other.

Taking into account multiplier relationships, perhaps some 20 per cent of Australians owe their livelihood to primary production either directly or indirectly. With primary production providing some 37 per cent of Australia's exports, the standard of living of all Australians is affected by primary production.

Rural Australia is an integral part of our history, our culture and our environment. No government can ignore this contribution of the rural sector to our society and our economy. This Government does not. What the Hawke Government does do-and this is different from our political opponents-is to recognise the true nature of this contribution. The only policies that work are those that contribute to the long term health of the sector in its market environment. Individuals in need are helped effectively only by measures that are properly targeted on those individuals.

Not all country dwellers are farmers, nor do all country dwellers depend on primary production. But all country dwellers do have common problems of access to the range of public and other services that are taken for granted in the cities. It is for this reason that this Government does not confine its rural policies to farmers alone-we are in the business of addressing the problems of all Australians.
Nature of the Current Rural Problem

There can be no doubting the very substantial economic successes that the Hawke Labor Government has achieved. Australia's economic growth is the most rapid in the Western world. Our job creation record has greatly exceeded our targets. Only last week it was recorded that we have now created almost 620,000 new jobs. This outstanding record has reflected a number of factors, not the least being our successes in the areas of wages and fiscal and monetary policy. The fundamental problem is that, by and large, the rural sector has not shared in this economic success.

According to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the real net value of rural production-that is, the Bureau's key indicator of farm income movements-is projected to fall by 21 per cent in 1985-86, with a further 21 per cent fall projected for 1986-87. Average farm cash operating surplus is projected to fall by 25 per cent in 1985-86 to $19,600, after fluctuating from $19,500 in 1982-83, the lowest in recent times, to $27,500 in 1983-84, the highest in recent times. Average farm incomes on family farms-which allows for depreciation-is projected to fall by 66 per cent. This does not, however, include imputed or off-farm income. Rural land prices are falling in some areas in an inevitable response to present lower returns and unrealistically high prices in the past.

The proportion of farms assessed by the BAE as being `at risk', that is, having a negative cash margin and less than 70 per cent equity, is up from 5 per cent in 1984-85 to 7 per cent in 1985-86-12,000 farms. Employment growth in non-metropolitan areas was very close to that recorded in metropolitan areas. However, country areas generally have not experienced the same dramatic falls in unemployment as have the cities. I emphasise that there has still been a fall in the non-metropolitan unemployment rate. The major causes of the poorer country labour market performance have been more rapid population growth and stronger growth in female labour force participation. The gap between country and city female labour force participation rates has narrowed as country women have increasingly sought to take their rightful place in the community.

The broad statistics on farm incomes I have cited so far need to be qualified in two major respects. The first is that there is substantial diversity across commodities, regions and individuals. It is both unreasonable and dishonest to infer that all farmers are in trouble. For example, the projected change in average farm cash operating surplus in 1985-86 ranges from a fall of 52 per cent for wheat and other crops to an increase of 10 per cent for beef farms. Of course, international price movements, seasonal conditions and overseas policies can always confound such estimates. Estimates are estimates.

It is a simple fact that the current and prospective income problems are concentrated in certain commodities, such as wheat, sugar, dairy, rice and horticulture, and in certain areas, such as the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia and the Mallee districts of Victoria and South Australia. As a result, the falls in rural land prices have been by no means universal. Similarly, there has been a great deal of talk of farm debt problems, and this is undoubtedly the heart of the problem for many individuals. Nevertheless, according to BAE estimates for June 1985, some 28 per cent of farmers had no debt and a further 18 per cent of farmers had less than $20,000 debt. This is in contrast to the 12 per cent of farmers, including 25 per cent of wheat farmers, who had more than $150,000 in debt. This diversity shows that no grand fix-it solution can work. The problem needs to be addressed on an individual basis.

The second qualification is that it is entirely wrong to compare the BAE's farm income estimates with estimates of average weekly earnings and so suggest some comparison with wage earners. The two sets of statistics are totally incompatible, as the BAE's farm income statistics make no allowance for either off-farm or imputed income. Whilst the statistics show that there are declining farm incomes, they do not, of themselves, demonstrate an individual welfare problem. This, too, needs to be addressed on a case-by-case basis. Obviously, if the averages are low, there is a welfare problem at the bottom end. Consequently, proper policy settings cannot be directed at simply supplementing all farm incomes. Rather, they need to be directed at solving the underlying problems of primary production, transport, marketing and adjustment. Any special assistance needs to be carefully targetted on individuals.
Causes of the Problem

It is important for all of us, including both producers and governments, clearly to establish the causes of the current problems. The simple fact is that adverse world market trends are the reason for the failure of the farm sector to share fully in Australia's general economic growth. Average export returns for Australia's primary products have increased by only 5 per cent in the two years to 1985-86, despite a currency depreciation of the order of 25 per cent. This implies that average world prices for our exports have fallen by around 20 per cent. Had world prices not fallen, rural incomes would be over 50 per cent higher than is currently projected. Instead of a fall of over 30 per cent in the real net value of rural production over the past two years, we would be looking at an increase of 6 per cent. There is little prospect of immediate improvement. Projections for 1986-87 suggest little increase in world prices.

It is simply not possible, in the face of these figures, to lay all the blame for the problem at the door of the Australian Government. Our overall economic policies cannot be blamed, as the rest of the economy has been doing very well. Tariff and other industry policy measures cannot be blamed. The direction of movements in protection has been generally downwards for some time, particularly through the measures being implemented by this Government. In any case, Australian agriculture adjusted to our historically high levels of protection decades ago.

World prices are the problem. The Government does recognise that the impact of general economic policies can fall unevenly. At a time of low commodity prices, farmers are less able to withstand high interest rates. The problem is not high rural debt levels-the use of debt finance is less in the rural sector than in other sectors-nor is it high interest rates alone. The problem is the conjunction of high interest rates and low returns, exacerbated in some areas by a series of poor seasons.
The `Grand Solutions'

Rural populists have proposed alleged quick cures to these problems, including massive subsidisation of the farm sector. The rationale for these proposals is often the `tariff compensation' argument-that farmers lose from protection for manufacturing industry and so should be compensated. The logic behind this argument is extremely faulty. I repeat that Australian agriculture adjusted to our high protection levels decades ago, and recent movements in protection have been downwards.

The protection of other industries is not the cause of the current problem. It is true that protection imposes a cost on all Australians, including farmers, and that farmers would particularly gain from a reduction in protection. In recognition of this, the Government is reducing protection levels. For instance, our decisions on the car industry are resulting in reductions in effective assistance of an estimated 10 to 15 per cent per year. Any so-called `compensation' during the time it takes for these measures to have their impact would make no economic sense and, in particular, would make no equity sense. People should be assisted according to need.

The final problem with `tariff compensation' is that no-one has yet worked out a form of assistance that would not make other problems worse. For example, we could simply provide massive price support across all commodities. As European and North American experience shows, this simply does not work. Europe's agricultural subsidies have thrown a million people out of work, while the farm problem in the United States is much worse than in Australia, despite massive subsidisation.

It is government cave-in to farmer demonstrations and revolt overseas that has accentuated the problem. In these countries, subsidies represent most, if not all, of the total level of farm income. Subsidies would provide a windfall gain for current producers, but would do nothing to prevent a recurrence of the problems in future as market fluctuations continued. By encouraging over-production, subsidies exacerbate the problems. By encouraging reliance on governmental support they reduce the dynamism and self-reliance that is the strength of Australian agriculture. The budgetary costs would also be enormous. An equivalent level of support to that provided in Europe and the United States could cost us anything up to $5,000m. We simply cannot afford it. Any attempt to do so would so destabilise the macro-economic environment that it could make farm sector problems worse. Finally, and most importantly, it would totally fail to target assistance on those most in need. Twenty-five per cent of Australia's farmers produce 60 per cent of the output, so it is obvious that this 25 per cent would get 60 per cent of the benefits of such an approach.

Another popular but irrational form of assistance would be to provide massive general subsidies on farm interest rates. This, of course, would be even worse, as it would subsidise only one input-debt finance. It would distort the pattern of assistance across commodities, regions and individuals. To the extent that debt is not correlated with need, there would be perverse distributional consequences.

Interestingly, the sector's total interest bill is less than the amount of `tariff compensation' that is often claimed. The Balderstone report in 1982 suggested that interest subsidies could be delivered through a loading on the tax deductibility of interest rates. This would be even more inequitable, giving greatest assistance to those with the highest incomes. The conservative parties' policy favourite of tax deductibility has never done a thing for farmers with low, or nil, taxable income.

Another set of `grand solutions' relates to the current privatisation fad. The Government is reviewing the regulation that exists, implementing deregulatory measures where appropriate, and acting to improve the efficiency of public sector operations. This includes our reforms of statutory marketing authorities, the dairy industry and sugar industry restructuring. What counts is not necessarily ownership, but the quality of management and the incentives provided by the regulatory environment. These issues were ignored by previous governments for too long.

We all know what would happen with wholesale privatisation. In the case of Telecom Australia, for example, the $490m provided in 1984-85 in cross-subsidisation of non-metropolitan rentals and local calls would be lost. I note that the dries in the Liberal Party have yet to direct their attention to the primary industry statutory marketing authorities. In short, the grand solutions provide no solution.
The Government's Approach

What the Government is doing is implementing those measures that do three things-strengthen the sector's long term competitiveness, assist those most in need, and complement our general social and economic policy approach. It is true that we have changed the worst examples of the National Party's legacy, but we have also improved those special programs that specifically benefit primary producers. I particularly refer to tax averaging, the diesel excise rebate and the various commodity underwriting arrangements. No other sector receives these benefits. Our policies need to be set against a background of understanding the market environment of the sector. Despite all the rhetoric, there often does not seem to be much understanding of the nature of markets or of the free enterprise system. Primary production is a form of business activity and therefore should be treated as a business activity. All markets involve risks, and all market participants should know the risks. Accordingly, farm policies need to be consistent with other economic and industry policies.

However, the Government is prepared to give specific assistance to a single commodity where required, and the sugar industry is a good example. Last September, Cabinet took a decision to provide up to $150m in assistance to the sugar industry provided that the Queensland and New South Wales governments matched $1 for $2 price support, up to an agreed level, and that the industry agreed to a beneficial level of deregulation. While the New South Wales Government and industry agreed to the proposal, the recalcitrance of the Queensland Government, which legislatively controls the industry, has resulted in drawn out, inconclusive discussions, rather than effective negotiations on price support and deregulation. The Commonwealth Government has now decided that it will support sugar prices up to a maximum of $230, $225 and $220 per tonne for each of the years 1985, 1986 and 1987 as long as the cost of this support does not exceed $54m in Queensland. This offer is on the basis that the Queensland Government accepts that its offer of $27m interest cost on early season advances and Sugar Board stockholdings represents price support for the industry, thus meeting the Commonwealth's stipulation that State Government contribution for price support is provided on the basis of $1 for each $2 from the Commonwealth. The Government will also participate in the development of measures for farm and mill adjustment on the basis of discussions between the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries and myself on 14 March this year. It is proposed that a consultative body be established for the planning and implementation of regionally based industry adjustment, giving priority attention to the area affected by Cyclone Winifred, which includes Babinda mill.

The decision by the Commonwealth to provide a $100m package for the sugar industry indicates its preparedness to assist specific industries in times of need so long as they are prepared to adjust to changing market and technological circumstances.

The measures I shall announce are not some major change from the policy approach we have been following for the past three years. Rather, they are the natural development of that approach-an approach that recognises the central role of macro-economic policy; an approach that addresses the much needed and long awaited reforms of marketing institutions and systems; an approach that addresses all legitimate cost difficulties and the need to secure the long term resource base of the sector; and, most importantly, an approach that recognises the importance of all country dwellers, not just primary producers.
Macro-economic Policy

It is becoming increasingly recognised that the most important issues facing the rural sector relate to general economic policy. Specific commodity policy, while important, pales by comparison. We need to recognise, however, that primary production represents less than 10 per cent of economic activity in Australia, so there is no way we are going to redesign our entire economic policy for the sole benefit of that, or any other, sector. No sector, group or interest in our federal, pluralist, private enterprise society ever gets all it wants. Nevertheless, general economic and labour market success implies, by definition, the implementation of appropriate policies for the rural sector. Success means minimal inflation, strong economic growth, and international competitiveness. These are precisely the prerequisites for a healthy rural sector. We have had substantial success on all of these fronts. The BAE's projections are for rates of farm cost inflation of 8 per cent in 1985-86, reflecting the impact of the currency depreciation, and 3 per cent in 1986-87. This compares with the 11 per cent rate we inherited-3 per cent coming up, 11 per cent when we came to government. If the 11 per cent inflation rate had continued, the net value of rural production would have been some $1.5 billion lower by now. Instead of a fall of 30 per cent over the last two years, we would be looking at a fall of around 60 per cent.

Our record of strong economic growth has brought benefits to all country dwellers through improved job opportunities and to primary producers through stronger domestic demand for their output. The floating of the currency has lifted our international competitiveness to record levels. Due to its export exposure, the farm sector is a major beneficiary of this. The BAE estimates that if the currency depreciation had not happened, the farm sector would have been around $1,000m worse off. If our predecessor's policy of maintaining an overvalued dollar had continued, the fall in the real net value of rural production would have been around 40 per cent in 1985-86, not 20 per cent. The Government's general economy policy stance is, of course, subject to continuing review. It has also been reviewed in the context of this statement.
Monetary Policy

Interest rates are the main cost concern of the rural sector at present. As I have pointed out, they are not of concern to all farmers, as many have little or no debt. They are of very great concern to many individuals. The story has been put around the bush that interest rates are high solely because we are artificially propping up the Australian dollar, and that a different policy stance could simply and quickly result in Australian interest rates falling to equal overseas rates with an equivalent depreciation of the currency. I can assure honourable members that things are not that simple. The fact is that the recent stance of monetary policy has been necessary to moderate domestic demand and restrain growth in the monetary aggregates, as well as provide some stability to the dollar. The cleanliness of our float is shown by the size of the depreciation we have been prepared to allow.

While policy has been important, the increase in interest rates late last year was also due to other factors. These primarily related to lags in the operation of policy and the unexpected strength of domestic demand. At the same time, the balance of payments deficit was increasing and the impact of reduced public sector borrowing had not yet been felt. Many of these factors are turning around. Tight monetary policy has achieved its objectives, and the Government is now allowing market induced falls in interest rates to take their course. At the same time, the effects of the currency depreciation and reduced public sector borrowing are being felt. As a consequence, interest rates have already started to fall. For example, 90-day bill rates have fallen from 19.75 per cent to around 15 per cent, while 10-year bond rates are at the lowest level since 1980. The scene appears to be set for further falls. The rural sector wants interest rate reductions. It is getting them-not through an irresponsible monetary policy, but because of the success of our responsible but unpopular policy stance, a stance that was necessary to ensure that primary producers, and all Australians, reap the benefit of the currency depreciation.

In the meantime, the Government recognises the difficulties that high interest rates are causing for a number of primary producers. While we cannot accept an across the board subsidy, we do support appropriate measures targeted to those most in need which have the effect of strengthening the sector in the long term. These are precisely the objectives of the revised rural adjustment scheme, which is an accepted form of assistance with a successfully functioning administrative operation. The Government will constantly liaise with the States' rural adjustment authorities to ensure there is as much flexibility as possible in administration.

In order to enhance the ability of this scheme to achieve its objectives, the Government has decided to increase funding under part A of the scheme by $20m in 1986-87. This will channel additional funds of about $220m into the sector and represents a tenfold increase in loans supported under the scheme since 1982-83. We have also decided to conduct a program to ensure that primary producers are aware of the provisions of the scheme as it may affect them. In addition, the Government has reviewed the foreign investment guidelines relating to rural land. In the current economic climate, the restriction could be acting to exacerbate the declines in land prices that are occurring in some areas. We have decided, therefore, to lift the threshold above which foreign investment proposals are subject to approval from $1m to $3m. This effectively exempt the majority of rural properties, without allowing massive purchases to go unchecked.
Fiscal Policy

Agro-political spokesmen have, for some years, been very fond of calling for reduced public spending and borrowing. This is based on the links between spending, borrowing, taxation, interest rates, inflation and the exchange rate. There has always been an excessively ideological aspect to this position, but the Government recognises that these links do exist. As a result, the Government has committed itself to the trilogy, whereby the Budget deficit, Commonwealth spending and the burden of taxation should not increase as a share of gross domestic product over the life of the current Parliament. This is the most severe self-discipline ever imposed on any Australian government.

A shift in the mix of economic policy, with fiscal policy playing a larger role to reduce the burden of monetary policy, is an important objective this year. This represents a necessary tightening of fiscal policy at a time of rising capital market demands. As such it will not exert a depressing influence on economic activity, but will leave room for private sector expansion. The rural sector will benefit, mainly because of the further easing of financial market and interest rate pressures to which such restraint contributes. This stance does imply, however, the closest scrutiny of all outlay items. No portfolio can be exempt from this, least of all my Department, relating as it does to a constituency that has always supported reduced expenditure. Nevertheless, in addition to the cost of the decisions I am announcing today, and because of the problems facing the rural sector, the Government has decided to give high priority to retaining those expenditure programs which affect the farm sector in the 1986-87 Budget. The benefits to primary producers could be much greater, and come on top of the benefits of the recent fuel price decisions.

On the taxation side, the Government has announced a number of measures to improve the operation of the taxation system in terms of its impact on both economic activity and equity across individuals. This has centred on a crackdown on tax avoidance and evasion opportunities-the $3,000m leakage allowed by our opponents in the past. Because of the substantial reductions in tax rates that are at the heart of this package, the farm sector will be a major beneficiary. Some of the decisions embodied in the tax package have been subject to criticism from rural spokesmen. By and large, I reject this criticism. The capital gains tax is necessary for the proper taxation of all forms of income. It has been designed carefully so as to effectively exempt the farm sector without creating a tax shelter. The great majority of rural properties will not be subject to the tax for generations, if ever. Similarly, the fringe benefits tax will bring in to account forms of income currently untaxed.

The major criticism has focused on the proposal to quarantine farm income for taxation purposes. The Government has reviewed this matter and, in the light of some potential inequities, has decided not to proceed with this measure but to pursue an alternative approach. This represents a cost to revenue of $65m. The problem of tax abuse in the primary production area will now be addressed with more closely targeted remedies. As a first step, we have decided that breeding costs by registered stud breeders up to the time of birth of progeny are to be taken into account in the trading stock valuation for income tax purposes.

The Government's motivation regarding quarantining was correct. Many of us will agree with the phrase `we are living beyond our means'. I would be happier with the phrase if it were not being uttered by the `haves' instead of the `have nots'. There is no reason why the community should allow tax shelters so that those with high incomes can make massive capital gains and push up the price of farm land in the process. If the claims of some of the critics of quarantining could be believed, we could expect a substantial recovery in land prices to result from this decision. Unfortunately, I do not expect this to be the case-the fundamental cause of the weakness in rural land prices is the low level of farm incomes.
Wages Policy

The central tenet of much rural criticism of the Government's economic policy relates to our wages policy. I want clearly to state here and now that, given the demonstrable success of the Government's wages policy, we are not about to change our basic direction. Our current centralised wages system is working, with wage inflation having fallen dramatically while still allowing real incomes to be maintained. As a result, the previous imbalance in factor shares has been corrected. This development has played a large part in the achievement of strong economic and employment growth.

Critics of the system need to demonstrate that an alternative system could deliver more in terms of wage restraint and reduced industrial disputation. The facts of history are against them. The catchcry of many critics is the need for `flexibility' in wage setting. In most cases, they do not know what they are talking about. The accord has, for the first time, introduced macro-economic flexibility into wage setting in the form of wage restraint at a time of strong economic growth. Unlike our opponents, we do not need to resort to severe deflationary policies and consequent spiralling unemployment. This capacity for macro wage flexibility through the accord has already been demonstrated by the agreement to discount the current national wage case for the effects of the currency depreciation.

The basis for much rural criticism of centralised wage fixation is a desire for `capacity to pay' on an industry basis to be the central issue in wage determination. What the critics are saying is that people in similar occupations should receive different remuneration. Why should this concept apply to employees and not any other input? I wonder whether it is also being suggested that equipment suppliers, banks, local stores and everyone else who supplies farmers should also charge farmers less than their other customers. How is the work force to be so browbeaten that it would accept such an inequity? Farm leaders appear to believe that their preferred system will result in depressed industries paying less in wages than they do now. Unfortunately for them, the lessons of history are different-`capacity to pay' would mean that the more profitable industries would pay more, with all other industries quickly experiencing a flow-on.

Just look at the disastrous effects on the economy of the 1981-82 experiment with deregu- lation. Where is the economic logic in that? One could only imagine the effect on economic growth, on the incentive for entrepreneurial dynamism, of a system whereby every time a firm improved its productivity it was hit by a wage increase. How would an industry subject to wide fluctuations in its fortunes-such as the farm based industries-guarantee that it could reverse wage increases granted in upswings? The proposals are recipes for both an industrial relations and an economic disaster.

This is not to say, however, that there would not be some advantages in achieving increased relative wage flexibility, but only insofar as it did not endanger the macro wage outcome. Achieving this balance will be a difficult and challenging task, but one which the Government will continue to pursue. Flexibility is available under the current system, as it is always open to an industry to argue its incapacity to pay national wage cases. The National Farmers Federation has taken advantage of this in the past. The Government has indicated that flexibility will also be available in the implementation of the superannuation reforms that are proposed to be paid from the current national productivity case.

As previously announced by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), rural workers must expect that they will receive the benefits of the new arrangements towards the end of the two-year phasing-in period. Naturally, this will not preclude discussions being undertaken beforehand to settle the detailed implementation of the schemes.
Income Side Measures

The rural debate in this country has become excessively focused on narrow-minded discussions of particular cost issues. As I shall outline in a moment, the Government's record on these issues is impressive, with substantial further gains in the pipeline. Nevertheless, as the major problem for the rural sector is declining receipts on world markets, this is the area that needs to be addressed first.
TRADE POLICY

World trade growth has underpinned the health of our rural sector in the post-war period. It is essential, and inevitable, that it do so again. We must make every endeavour to maximise both the growth in trade and our share of it. This requires concerted action on both the demand and supply side of international markets. On the supply side, the Government has been most active in expressing Australia's concerns on the international scene about the subsidisation practices of certain major agricultural producers.

We have changed the abusive tactics used by our predecessors for more calmly reasoned argument, pointing out the adverse effects of these subsidisation practices on world markets, other countries including the Third World, and, indeed, on the subsidising countries themselves.

We have had some successes in this regard. Last year we were able to negotiate the Andriessen Agreement with the European communities which protects our major Asian beef markets from the intrusion of subsidised European beef. This year, the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) was able to achieve an important contribution in winning improvements to the United States Farm Act, as reflected by the United States congressional decision to reduce the size of its export subsidy program; it halved it. There is still a long way to go. Our determination to continue our efforts is demonstrated by the departure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) later today to further pursue these issues.

The problem of agricultural production and export subsidies is directly related to the ineffectiveness of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade disciplines in respect of agriculture. The Government is giving priority and using every possible avenue to ensure that the problems are effectively addressed in the GATT and the new round of multilateral trade negotiations. We are particularly seeking to strengthen GATT rules so as to phase out direct export subsidies for agriculture and improve our access to markets. Simultaneously, the Government is pressing forward with bilateral trade arrangements. An important aim is to fully secure Australia's position in the growth markets of the Pacific Basin, North Asia, the Middle East and North Africa.

Trade agreements, with appropriate emphasis on agriculture, have been concluded with most countries of the Middle East, while an Agricultural co-operation agreement with China has been signed and an agreement with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is at an advanced stage. A high level group of officials and the rural and exporting communities is being convened to develop a more comprehensive strategy for bilateral agricultural trade policy. The necessity for broad recovery in the world economy is also important in rejuvenating demand for agricultural imports in world trade. The Government is involved in discussions in a number of world fora which seek to promote policies designed to achieve the highest sustainable rate of output and employment growth.
MARKETING ARRANGEMENTS

Ever since becoming Minister three years ago, the reform of the various statutory marketing authorities has been one of my top priorities. Our marketing arrangements need to be as flexible and commercially oriented as possible if they are to achieve their objective of maximising returns to producers. I have therefore established a policy for statutory marketing authorities that removes unnecessary bureaucratic controls, and replaces the politically motivated appointments of our predecessors with a procedure that ensures that only the best people for the job are selected.

It is impossible to estimate the gains from this policy. An improvement of even one per cent in our rural export returns still amounts to over $100m. To illustrate the magnitude of the potential benefits, our decision to allow the Australian Wheat Board to borrow overseas, alone, saved Australia's wheatgrowers some $50m in 1984-85. As a further step in improving marketing arrangements, we have decided on a comprehensive reform of marketing for the horticultural industry. Australia has performed poorly in both traditional and newer horticultural markets in recent years. This is partly due to a lack of co-ordination, infrastructure, research, and promotion. The Government has decided, therefore, to establish a Horticultural Marketing Corporation, together with complementary industry selection, policy and research organisations. Commonwealth support of $10m over five years will be made to these organisations. This includes $5.85m for the Corporation, $1.9m for the Policy Council, $1.25m for the Research Fund, and $1m for research on overseas quarantine barriers.

In the 1985-86 Budget, the Government agreed to provide $7m over four years to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to encourage marketing innovation. We have also secured the basis of wool promotion expenditure, with a financial commitment of about $32m this financial year. The newly created Australian Trade Commission-Austrade-will enhance Australia's export performance, while its export, finance and insurance arm is providing extensive insurance support for Australia's rural exports.

There is no question that agriculture needs greater sophistication in producing for market requirements and developing better marketing systems. In order to encourage change in these areas, the Government has agreed to the establishment of a special fund of $25m over five years for innovation in agricultural product development and marketing. No marketing measures are worth while if the incentives to producers, processors and exporters are all wrong. Such a situation currently prevails in the dairy industry through the export pooling arrangements. These arrangements encourage unprofitable exports at the expense of both producers and domestic consumers. Our recently announced reforms to the dairy marketing arrangements will correct this situation.
Cost Side Measures

As I pointed out earlier, our success in restraining inflation and hence farm cost increases has been of substantial benefit to rural producers, as well as to the economy as a whole. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics projects that the index of prices paid by farmers will increase by only 3 per cent in 1986-87, compared with 8 per cent in 1985-86 and the 11 per cent rate we inherited. This reflects generally lower inflation and, in particular, lower fuel prices and interest rates. Today's decisions will further reduce the rate of cost increases. This is a substantial achievement, one that deserves recognition by all those associated with rural communities.
FUEL PRICES

Fuel prices to primary producers have fallen significantly recently as a direct result of our decision in last year's Budget to fully rebate the excise for diesel off-road use by primary producers. This is in addition to the benefit to primary producers, like all users, from the recent petrol price reductions. These decisions are saving farmers over $300m per year. Primary producers are the only users in receipt of this full rebate. It has been suggested that we should extend the rebate to include petrol excise. This raises a number of difficulties with respect to cost, equity and administration. The Industries Assistance Commission is considering the fuel excise system. In considering its report, the Government does not envisage a reduction in the benefits to primary producers represented by the current diesel exemption.
FERTILISERS

The Government currently provides assistance to fertiliser consumption through subsidies costing some $55m annually. We have also provided a $10m subsidy so as to exempt farmers from the effects of anti-dumping action on certain fertiliser imports. Both these measures are currently subject to review. As recognised by the National Farmers Federation, fertiliser subsidisation is less than an ideal method of delivering assistance to primary producers. Nevertheless, in the light of current rural sector problems, the Government has decided that the overall cost of fertilisers to farmers will not increase as a result of any decisions which may flow from these reviews.
TARIFFS AND INDUSTRY POLICY

There has been increasing recognition by primary producers in recent years of the costs to them of tariffs and other forms of industry protection. As a result, farmers have come to realise that they have effectively been sold out over the years by political representatives who supported `protection all round'-that is, members of the National Party of Australia. There has, however, been a great deal of confusion about which forms of protection have been imposing these costs. Some believe that tariffs on farm inputs are the major cause of these costs. Others tend to ignore the costs arising from protection for some agricultural commodities. The fact is that anyone who is not receiving protection is paying for all forms of protection, either through higher prices for particular inputs or through a higher exchange rate and a higher overall domestic cost structure.

The present Government is the first government in Australia's history to adopt a program of protection reductions on a long term sustainable basis. Our approach is to consider each industry's situation and difficulties, and implement a package of measures that reduce unwarranted assistance while strengthening the industry's long term competitive position and prospects. Such packages have been implemented for the steel and car industries in particular, along with some smaller industries. Rural industries cannot expect to be exempted. Our decisions on the dairy, tobacco and dried vine fruits industries include aspects that reduce the high levels of assistance these industries receive. In a number of cases, the forms of regulation and assistance provided to rural industries are perverse in their operation. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the sugar industry, where the regulatory framework redistributes income within the industry resulting in higher costs to the industry as a whole.

The Government will be continuing with its present approach when considering the reports of the Industries Assistance Commission on industries currently under inquiry. These include textiles, clothing and footwear, pulp and paper, and the chemical and plastics industries. This will result in all major highly protected industries having been reviewed since we came to office. As a result, over time, decisions on these industries will further reduce reliance on high levels of protection and promote internationally competitive activities.

The Government is confident that the continued application and extension of its policies towards manufacturing, with competing interests properly balanced and in full co-operation with affected parties, will progressively reduce the costs of protection imposed on the farm sector. The Government also carefully considers the forms of assistance, in order to minimise the impact on users. Accordingly, it was decided in last year's Budget to replace the tariff on grain harvesters with a bounty, so reducing farm costs by some $14m per year.

The Government has now decided to take further action to reduce tariff-induced farm input costs. The tariffs on agricultural and horticultural machinery for soil preparation and cultivation will be replaced with a bounty providing equivalent assistance. The IAC will be requested to advise on the appropriate bounty level and arrangements. These will apply from today, cover existing stocks, and will cost an estimated $39m in the first year. In last year's Budget Speech, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated that the Government was disposed to replace tariffs on agricultural chemicals with bounties when considering the IAC report on the chemicals industry. A final decision will be made in the context of the IAC's final report. However, the Government is committed to reducing the price of these chemicals for farmers, either by bounties or the reduction of tariffs or a combination of the two. In the meantime, we have decided to remove immediately the 2 per cent revenue duty where it now applies to agricultural chemicals, at a cost to revenue of $0.4m in a full year.
BOVINE AND TUBERCULOSIS ERADICATION CAMPAIGN

The bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign-BTEC-is on target to meet its objective of national disease-free status by 1992, with the BTEC trust fund currently in a healthy state. As a result, the Government has decided to reduce the BTEC component of the livestock slaughter levy by $1, at a saving to the industry of its own money of about $6m next year. We have also decided to amend section 36AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act to permit profit from the sale or destruction of animals for BTEC purposes to be offset on a head per herd basis and to be assessed as income over 10 years.
OFF-FARM COSTS

The area of downstream costs has become increasingly contentious in recent years. The Government has already achieved substantial successes in restraining these costs. Our SMA reforms are improving the value for money primary producers receive from their marketing institutions. After many years, progress is finally being made in creating a single national inspection service. This, along with other measures, has resulted in substantial cost savings, estimated at some $16.8m per annum. I might point out that, had the National Party allowed changes in the Victorian Parliament, there would have been another $2.3m saving. A review of relevant legislation has identified some export controls on wheat products, timber and some livestock which can no longer be justified. Through the Business Regulation Review Unit in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, a wide range of regulations are being reviewed. One of the priority areas of particular relevance to primary producers relates to food laws. Of course, the most important aspect of restraining off-farm cost increases has been our success in reducing overall inflation.

Nevertheless, we recognise that there needs to be eternal vigilance in this area, and further measures are required. To this end, the Government has decided to offer to the States the establishment of a joint inquiry into the costs and efficiency of wheat transport and handling. The inquiry will take the form of a Commonwealth-State royal commission, to report within 12 months. The terms of reference will be developed between Commonwealth and State Ministers.

In its consideration of the two task force reports on liner shipping and shore-based shipping costs, the Government will seek measures which continue to enable exporters to negotiate further commercial improvements in shipping arrangements. The liner shipping report calls for shipping arrangements to promote Australia's overall trading interests and advocates the maintenance of a competitive regime for liner shipping, with shipping lines free to operate commercially either within or outside conference arrangements and with minimal government intervention or regulation.

Some rural lobby groups have suggested to me that they should receive funding from their industries through the Commonwealth's compulsory levy mechanisms. I cannot agree to this request, as I do not believe it is appropriate for the Commonwealth's ability to raise compulsory levies to be used for this purpose. Nevertheless, the Government does recognise that there is a need for improved consultative mechanisms with all those involved in the rural scene. We have decided, therefore, to offer to establish a Rural and Allied Industries Council involving the National Farmers' Federation, industry and trade union representation. The Council, modelled on the successful operation of the manufacturing industry councils, would provide a forum for regular consultation on all issues affecting the rural sector, including the review of conditions in the sector and the identification of major impediments to its development.
RESOURCE BASE

A major concern of the Government since taking office has been to secure the resource base of the sector. We have instituted the national soil conservation program, which is receiving $5.2m in Commonwealth funding in 1985-86. We have also broadened the scope of the tax concession available for soil conservation expenditure to include all land degradation expenditure. We have placed rural research funding on a sound long term basis, with a guaranteed Commonwealth matching contribution of up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of each industry, and reformed the institutional arrangements. I have already announced improved research arrangements for the horticultural industry. With the agreement of the Agricultural Council, the National Drought Consultative Committee was formed in 1984. As a result, we now have a consistent set of drought policy measures. The principal drought measures are concessional finance for carry-on, restocking and restoration, and freight rebates for the transport of livestock, fodder and water.

Our nation's most important resource is, and is increasingly, the talents, skills and dedication of our population. Understanding of advanced technology and of its application to rural industries is becoming essential for future success in primary production. Commercial management skills are also becoming of even greater significance. While many of the advances required of the rural education system are being met in varying degrees by individual educational and training institutions, we have decided to examine further the adequacy of rural educational and training services.

The Government is also concerned at the relatively low level of participation by country youth in senior secondary and tertiary education. The Government has already acted to improve assistance for students and their educational opportunities in country areas. It will also be considering the scope for further action, in conjunction with the States, to increase educational participation. As a first step, the Department of Education has been allocated $388,000 to implement several initiatives to improve the access by rural people to information on Commonwealth education assistance schemes.
Rural and Provincial Affairs

As I acknowledged at the beginning of this statement, agricultural policy needs to be set in the context of the overall perspective of the needs of country dwellers. Not all country dwellers are farmers-in fact, most are not-and not all country dwellers are directly or indirectly dependent on agriculture for their livelihood. But all country dwellers, whether farmers or not, do have special needs and concerns that should be addressed by Government.
Access to Services

The Hawke Labor Government is the first government to take its responsibilities in this area seriously. Our Party platform commits us to ensuring that no disadvantage occurs to country dwellers, and to develop special institutions and programs where necessary. Both myself and my colleagues in relevant areas have been very active in precisely this direction. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris)-Australia's greatest Minister for Transport-has taken many initiatives to improve our transport system. Substantial gains have been made in the areas of improved operation of the Australian National Line and Australian National Railways, the shipping reviews to which I referred to earlier, and securing the funding of roads and road safety.

The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has allocated substantial sums of money to airports in rural and provincial centres. The number of airports receiving development and maintenance grants has increased. Coupled with assistance to rural air services, this has meant a substantial improvement in the quality of services in rural Australia.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has presided over a massive expansion in services to rural areas. These include remote commercial television services, Aussat, and Telecom's rural and remote areas program. Incidentally, the last mentioned is still to be endorsed by our political opponents. Through these initiatives, we are now more than ever before one nation, with more equal access to each other.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has ensured that the community employment program is equitable in its treatment of non-metropolitan areas. Under this program, we have so far approved $422m in grants for projects located in non-metropolitan areas providing employment for almost 43,000 long term unemployed persons. The program of Commonwealth general purpose financial assistance for local government is particularly significant for rural councils as it contributes, on average, the equivalent of about one-third of their rate revenue. The level of program funding will be at least maintained in real terms in the coming two years. For the coming year, there will be no change in the basis of distribution of funds between councils. However, in subsequent years there will be a gradual change in favour of the most needy councils, including rural councils.

The labour force participation of country women, including in agriculture, has been increasing for many years. This reflects both a greater equality of roles between the sexes and changed perceptions by rural women of the roles they have always undertaken. This development has gone largely unrecognised by many National Party and agro-politicians, who continue to cling to unrealistic attitudes on the role of women. We have decided to provide $100,000 for a rural women's access program to fund projects aimed at providing the access of all women in rural areas to services and employment. This is in addition to the national survey on the needs and priorities of rural women that is being undertaken in collaboration with the Country Women's Association.

We have taken the opportunity of our review of rural policy to consider also some of the more general measures in this area. We have decided to establish a working group to advise on the most cost-effective means of providing greater access for rural areas to Commonwealth Government administration, including the delivery of cash payments and to information on the range of Government programs. Studies by the Department of Community Services on the delivery and effectiveness of its programs in remote areas have also been commissioned.

We have decided to expedite negotiations with the States on improved travel arrangements under the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme. We have decided to allocate $0.5m in 1986-87 for fostering strategic plans for country centres and surrounding regions to provide a basis for future development by the private sector and State and local government. We have decided to further integrate rural policy development, particularly through the operation of the Rural and Provincial Affairs Unit in my Department. We have also decided to develop a research proposal on policies to increase the relevance and effectiveness in rural areas of housing policies and programs.
Welfare Measures

In the light of the current income difficulties, the Government has reviewed existing income security measures available to primary producers and has decided to make a number of improvements. Part C of the rural adjustment scheme provides household support for up to three years to producers considering leaving the industry. This has been successful in alleviating on-farm hardship. It has been decided to increase funding under Part C by $1.8m in 1986-87. This is an open-ended commitment, so it is anticipated that all applications for assistance will be met, including an expanded presence in those States currently under-utilising this aspect of the scheme.

Various State and private initiatives already in existence have demonstrated that counselling services, particularly financial counselling services, for primary producers can have beneficial local and national economic effects through the encouragement of appropriate adjustment and to reduce personal and social stresses associated with poor financial circumstances. The Government has therefore decided to establish a rural counselling service, under which the Commonwealth is prepared to provide matching funds to help community groups employ a counsellor. The service is estimated to cost the Commonwealth $900,000 per year.

One industry with special adjustment problems is the fishing industry which, in a number of cases, needs to reduce activity if fisheries are to be managed on a sustainable yield basis. Successful adjustment assistance has already been provided in respect of the northern prawn fisheries. We have decided to extend this assistance to all fisheries that are subject to effective management arrangements.
Conclusion

The cost of the initiatives I have announced is not large when compared with the total value of rural production. It is certainly not large when compared with the benefits to the sector of our general economic policies. However, these measures do represent all the remaining specific measures that can be taken for the rural sector. Any further expenditure at this time would not be justified either against the need for fiscal constraint or for equity reasons. The solution to the rural sector's problems must come through a recovery in international markets. We will continue to do our utmost in this area. In the meantime, the major rural sector concerns must be on appropriate macro-economic policy management. The Hawke Labor Government has demonstrated its credentials, with further substantial economic gains in prospect.

I know today's statement will not satisfy everyone-nothing ever does. However, in many ways this is an historic statement. No government has ever presented such a comprehensive, wide-ranging policy review from the standpoint of the rural, or any other, sector.
