TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say at the outset that this statement does not meet the expectations of the farmers. It is long in words and short in action. Financially, it is a mean and miserable attempt to redress the damage that the Government's policies have done to rural Australia. It is a package costing less than $110m, $35m of which is to be spread over 10 to 15 years. Yet we have seen Press leaks of the $200m package that was to go to the farm sector of Australia-a deliberate leak. I add that some of the media have had this statement since last Thursday, but the National Farmers Federation did not receive it until the lock-up. That is an incredible indictment of the way in which this Government is treating not only the farmers of Australia but also their representative organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: This response to the $442m that the Government has ripped off the farm sector in the past three years is an outrage. But, worse still, the Government takes 43 pages to tell us that we can live with its monetary, interest rates, inflexible wages and fuel pricing policies. This statement made today, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is flying off to the United States of America this afternoon, is a public relations exercise of the worst type, and it will not wash. It is a bitter disappointment. It will be seen as such by the farmers of Australia. I believe the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) well knows this. Deep in his heart he knows that this will not quieten down the bush. The deep frustrations and agitations of the bush will continue.

The prime reason for the failure of this paper is that it does not tackle the fundamental economic causes of the problems facing the rural sector, namely, budgetary, monetary, wages and industrial protection policies which are all adding millions of dollars to the farm costs structure. There is no denying that there are serious international trade problems, with depressed commodity prices and demand. But the international situation is not the major area of concern. Farmers have proved in the past that they can cope with those problems, providing the domestic policies contribute to their competitiveness. The root causes of today's malaise revolve around a whole range of domestic policy issues. Regrettably, this statement fails to address most of the really important ones.

There are some positive features in the statement, but even they are not good enough. There is more money for farm and debt adjustment to assist those farmers with some hope of recovery, but who could not be classified as commercially viable by traditional lending institutions. But only a total of $22m has been allocated to parts A and C of the rural adjustment scheme. There are improved welfare benefits for those who have no hope of survival. There is some small relief from the tariff costs on some inputs such as farm equipment for soil cultivation and preparation, and a miserable $358,000 relief on agricultural chemicals.

The National Farmers Federation and every organisation that represents the farm sector has pointed to the need to take off the Government charges, the taxes on the inputs that the farmers have to use. The farmers have not asked for subsidies; they have asked the Government to take its hands out of its pockets, to get off their backs. Obviously the Government is not prepared to do this. It has taken the first joint of its little finger out of its pocket. There are to be changes to the most discriminatory tax ever dreamed up-the quarantining of farm losses from the other income for tax purposes. We are now threatened with `alternative targeted remedies'. As a first step the Minister tells us:
That the question of the appropriate rate of write off of capital expenditures-
may the farmers of Australia listen to this-
operating expenses and payment of annual expenses so that they more closely equate with the economic lives of the assets.

Obviously we are about to see a change in the write-off depreciation rates. We will lose the quarantining of farm losses. If honourable members look at the booklet they will see the range of things that we are likely to see come up when the tax package hits this place. We have been waiting for that for months, as have accountants, farmers and businessmen. What has happened to that tax package? It is a rubbishy tax package and it should have been buried the day after it was produced. The Government is too frightened to bring it into this place because it knows that it could well be an issue that will result in the Senate bringing it to the test and facing the people. The Government would have to face the people on a tax package that was an absolute camel. It was put together by delegates to a tax summit after days and days of negotiation.

In the time that has elapsed since the tax package was announced, we have seen land values in this country plummet, and we have seen the security of farmers-the equity against which they have borrowed-diminish. Would any home owner in this place or in Australia like to see the capital value of his home, against which he has taken a mortgage or borrowed, diminish? There would not be one, but this does not matter for the farmer. He is out in the sticks and presumably he can take it. Farmers will not take it any more; they have taken it long enough and they have had a gutful. We wait with bated breath the alternative target remedies.

The Minister claims that the removal of the quarantining of farm losses will cost the Government $60m. How can he make such a claim when legislation has not even been introduced? The statement offers no real hope for the long term viability of Australian farmers and their families. It does not address the fundamental weaknesses of the Australian economy as far as they affect the export sector.

In order to come to grips with the problems facing agriculture, let us analyse the basic causes of the current crisis. Firstly, the overall economic policies of government-its inflexible wages, monetary, budgetary and protection policies and its taxes on input costs such as fuel costs-have forced up farm costs and rendered most farms unprofitable. Secondly, the removal from the primary industry portfolio of $442m in Labor's Budgets and mini-Budgets since 1983 has added to the cost burden of farmers. Thirdly, I mention the declining world commodity prices due to Europe's common agricultural policy, the increasing self-sufficiency in food production world-wide and more recently the United States farm Bill.

I want to concentrate on those domestic policy issues over which the Government has direct control. However, before doing so, before the Prime Minister departs from Australia today I wish him well in his endeavours to minimise the damaging effects of Europe's common agricultural policy and the United States Farm Bill on world commodity prices and world trade in agriculture. But it is far more difficult to convince other nations to change their policies to advantage our farmers than it is to change our policies. In a sense it is extraordinary that the launching pad for the Prime Minister's overseas visit is this statement today. What arguing leverage will he have with President Reagan or the European Commission when he finds-as he surely will-that the farmers of this country are not prepared to accept the statement, which does not even go to the fringe of their problem. It is an incredible farce. It is far more difficult to convince other nations of the economic courses they should follow than it is for us to change our policies. Our best prospect on the international scene will be to secure the support of the United States in having agriculture included on the agenda in the forthcoming round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussions and bound within the terms of GATT.

There is, of course, a necessity to bring pressure to bear on the United States to remove the direct and damaging impact of the United States farm Bill on our cotton industry, beef industry and other exposed industries and the indirect effects on our cereal, coarse grain and oilseed industries. I mention the cotton industry because it has a significant problem and it is probably different from any other industry. The cotton industry is now facing competition from an industry which, under the farm Bill, will receive support in the form of a guaranteed price to the grower. However, under that arrangement the merchants of the US will also receive a guarantee which will have no floor or bottom. In other words, a merchant will be able to sell below the guaranteed price of US44c a pound; he would be able to sell for US25c and the Government or the Administration will make up the difference under the US farm Bill. Already we have seen cotton prices fall from about $490 a bale to $265. The latest prices indicate that the figure could go as low as $240 a bale. This would decimate the Australian cotton industry. Let us hope that a strong case is made to relieve the industry of that sort of predatory action.

One only hopes that the eleventh hour visit of the Prime Minister to the United States and Europe is not too late. One hopes that the exercise is more than a public relations exercise and that meaningful results will be achieved. Leaving aside the international scene, let me return to domestic macroeconomic policy issues. The Minister in his statement brushed aside this matter. He said:
There is no way we are going to redesign our entire economic policy for the sole benefit of that, or any other, sector.

That is what he said and I will repeat it because everybody who is interested in the farm sector and the small businesses in country towns and provincial cities need to understand what the Minister said and what he meant. This is what he said:
There is no way we are going to redesign our entire economic policy for the sole benefit of that, or any other, sector.

Is that the sort of recognition that farmers earning one-fifth of average weekly earnings should have expected? Do honourable members think that they have wasted their time in assembling in their thousands outside Parliament House? Do honourable members think that they have wasted their time in attending rallies at Wagga, Dubbo and at places all around the countryside-you name it-where they have been trying to get their message across?

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been betrayed.
—They have been betrayed, says the honourable gentleman. I think the Minister's words bear repeating:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no way we are going to redesign our entire economic policy for the sole benefit of that, or any other, sector.

He therefore ignores the importance of the need for a comprehensive environment for our export industries. More than that, he has condemned our rural and export industries to a continuing and deepening crisis. Failure to address these matters properly is the fundamental reason why this Government statement today is simply not good enough.
There is to be no change to the accord, to high interest rates, to rising wages, to our inflation levels-which are now more than double those of our competitors-and to increasing costs and charges.

Nothing has been done in this statement to help our agricultural sector-our main export earner-to become more competitive in the world market-place, which is corrupted, I might say, by the export subsidy policies of Europe and, to a certain extent, the United States. The vital ingredients have been bypassed. That saddens me-it angers me-for the sake of our farmers, for the sake of all Australians. We are dealing with Australian living standards. Agriculture is the centrepiece of our national export strategy. The Minister almost went as far as to say that in his statement. There is an acknowledgment that agriculture is fundamental to the welfare of every Australian, of every small business, particularly in our rural areas. Traditionally farmers produce about 40 per cent of our export earnings, selling 70 per cent of their output overseas. Of our 170,000 farms, 93 per cent are owned by Australian individuals or family partnerships. It must be stressed that they are the least subsidised, least protected farmers in the Western world, producing on the cheapest land. Yet the return per capita this year is estimated to be minus 6 per cent. The Government says `We are not going to change our policies for anything, not even for the sector we rely upon so much, to try to improve our balance of trade figures', which are plummeting at an alarming rate.

Whilst agricultural policy must be an integral part of our national economic policy objectives, there are clear policy goals that should be fundamental to restoring the capacity of farmers to continue their important role in earning foreign exchange. These objectives should be: To establish a competitive economic environment that will encourage investment, research and innovation in farming; to stop the transfer of resources away from our agricultural industries by direct and insidious indirect means such as tariff protection; to encourage the development of an agricultural sector producing goods more attuned to the demands of the market-place; to increase farm profitability by producing high quality goods at competitive prices; to improve our reputation as a reliable supplier; to encourage conservation of the agricultural environment so that production potential is protected and enhanced; and to contribute to our national economic and social objectives, with equity between those living in rural and urban communities.

Labor has failed the farmers miserably on two significant counts. First, in satisfying the demands of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, it has adopted adverse macro-economic policies which are reducing our competitiveness on difficult export markets. In manipulating its monetary and exchange rate policies, it has forced up interest rates to record levels to protect its wages policy and the accord with the ACTU. Secondly, it has savaged the resources of farmers with systematic discrimination, extracting $442m--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting wage cuts for the workers?

—The honourable member ought to protest to his own colleagues. The farmers are workers. The farmers are among the hardest workers in this country. The Government has extracted $442m in its three Budgets and two mini-Budgets. This $442m-never let us forget the figure-contrasts with an annual outlay of around $330m to the primary industry portfolio. Honourable members should not think that there has been any great handout to the Australian farmer. The budgetary allocation for primary industry represents less than 0.5 per cent of the total budgetary outlay in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement has failed to alter the economic directions which are diverting resources away from the farm industries into other sectors which are less capable of earning the export income so badly needed. Clearly the Government is not prepared to reduce its Budget deficits or to adopt a more flexible wages policy-both vitally relevant to the accelerating fall in the agricultural terms of trade. Even that great trade union leader, Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, has urged on the Government this necessity. The statement does not address the need to adopt monetary policies which do not force up interest rates to intolerable levels to prop up the basic weakness of the Australian dollar. The Minister virtually denied that the Government is not propping up the dollar, yet he says in his statement:
The cleanliness of our float is shown by the size of the depreciation we have been prepared to allow.

If ever there were an admission, that is one. The statement is terribly contradictory and, probably, necessarily so. The Government should not think it is going to pull the wool over the eyes of the average farmer. I quote the Minister's statement again, because they are great quotes:
The cleanliness of our float is shown by the size of the depreciation we have been prepared to allow.
The Minister now claims:
The Government is now allowing market induced falls in interest rates.

I wonder whether the fall in world oil prices had anything to do with it. It did in every other country. One would assume that it is a rub-off; but the Minister assumes credit, saying that the Government is now allowing market induced falls in interest rates. Whilst giving some minimal relief of the tariffs on selected farm equipment, the statement does not acknowledge the urgent need to reduce tariff protection generally on a steady, predictable timetable to relieve farmers of the indirect average cost burden of $9,000 per farm per annum. This is the Government's figuring, not the belief of the National Farmers Federation. The average effective level of assistance for manufacturing is 26 per cent and about 10 per cent for agriculture. There could be no better opportunity to reduce tariff protection now that the 30 per cent trade-weighted depreciation of the dollar has added substantially to industry protection.

The Government does not acknowledge the cost to farmers of the manipulation of the exchange rate, estimated to be costing farmers $750m per annum from artificially high interest rates alone. It does not attempt to pass on to the farmers, or indeed to the community as a whole, the full benefit of the collapse in world oil prices. The full restoration of the fuel excise rebate on distillate used on farm, which Labor removed-we should remember that Labor removed it at a cost of $50m to the farming industry and is now claiming credit for putting it back on-is not good enough.

On average, 40 per cent of fuel used on farm is petrol, but the Government has said that it cannot do anything about this because it raises a number of difficulties, one of them being financial. It is too costly for the Government, but not too costly for the farmers. The benefits of lower world oil prices are denied to transport operators and those who service farm needs. Instead of extending the benefit of lower fuel prices to the community, the Government has increased excise by 157 per cent since it came to office. The Government has increased excise from 7.155c a litre to 18.3888c a litre. Honourable members should remember that the excise is indexed to the rate of inflation. The higher the inflation rate, the more the index rips off. In other words, the Government has intercepted the full benefit of lower world oil prices with a massive hike in fuel excise imposed upon farm carriers and contractors which, of course, is passed on to the farmers.

How can we compete with other agriculture producing nations when we are slugged in this manner? It is an outrage that whilst we were exposed to fuel prices when they were high, we are now denied the benefit when they are low. The Government stands condemned for its fuel robbery and deceit. The Government has not restored the fuel freight equalisation scheme for those who lost that equitable arrangement. It has not removed the sales tax on lubricants used on farms and in fisheries. Of course, it imposed it. It has maintained its sneaky fuel excise indexed to the inflation rate that its own policies are generating.

The time has come for governments in Australia to progressively remove the fuel tax burden. I say that because it is an essential ingredient in most export producing industries. It is handicapping the nation's competitiveness on export markets. The Government has not come to grips with these issues. As a result, there can be no lasting and meaningful improvement in the domestic environment for agriculture. Gone are the days when farmers were capable of carrying direct and indirect burdens of various forms of indirect taxation such as excise on imports and certain types of taxation, tariff protection and inflexible wage policies which are constantly eroding our competitiveness as a nation.

Since it is neither feasible nor desirable to out- subsidise our major competitors with their massive industrial bases, we must rely on less interventionary and more flexible market-oriented policies to improve our export competitiveness. The Minister was right when he said that we cannot match the subsidy policies of Europe. To try to match them, he estimates, we would have to find $5,000m in a year. Nobody should expect the nation to provide that sum. But no longer can Australians afford the consequences of governments pursuing macro-economic policies which transfer resources from the export industries to the rest of the community. The consequences are there for all to see in Argentina and, to a lesser extent, in Canada.

I commend a book for all people to read. It is called Australia and Argentina: On Parallel Paths and was written by Tim Duncan and John Fogarty. It should be compulsory reading for every politician and public servant who has an economic responsibility because there is not the slightest doubt that the book warns policy developers and administrators of the very policies that have destroyed Argentina's economy, placing it in a position where it does not even provide an old age pension. Argentina had one of the strongest economies in the world and the highest standard of living in 1945. What has happened to it today? Argentina cannot even afford to pay the pension because the populist Peron Government bled the export industries dry to satisfy the screaming masses in Buenos Aires. Australia is on a parallel path. That path needs to be stopped or our children will suffer consequences similar to those in Argentina.

Tariffs, excise and other government imposts on farm inputs have eroded farm profitability. They are part of a network of measures which are unfairly diverting resources away from agriculture to other sectors of our economy. The failure to give meaningful indications of major economic policy changes in these vital areas is the most significant failure in the Government's statement. Honourable members opposite should have heeded the advice of the BAE Director, Dr Andy Stoeckel, at this year's Agricultural Outlook Conference. He said:

Macroeconomic policies can, at least in the short term, affect variables such as the exchange rate, inflation and interest rates, which have a direct bearing on both the total availability of resources to the export sector and the efficiency with which those resources can be used by them.

The stark facts are that the drop in Australia's trade-weighted exchange rate, on a comparison of 13 major trading nations, is the second worst, ahead of only the United States which earlier had a vastly over-valued currency. It was by deliberate design that the United States brought down its currency after a mini-summit conference. Regarding inflation, based on consumer prices, Australia is among the worst three of the 13 countries. The Australian rate of 8.2 per cent compares with 3.9 per cent in the United States, 1.4 per cent in Japan and 0.7 per cent in West Germany. On average, our prime lending interest rate stands at 19.6 per cent, far and away the worst of any of those countries. It is 9 per cent in the United States, 7.5 per cent in West Germany-in fact, I believe that it is lower now; it is closer to 5 per cent, although I cannot get confirmation of that-and less than 5 per cent in Japan.

The Government's macro-economic mix, structured on the accord, has not been conducive to a competitive economy such as that sought by the people involved in the export industries. Nothing in this statement will alter that problem. These band-aid policy changes are not good enough. Dr Stoeckel said at the Outlook Conference that the financial markets now appear to insist on an interest rate premium in Australia before they will lend to us. He concluded:
This seems to reflect a perception in those markets about the future course of our economic performance and the effectiveness of macro-economic policy.
The crux of all this lies in the ability of wages to be discounted to maintain the real effects of any nominal currency devaluation.

Twelve months after the major collapse of the Australian dollar we still do not have discounting in this country. Dr Stoeckel has done his best as the Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to warn the Government of the course to follow. Sadly, it will not take his advice. Our trade-weighted exchange rate plunged 30 per cent last year, but still we have no discounting. Our honeymoon is rapidly coming to an end. We should not be mistaken about what is going on. The Prime Minister's cause is the ACTU. He is its man. Simon Crean could be likened to the head of state and the accord has become its constitution. What the Government is all about, which people should acknowledge, is laboriously and faithfully pursuing that course. Let us not misunderstand the purpose, intention, aim or objective. It is there for all to see and comprehend. The Government's macro-economic mix of its inflexible wages system, the propping up of the Australian dollar and crushing interest rates is not conducive to export competitiveness. The words of the Westpac Banking Corporation's John Chatterton to the Outlook Conference this year also bear quoting. On interest rates, he said:

Undoubtedly, the Prices and Incomes Accord must shoulder much of the blame. Institutionalised wage indexation is a peculiar Australian foible. Even when partially discounted the Australian labour force pay increases in 1986 will be well above those in the industrial world.

Way down in this part of the world we are adopting a system that strikes at the very ability of this nation to compete on international markets. Surely we have to compete. We depend so much on exports to maintain our standard of living. Nobody will buy our products if they are not of good quality, if the unions delay them at the port or if they are more expensive. We are in a very competitive world and we need to recognise that. The Minister has admitted that there would be some advantages in `achieving increased wage flexibility' but nowhere is there any commitment to such a policy. Clearly, the Government will not change its wages policy. The proposed deferral of the so-called productivity superannuation deal with the ACTU is just not good enough. The farmers, with their depressed incomes, cannot afford such a union dominated scheme designed to introduce compulsory unionism by stealth. That is what it is all about, because unless a person is a member of a union-most farm employees are not members of unions-there is no benefit. Let us hope that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission listens to the arguments for and against.

Until there is a renegotiation of the accord there can be no substantial economic recovery in this nation. On the basis that labour makes up around 60 per cent of off-farm costs, overall labour costs represent up to 30 per cent of gross farm returns. It is essential that there be some sort of flexibility in the system. The master plan devised by the faceless men of the ACTU is costing every Australian dearly-most of all our future generations, who stand to inherit a heavy legacy of debt. It is outrageous that a section of the community led by a few power-hungry trade union leaders has snatched unto itself indexed wages at the expense of the unemployed and our children. These people care only for themselves and their pockets. Battling depressed world market prices, the farmers are the biggest losers. The typical family farm business has been earning about 2 per cent return on capital invested-until this year, when it will be minus 6 per cent. In the past farmers benefited from some capital appreciation. This Government has seen to that. Today family farms are almost unsaleable.

Last year overseas financial interests, in passing their judgment on the Hawke Government, collapsed our trade weighted dollar by nearly 30 per cent. The Government then manipulated the financial system to stop the dollar collapsing to its real level. So much for its market forces and deregulation of the financial system. The Government bloated interest rates by 6 to 7 per cent to satisfy its own plan to save the accord-costing farmers $750m in a full year. These are sorts of costs that we do not see up on the notice board but they are there, as indirect costs, if we calculate them. The financial security of thousands of farmers and their families has now been devastated by Labor's unrelenting manipulation of the financial system. While our interest rates have reached record levels, overseas rates have fallen. American rates have fallen from 10.5 per cent to 9 per cent; in West Germany rates have fallen from 8 per cent to 7.5 per cent; and in Japan, from 5.5 per cent to 4.5 per cent. Of the 13 major competing nations I mentioned earlier, 11 have experienced cuts to interest rates over the last year. Interest rates rose in two countries-Canada and Australia. The Canadian rates are up 0.5 per cent. Over the same period, Australian rates rose over 6 per cent and even now, following recent falls, are 5 per cent higher, at 19.6 per cent.

This is a Government of records-record farm debt, record real interest rates, and record external debt. The Government's policy mix has contributed to the farmers' crashing incomes, now estimated at a net $3,800 average income per farm this year. Now we learn today of a further 21 per cent forecast drop in the real net value of rural production-a key indicator of farm incomes. This figure has only just come to light. We have a drop of a further 21 per cent, remembering that the drop the year before was 40 per cent. We are ending up in this country with a rural poverty ghetto. This statement is designed to redress that. The Prime Minister has flown off, with his bags full, to tell President Reagan what he has done to Australian farmers and would he please come to our aid and knock off the farm Bill. It would be laughable if it were not so serious. The Minister by his own words has indicated the farm crisis will worsen dramatically in 1986-87. He is absolutely right. One cannot describe as equitable a policy mix which has resulted in the total farm interest bill exceeding total net farm incomes.

The Government's failure to tackle interest rates effectively is an attack on the living standards of the average Australian. The Minister in his statement has made soothing noises about interest rates, while taking no substantive action. In this House on 22 August last year the Minister forecast:
This Budget will bring interest rates down.

Mind you, he was the only one brave enough to say it. The prime rate was then 17.5 per cent. Today it is 19.6 per cent. Of course it did rise to over 20 per cent. Today he forecasts that `The scene appears to be set for further falls'. If his past predictions are any guide, we had better prepare for the worst.

The Minister attempts to claim credit for reducing production costs. Let us look at the facts relative to our competitors. General inflation rates in Australia are running at about double the average of our major competing nations. A comparison of wholesale price index movements shows Australia's rate to be six times the average. Labor's policies have removed Australia from the low end of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development range of inflation levels to the high end. I am sick and tired of hearing people, particularly those opposite, say that the inflation rate was worse when we were in government. So was the world's inflation rate. We were at the lower end of the OECD range, yet today we are at the higher end. Farmers' domestic production costs have increased at twice the speed of their overseas competitors since this Government came to office. The ratio of prices received to those paid has dropped 12 points, from 85 to 73, in three years. Worse, there has been a further plunge of six points in the last half of 1985, against the long term trend of two points in a full year.

The third economic policy area identified at Outlook by Dr Stoeckel is the value of the Australian dollar. What substantial action has been taken, firstly, to restore confidence in the Australian dollar and, secondly, to stop the manipulation of the exchange rate? The problem with the current dirty float is that export returns have risen about 2 per cent this year, but the cost of imported farm inputs is up by a devastating 25 per cent. The dirty float has left farmers betwixt and between-unable to gain improved incomes but having to pay inflationary cost increases. In many industries the devaluation has not resulted in higher prices for products. In fact, in some instances commodity prices have fallen substantially. If the interest rates were not being forced to artificially high levels and the dollar allowed to find its true market position, it would help to correct this massive imbalance. Labor's economic strategy has hurt the farmers, and three good seasons have not rescued them. They are battling depressed world prices and high domestic costs when compared to our overseas competitors. The Government has failed to give full relief from the cost burdens it is imposing on fuel prices including petrol, farm machinery and parts. It is a message the farm organisations have battled desperately to get home to all Australians, but it has been to no avail.

I address those initiatives put forward by the Minister in the light of my 14-point plan submitted earlier this year. This plan addresses the crisis, not as a magic cure-all, but as a series of constructive policy actions which could be taken to reduce the cost burden on the export oriented farm sector. Sadly, the Hawke Government has failed to come to grips with the farm crisis. Let us see how this Government has responded to the 14 points. My first point was that the Government should pass on immediately the full benefits of lower oil prices to the community, including the embattled farm, fishing and timber industries. Last year under extreme pressure the Government gave back only what it had earlier taken away-the full diesel excise rebate for off-road use-but it has sent petrol excise through the roof.

Point two was abolition of fuel excise indexation. Indexation was a cunning scheme imposed by the Government to give it automatic revenue increases. Clearly, it does not want to lose the bonuses from this snide form of taxation, despite the extra burden imposed on the community. My third point related to the removal of sales tax on fuel and lubricants used on farms and in fisheries, a tax which this Government introduced. On that there has been no government initiative.

Point four called for restoration of a more equitable fuel freight equalisation scheme. That scheme was another important device to ease some of the inordinate cost burdens on country people and to compensate them for the tyranny of distance but it was scrapped by this Government as indeed it was scrapped by the Whitlam Government. No attempt was made today to return to that scheme.

Point five involved scrapping the anti-farmer measures of the tax package. At least, the Government has acted on this point by abandoning its vicious, discriminatory quarantining farm losses provision, but let me underline the point. This has not cost the Government a cent, but we now face another or alternative range of taxes. The threat of this tax measure and this package has cost farmers plenty. Combined with the capital gains tax proposals and high interest rates, these factors have accelerated the crash in land prices and brought about almost a standstill in land sales. The widespread crash in land prices has undermined farmers' equity with many farmers unable to justify their debt load. The Government's package has failed to address this fundamental problem.

My sixth point called for a backing off from the 3 per cent productivity superannuation deal. There has been no such commitment today, except to say that it will be postponed or put down the track up to two years. It will be as flexible as that. This is a ludicrous move designed with one purpose in mind, which is to transfer billions of dollars in resources to the effective control of the trade union movement and to achieve compulsory union membership by stealth.

Point seven related to greater flexibility of wages policy to take account of industry's capacity to pay. Australia stands alone in its inflexible wages policy which is destroying our competitiveness as a trading nation. Yet this Government of the people by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and for the Australian Council of Trade Unions has made no effort to change, and it is a sell-out to the union movement. It would have been well advised to heed the advice of one of our great trade union leaders, one of the most responsible people in the nation, Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon.

Point eight concerned a change in the economic strategy to ease interest rates-perhaps one of the biggest failings of this document. The Labor Cabinet has not had the courage to change its mix of policies because it does not want to face a renegotiation of the accord.
Point nine called for a clean float of the Australian dollar. The obsession to prop up the dollar by maintaining high interest rates is designed to avoid any renegotiation of the accord.

Point 10 sought the provision of immediate substantial funds to the rural adjustment scheme. It is true that the extra $22m is welcomed. This $22m outlay should give producers access to an additional $220m in loans from commercial sources. But I hope that the Government will honour its commitment to ensure that there is as much flexibility as possible in the administration of the scheme because dozens of people in great financial difficulty are coming to me saying that they cannot get any assistance from the rural assistance scheme.

I would also point out that under the revised scheme the States and the Northern Territory are required to pay 50 per cent of the interest concession-that is, to match these outlays by the Commonwealth, dollar for dollar. It is up to the State governments to make sure that they do not act in any miserable way in administering the scheme. Further, the House should be aware that this Government has cut direct outlays to the rural assistance scheme by $27.6m since coming to office. The $22m outlays announced today do not fully compensate for that cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an extraordinary state of affairs.

—Yes, it is extraordinary. The Government knocked off $26m as soon as it came to office, and today in this flourishing manner it says that it will increase the sum by $22m. It is putting a little bit into one pocket and taking a lot more out of the other. That is what the Government is up to. It is an outrage. In fact, the combined funding for the rural assistance scheme and drought relief was $125m in 1982-83 against $16.9m this year. That statement speaks for itself.
—That is a shame-an absolute shame.

—It is shameful-in fact, a disgrace. I wish the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) were here to respond in the way only he can. If he were here, he would be absolutely outraged. Point 11 concerned the replacement of tariffs on agricultural chemicals, farm machinery and parts with bounties. I welcome the move to replace the tariff on some agricultural and horticultural machinery used for soil preparation and so on with a bounty and to remove the 2 per cent duty on agricultural chemicals. But that does not go far enough. Bounties should apply to all farm machinery and parts in this hour of crisis. There is no way that the farmers, embattled and beleaguered as they are, with incomes about a fifth of average weekly earnings, should be called upon to pay a tariff on inputs to sustain industries and employment in those industries. If it is necessary-and it probably is a social requirement and a necessity-to protect jobs in those industries, it should be a charge against the pockets of every Australian. Equity is all farmers ask for. I repeat that bounties should apply to all farm machinery and parts. The Government should have been prepared to live up to its promise to reduce the price of chemicals for farmers by replacing tariffs with bounties. Instead, we have today another promise, and the Government continues to avoid taking any action by hiding behind the Industries Assistance Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to point 12, which is the abolition of export inspection charges to producers. One of the misleading statements this Government loves to spread is that the coalition was responsible for vastly increased export charges. Let that fallacy be buried once and for all today. We did not pursue the 50 per cent cost recovery in the light of difficult farm economic conditions. Labor's actions have resulted in a 200 per cent plus increase on vital wealth producing export farm industries. There has been no initiative to reduce this cost burden imposed by this Government, and that is a grave indictment of Labor's attitudes.

Point 13 concerned steady predictable cuts in tariff protection, and I have dealt with that. There is no way that the farm sector can continue to meet those sorts of burdens without relief. Point 14 is the restoration of the tax benefits of the income equalisation deposits scheme. The gutting of the IEDs by this Government is costing farmers at least $20m a year, and this point has been totally overlooked. I turn to the reference to the depressed sugar industry. The long-awaited statement for the sugar industry has at last surfaced.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken three years.

—It has taken three years, as the honourable member for Dawson reminds us, and he represents one of the most important sugar producing districts in Australia. The contribution by the Government to this industry at this time is nothing less than disgraceful. It is a disappointing response, in spite of the major contribution to the industry by the Queensland Government. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) asked a question on this topic yesterday. I am glad he did so, because he has hurried the Government up. There is no doubt that the honourable member for Kennedy brings great pressure to bear on the Government to satisfy his constituents, but not even the honourable member for Kennedy is going to be happy with this. This contribution amounts to $72m in loans and grants for carry-on finance, with another $170m promised. The need for a minimum $240 per tonne floor price has been ignored.
—A broken promise-a totally broken promise.

—As the honourable member for Page, who also represents a very important sugar producing district, has said, it is a broken promise. Instead of the minimum $240 per tonne floor price, growers have a floor price of $230 for the current season against a predicted No. 1 pool return of $225m. The floor is $225 for 1986 but the pool return will be $237 and a floor of $220 in 1987 against a forecast return of that same amount; in other words, the support is likely to be only about $15m for one season.
—Miserable.

—It is miserable. The cost to the Commonwealth will be $10m. It is a miserable and outrageous response to a desperate industry situation. Labor has turned its back on the sugar industry and I am sure that every sugar producer and worker in the towns that depend on the mills and the industry will not forget them at the next election. It is a scandalous response to a solemn election promise and it is typical of the Government's mean and miserable approach to the distress that is being felt in the farm sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It is beyond belief that the Hawke Government could have failed to address the central issues of the damaging interest rates, inflation and the exchange rate in a meaningful way. The Minister's statement does not undo the destruction that these factors have caused to rural Australians. The question I ask once again is: How can the Prime Minister possibly convince the European Commission and the USA that they should bend over backwards to help our farmers and that they should become more rational in their agricultural policies when they know that the Australian Labor Party has indulged in an orgy of farmer discrimination?

The statement is devoid of concrete initiatives. Sure, we have heard a few broad generalisations about the future and that was to be expected, but if the Government were serious about addressing the long term needs it could have changed its macro-economic polices to enhance competitiveness. The Government had at its disposal the report of the Balderstone Working Group to Provide a Policy Discussion Paper on Agriculture. That report dealt in vast detail with the issues and options facing farmers in the 1980s and beyond. For instance, in relation to research, it stressed that individual farms are too small to carry out advanced agricultural research because the expenditure threshold for scientists and equipment is beyond the capacity of the individual farm. Whilst I commend the Minister for the changes to specific industry research funding arrangements, I am disappointed that there are no real funding initiatives to assist farmers in coping with the downturn of world commodity prices for cereals, dairy products, sugar and wine products. The Government must research more closely alternative cropping prospects, market development, packaging, presentation, promotion, the preservation of goods and their distribution, along with improved storage, transport, handling and the certainty of delivery.

If our farmers simply go on ploughing, cultivating and sowing traditional crops in the face of mounting world stockpiles, there is no profitable future for Australian agriculture. We are living in a world where, as a result of a number of well known factors, cereals and traditional crops are in oversupply. We are also living in a world of changing tastes and spending patterns, where people are seeking alternative food types. With research, foresight and innovation, our farm industries could diversify into a seemingly limitless range of alternative crops. Therefore, the Government needs to assist in producing information to farmers, enabling them to produce products which are both salable and profitable on world markets. The advice given the other day by a Moree farmer, Mr Alan Hunter, to farmers to try out new forms of cropping and to be flexible in farming and cropping techniques is worthy of consideration by the Government. There is no point increasing cereal cropping if the world has more cereals than it can eat. There is no point continuing to market products in traditional packages if that is not what the market requires. Market research in particular must be tackled in a big way, perhaps through the establishment of single purpose research units. The additional expense need not be great, but the concentration of effort could be of enormous benefit to the nation.

Australia's record foreign debt and shocking current account deficit demand a mighty trade effort by the Government. Both the Department of Primary Industry and the Department of Trade need to be given much greater priority in status and expenditures. There is a need to focus attention on the necessity to ensure that our production is of the highest possible quality. With the renewed threat of drought farmers are becoming increasingly worried that their run of good wheat growing seasons is coming to an end and I must say that it is an extraordinary state of affairs that this comprehensive statement devoted only two sentences to drought relief. There is no mention of small business or its difficulties. The statement is a major disappointment to the many thousands of farmers and their families who are in desperate financial trouble and who were looking to the Government for relief from its crippling influence on their costs. I must say that all the farmers sought was a fair go, but they have not obtained that. I think that the Government now faces some very difficult times with the farm sector and, if it faces new rounds of rural militancy, it will do so in the knowledge that the farmers have given it every chance to change its damaging economic strategy. It has let the farmers of Australia down. The package is a total disgrace.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag

1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions

PETITION.TITLE: Namibia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your Petitioners therefore pray and urge the provision of:-
1. Official recognition of A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia.
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the African National Congress and the South West Africa Peoples Organisation to promote the anti-Apartheid cause.
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African refugees who are victims of Apartheid.
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the A.N.C. and S.W.A.P.O. education departments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Scott and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Sheep
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

According to the Senate Select Committee report 1 million sheep have died during export to the Middle East in the last 5 years. At least 2% die on each voyage, in addition to the large numbers which may die as a result of particularly adverse conditions, for example 40,000 due to fire, 15,000 due to cold at Portland and 15,000 recently due to humidity near Jedda. Beyond the mortality figures, all sheep endure the stress of the voyage and the cruelty of halal slaughter (which has recently been banned in Britain).
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should accept the findings of the Senate Select Committee. In particular:
1. to phase out the live sheep export trade over 5 years and to substitute for it a refrigerated sheepmeat trade.
2. in the interim, to give the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service responsibility for the welfare of export sheep in Australia, including the power to stop abuses,
3. in the interim, to implement the Senate Select Committee's recommendations regarding the improvement of current conditions and husbandry practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Tamils in Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that under the guise of ceasefire the Government of Sri Lanka has largely militarised Tamil regions and has now resorted to airship attacks in highly populated areas and indiscriminate killings of civilians which is seen even by the Indian Foreign Minister as having genocidal tendencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to:
1. Intercede with the Government of Sri Lanka to desist from airship attacks and seeking a military solution;
2. To offer refuge under humanitarian and compassionate programs, to Tamils who are fleeing from the violence;
3. Abandon all direct and indirect forms of repatriation of any Tamil who has sought refuge in Australia and grant them meaningful assistance to resettle;
4. As a member of the Commonwealth, persuade the Government of Sri Lanka to pursue a political solution which will allow the Tamils to live in peace and dignity.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hand and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Martin Tebbutt
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
The right of egg farmers to run their own business unencumbered by State and Federal Government controls.
That the Federal Hawke Government aided and abetted by the New South Wales Wran Government-
(1) Has bankrupted and imprisoned Martin Tebbutt, poultry farmer;
(2) Has further bankruptcy actions on five other egg farmers;
(3) Has caused imprisonment of 13 other people on egg board related matters;
(4) Since inception of government hen quotas, some 2,100 egg farmers have left the industry in ten years (averaging 4 farmers per week);
(5) The hen quota system hailed as the family farmer's saviour has become his executioner.
That these methods of administration are equally capable of application to other agricultural industries with similar interference with our rights.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will release Martin Tebbutt from jail, order all bankruptcy proceedings be dropped, severely reprimand the egg board concerned and allow all egg farmers to only pay the egg board if they use it (User-Pays).
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Namibia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
S.W.A.P.O. is recognised by the United Nations as the sole and authentic representative of the Namibian people.

The situation in Namibia is of particular importance to Australians, given Australia's position as a member of the United Nations Council for Namibia-in effect a member of the UN, the government for Namibia in exile and therefore has a legal international entrusted responsibility to the people of Namibia, responsibilities which it must be prepared to take seriously in order to bring about social justice, freedom and independence for Namibia and genuine peace in that Region.
Therefore this humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests the Government to urgently initiate the following steps:
1. To fund a S.W.A.P.O. office in Australia, such funding to continue until a free Namibia is able to establish an Embassy in Canberra.
2. That all commercial, sporting and cultural ties with the Republic of South Africa be severed forthwith.
3. That all diplomatic ties with Pretoria be severed.
4. To give decent support to S.W.A.P.O. agriculture and educational programs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further capital gains and wealth taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of capital gains and wealth taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that `States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women'.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26.1.85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.

Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
The Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

Any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not ``windfall gains'', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
The owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement.
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and, to the Australian Government.

inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

The Australian Government (a) take new initiatives to encourage all member States of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time, (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985.

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner.

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia.
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
