DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The effect on jobs, family living standards and Australian industries of the Government's tax proposals.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are becoming increasingly aware that Australian industries, be they our rural industries, our manufacturing industries or our service industries, are failing to compete in the international market-place, and that is having very severe implications, both now and in the longer term, for employment in this country and for the living standards of ordinary Australians. We have only to look at the latest balance of payments figures, which show that we are running a deficit of $1 billion in one month, to know that we have a major problem with the competitiveness of our industries. When we look at the performance of our balance of payments over this financial year we are looking at the prospect of a deficit of some $14 billion, or 28 per cent, above the original Budget estimate. It is not surprising with that failure of our competitiveness that we are running up a foreign debt now of around $70 billion-a debt that will have to be paid off by our children and our grandchildren.

SPEECH.PARA: The causes of this failure of the Australian economy to compete are, of course, manifold and have frequently been canvassed in this House. But perhaps I should briefly remind the House that one of the major causes of that failure is the fact that we have the highest real interest rates in this country for over 50 years and the highest real interest rates-even according to the eminent Economist magazine-of the whole of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. We have a wage fixing system which lacks the flexibility to enable Australian industries to compete in the international market-place, a point which is recognised by members of the trade union movement, by some Ministers on the other side of the House and by all on this side of the House but which is ignored in government policy. We also have an extremely high taxation regime. Indeed, our taxation levels at the moment, as a proportion of gross domestic product, are again around the highest that they have been in Australia's history.

All these problems are being seriously exacerbated by the tax proposals that the Government originally introduced in this place on 19 September. Those tax proposals are already imposing additional costs on Australian industry on top of all those other costs that I have mentioned. By imposing those costs the Government is contradicting its own policy of making Australian industry more competitive, whereas in practice the policies of the Government, in particular its tax policies, are making our industries only less competitive. Of course, the result of that is a reduction in jobs and the prospect of fewer jobs in many of our industries. Of course, the consequence of that will be lost opportunities in terms of building up the living standards of Australians. All those consequences are coming about because our industries are becoming less and less competitive by international standards.

One of the tax measures which has had the most severe effect on Australian manufacturing industry has been the fringe benefits tax. There is no doubt that that has had a very severe, anti-competitive effect on our manufacturing industries and the mining industry, where already mining companies are announcing that they will not be able to maintain their current levels of employment, partly because of the fringe benefits tax. Above all, the industry that is suffering already from the fringe benefits tax is the automotive industry, which is so important to my State of South Australia, to the people of South Australia and, in particular, to the people of metropolitan Adelaide.

The fringe benefits tax is damaging the car industry because between 40 per cent and 50 per cent of all car sales are fleet car sales. The fringe benefits tax has increased the cost of those cars to employers who provide them as a benefit to their employees by, on average, about $1,600 a car. That is a very significant additional impost for employers in terms of what amounts to remuneration for their employees. When we look at some of the estimates of the impact of this fringe benefits tax we see that it is taking jobs away from people in the car industry and is reducing the living standards of all those many thousands of people who, in one way or another, are directly or indirectly associated with that industry. As I said earlier, that is particularly true in the case of my own State of South Australia. The South Australian Government, which after all is of the same political complexion as the Federal Government, has made representations to the Federal Government asking it to abandon this iniquitous proposal, because the result of it will be the loss of 4,500 jobs in South Australia. The Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries commissioned a study from the National Institute of Economic and Industrial Research, a body which is completely impartial in terms of party politics. That body has estimated that the fringe benefits tax alone-not the other measures that have affected the car industry-will take away 10,000 jobs from the car industry all around Australia. Even the trade union movement has weighed into this debate, expressing deep concern about the effect of the tax on the automotive industry.

The Vehicle Builders Employees Federation estimates that up to 25,000 jobs will be lost as a result of the fringe benefits tax and other tax measures. When we look at the effect of this tax on the sales in the industry, we can see why so many jobs inevitably will be lost as a result of it. Again, referring to the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries study, it estimates that in 1986 some 35,000 cars will not be sold because of this tax and that in subsequent years after 1986 about 25,000 cars a year will not be sold. As a total, following all the measures the Government has recently introduced, as well as other issues such as the devaluation of the dollar, we are looking at the car industry losing sales this year of some 90,000 units. Devaluation of the dollar is certainly one of the causes. The fringe benefits tax, as I have explained, is one of the causes, together with record high interest rates and the introduction of unleaded petrol. When an industry is losing the sale of 90,000 units, it is inevitable that a large number of jobs will be lost, and it is inevitable that that will have a severe effect on living standards.

The car industry plan, in which the Government has placed so much stock-in particular the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has placed his reputation on it-is in complete disarray as a result of these tax proposals, particularly the fringe benefits tax. The Government promised that its industry policy, including its car policy, would be one of predictability and certainty; but the community and the industry have got the reverse. The industry has got a complete change of policy, complete unpredictability, and that will lead to the virtual collapse of the car plan. Already the industry estimates that the fringe benefits tax will reduce sales of the larger Australian made cars by around 20 per cent. Those cars have high local content, and so by reducing those sales it will be just about impossible for the major manufacturers, particularly Ford and General Motors-Holden's Ltd, to meet the target of local content and for the car industry plan to be able to continue in its present form.

We all know that Senator Button has made these points in Cabinet. We all know that he has gone there pleading for concessions on the fringe benefits tax. So has the Premier of South Australia and so has the South Australian Government. They all know the effect of the fringe benefits tax on the car plan, the car industry, jobs, and livelihoods. However, the Government has decided to reject the pleading of all these people and to march ahead with this iniquitous proposal regardless of its effect in terms of human livelihood. Exactly the same scenario exists for the hospitality industry, which has also been torpedoed by the Government's tax proposal and, in that case, by the Government's decision not to allow entertainment expenses as a tax deduction. A completely independent survey by BIS-Shrapnel summed up the economic impact, the impact in terms of jobs, of that proposal. It is estimated that some 11,000 jobs would be lost in the hospitality industry and that 18,500 jobs would be lost overall as a result of the proposal, and that it would reduce the Australian gross domestic product, the wealth of the Australian community, by some $434m.

Obviously, this tax will also affect those producers who supply goods to the hospitality industry, and I refer to the dairy industry and the wine industry, for example, both of which are important to my electorate and to South Australia, a State that deserves more consideration from honourable members opposite. One has only to consider the way South Australians were treated during the election campaign over the issue of housing interest rates. South Australia was totally deceived then. The hospitality industry has been deceived and so has the car industry in South Australia. South Australia deserves a better deal than it is getting from the Federal Labor Party and the State Labor Party. These issues of the effect of the non-deductibility of entertainment expenses are of very real concern. Surveys taken since that tax measure came into effect have shown the very real impact of that tax. Already employment in the industry is down by 11 per cent; profits are down by 29 per cent, and turnover is down by 26 per cent. The cost of this tax measure to the South Australian Government in terms of revenue is some $5m. There is a great anomaly in all this, because under the tax proposal Australian companies are not able to deduct their entertainment expenses if they are operating in Third World markets, if they are trying to sell products to Asia or other parts of the world, yet their competitors from other countries are able to deduct those expenses. So, automatically, foreign companies have a competitive advantage over Australian companies as a result of this tax proposal of the Government.

The car industry and the hospitality industry have been seriously affected by the Government's policy and its tax proposals, and so also has corporate profitability as a result of the Government's decision to increase company tax from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. That figure of 49 per cent will give Australia one of the highest corporate tax rates in the Western world. While I welcome the imputation initiative that has gone with it, there is no doubt that this 49 per cent tax rate will create major cash flow problems for Australian companies and affect their competitiveness. After all, British companies will be paying 35 per cent company tax later this year, but Australians will be paying 49 per cent. American companies are heading towards a tax rate of 33 per cent. Our companies will be paying 49 per cent, and it is irrefutable that as a result of that tax regime jobs will be lost and prosperity in our community will be significantly reduced.

That also applies to the foreign tax credit system the Government has introduced which, under the changed tax law, will insist on Australian companies paying higher tax rates for their overseas operations than their international competitors. We are always coming back to this question of competitiveness. We are always finding that the Government's policies are undermining the competitiveness of our companies, whether their operations be at home or overseas, and of course that will have an impact on jobs. Of course it will have an impact on family living standards. Apparently, the Government is oblivious to these things. Its rhetoric is about improving job opportunities and improving competitiveness, but the reality of its policies has been quite the reverse.

On top of these anti-business measures, these anti-business policies, there are all those other measures about which we have heard so much in this House over the past six months or so. I refer to the capital gains tax, which strikes directly at the heart of the small business community and our rural communities, and to the negative gearing proposals, which strike directly at low income people who are renting housing and who are finding housing shortages in that sector of the economy and their rents escalating dramatically. Further, there is the matter of the quarantining of farm income. I thought I would not have to include that in my speech today, but the quarantining of farm losses is still going on, and again that is a tax measure that strikes directly at our rural industries. All these things added together are affecting the car industry, the hospitality and entertainment industries, small business, big business and rural Australia. At the bottom line, those industries are being affected because the Government is oblivious to the equation that links competitiveness to jobs, links jobs to people's livelihoods, and links competititveness and jobs to standards of living in the community as a whole. This is a government obsessed with its passion for redistribution of wealth and a government that is oblivious to the need to create wealth through our business sector, our rural sector and our small business community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must congratulate the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) on the manner in which he presented his case here this afternoon. He spoke well, but I am afraid that the content was, as usual, far from the mark. Let us get down to what we are talking about here. Some of the claims that have been made, particularly about the effect of the Government's proposed taxation policies on manufacturing industry, and certainly the effect of the fringe benefits tax on the hospitality industry, are just patent nonsense. My colleague the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) will pick up some of these later.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I go to the particular point about the hospitality industry. It is a hoary old chestnut that keeps being trotted out. I made some comments on this matter when it came before the House last year. Quite obviously, all the estimates that were made about job losses in the hospitality industry and the effect of the new taxation measures, no free lunches being available and so on, were just that-estimates. Quite frankly, if we look at all the nonsense that was written at the time that these tax proposals came into place, we see that absurd estimates were made. For example, one headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 October last year stated:
13,500 food jobs to go, says Amex.

That was an American Express survey. A similar story reported in the Australian warned that 30,000 jobs would be lost. Yet that referred to the same Amex survey. Of course, the honourable member for Fadden, (Mr Jull), an Opposition member, said: `1,000 people have lost their jobs in the restaurant industry in Queensland in the past two weeks'. That was just after that legislation had come into the House. We also had a survey from the Restaurant and Catering Association that claimed that about 10,000 jobs in the restaurant industry could be lost by the end of last year as a result of the proposals. Then we had the other classic to which I have made reference before, when the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) made the claim that 80,000 jobs would be lost in the industry if the free lunch was abolished. Of course, our colleague in the Senate, Senator Walsh, made the point that the total number of people employed in the industry is believed to be only about 76,000; so the claimed number of jobs lost would represent more than the number of people employed in the industry.

Quite frankly-I speak from some experience because I have two brothers who work in this industry-the claims that have been made of job losses because of the taxation proposals are just patent rubbish. There are people who work in the restaurant industry who work in perhaps one, two or three jobs under different names, et cetera. People in the industry are transient. People go into that industry in the certain knowledge that they will not be there for a great deal of time because they can move around and get employment elsewhere. Obviously, the structural readjustment that is taking place in that industry has to be for the benefit of the people of Australia and to raise their living standards. We can look at The Lobby restaurant across the road. Since the fringe benefits tax affecting lunches was introduced--

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot get a table.

—One cannot get a table because the restaurant has cut its prices in half. What has been the effect of the tax measure in Sydney and other places? The cost of meals has come down because the restaurant owners have seen that they have been overcharging and that, if they want to attract clientele and promote competition, as suggested by the honourable member for Mayo, they have to be price competitive. Certainly we have seen people laid off within the industry. But they have drifted into other industries. That is just tantamount to proof that there was overemployment in many of these restaurants. The point made here about the fringe benefits tax is just absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point made was about the mining industry. I share some of the concerns of the honourable member for Mayo about the mining industry because, as in his State of South Australia, mining is very important in New South Wales and particularly in my electorate of Macarthur. But the point that has to be made is that it is not the fringe benefit tax that is affecting the mining industry; in effect, it is world economic conditions. For example, in the coal mining industry, because of the haphazard structure of coal marketing in this country whereby individual companies do their own thing overseas, the companies have to negotiate prices and this is not done in a structured manner. Of course, if we had the opportunity to have some sort of central marketing authority for coal, that problem might not exist. Nevertheless, while it does exist at present, the industry will be subject to fluctuations in world prices and competition from other suppliers. On the other hand, the suggestion that the fringe benefits tax is causing problems in the mining industry is absolute nonsense.

Concern has also been expressed about reductions in jobs. It has been said that these have been caused by all these taxes that have been or will be imposed and their effect on manufacturing industry. What garbage! In under three years 605,000 jobs have been created by this Government. In terms of the manufacturing industry and, for example, the steel regions of Australia, if it had not been that this Government came to the rescue with the steel industry plan, there would have been all sorts of problems. But, because of the economic directions and policies of this Government, we have seen an upturn in the economic circumstances in these areas and we have indeed seen a return to better days and better fortunes. In the case of the Illawarra region, 18 months or two years ago there was 22 per cent unemployment. Over 10,000 people were given the old heave ho from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Now employment is on the up and up. The unemployment rate has come down to 12 or 14 per cent and is improving all the time. Largely, this is because of the interest that this Government has had in the manufacturing sector and because it has taken appropriate remedies to offset some of the circumstances which surrounded the downturn in the industry.

Of course, the Opposition's approach generally on this whole issue of tax reform has been totally and highly irresponsible because it has continued to support the tax avoidance industry. At the same time, it has still not come up with a tangible policy of its own. Where is that policy? Time and again last year we made the plea to the Opposition to come out with its policy. Of course, we were told in about November last year that the tax policy of the Opposition would be in place in the middle of this year. That time is getting pretty close. Like my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), I look forward well and truly to seeing just what that policy will be.

In regard to the package announced by the Government, the Opposition was more than happy to support the goodies in the package, such as the alleviation of poverty traps, the tax cuts and the elimination of double tax on dividends. But once again it demonstrated its opportunism by expressing opposition to the reform measures which would generate the necessary funds. When the Opposition's policy comes out, I hope Opposition members will tell us how they will pay for all of the promises without putting in these particular measures and reducing tax avoidance opportunities. The attitude of the Opposition was summed up in an article in the Age of 13 November last year by Michelle Grattan. In talking about the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), she said:

John Howard, who came to the leadership as the man who knew where he was going, is now the chap who appears embarrassingly in the middle, between the toughies whose mutterings have led to the premature birth of the coalition response, and the `wets' who either disagree with an Opposition opposing revenue Bills or want to keep the former line of waiting to see the legislation.
She went on to state:
And an opposition that claims to be economically responsible is now taking an entirely irresponsible position of opposing the `nasties' in the tax changes while endorsing the giveaways.
It is good to see that the old habits are back. At least we know where the Opposition now stands on the tax package: right there under that big sign labelled `Expediency'.

I said last year that I could not have said that any better, and I reiterate that view today. If we go further into where the Opposition, and more particularly the Leader of the Opposition, stands on this issue, very clearly we get an indication of just what has happened. Quite clearly, the record of the Leader of the Opposition on the issue of tax evasion and avoidance has been absolutely shocking. For example, bottom of the harbour tax avoidance became rampant in the 1970s. Obviously, the Leader of the Opposition, who was one of the leading lights of the government of the day, had responsibility in the Treasury portfolio to do something about it. After the Opposition Leader was exposed to the McCabe-Lafranchi report in 1982, he admitted in June 1982 that the Commissioner of Taxation had asked him as early as May 1978 to pass a special law against bottom of the harbour schemes. In 1978 the Tax Commissioner told the Leader of the Opposition, who was then the Treasurer:
Despite the possibility that such prosecutions may be able to be launched, I think that the specific taxation offence of the kind indicated should exist.

The relevant law was not passed until 2 1/2 years after he was first made aware of the offence. At the time-this is an interesting point-the Leader of the Opposition admitted that the reason why he could not get his anti-bottom of the harbour legislation was that he got rolled by his Cabinet colleagues. This is the Party, this is the Opposition, which now stands for rorting the tax system. It did it in 1978 and it still does it. At the same time the Opposition does not go to the people with coherent policies which would seek to clarify its position in this area. Of course the Leader of the Opposition was caught out again in August 1982 when the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union was tabled. It showed that year after year the former Government failed to institute prosecutions against tax evaders who were promoting illegal schemes costing Australia hundreds of millions of dollars each year. The third time-one would think that the Opposition would learn after two times, but no, it was caught out again a third time-in 1984 there was a report by the special bottom of the harbour prosecutor, Roger Gyles. He sheeted home the responsibility directly where it belonged when he said:
If there had been an adequate administrative, judicial and political response in the first place the situation would never have arisen.

Since the Leader of the Opposition has been in opposition he has surrendered totally to the tax avoidance industry and, or course, as he is the Leader of those opposite the whole Party must be judged by the people for what it is. Five times in the Senate the Opposition rejected bottom of the harbour legislation and it has the nerve to talk about taxation, the policies of this Government and their effects on the broader community and on living standards. In the case of the latest Bill, defeated on 19 April 1985, the Opposition's action cost law abiding taxpayers of this country $270m and that was enough to finance a tax cut of $44 a year for every taxpayer. Yet the Opposition, in its sanctimonious way, talks about community standards, living standards of ordinary Australians and the problems that this Government has supposedly created because of the policies that it has put in place.

The Government's tax reform package and the package of measures that this Government has introduced will curtail the avoidance industry because the top marginal tax rate will be aligned with the company tax rate and the Opposition does not like it. Why? Because it will catch out its mates, its little mates in industry whom it has been helping all the time. An honourable member on this side reminded me about all the honest taxpayers whom the Liberal Party represents. I was interested to note in the newspapers recently that somebody mentioned the fact that John Elliott-I understand that he is the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party and one of the chief honchos of Elders IXL Ltd, soon to be BHP, and the list goes on-pays something like only 25 per cent taxation. That is typical. If we are being fair dinkum and if we are talking about this matter with a real desire of improving the economic fortunes of this country and the ability of the average taxpayer to meet his commitments, the little people who want to pay their fair share of tax and who put in their returns properly-

TALK.START.PARA: —People like you and me.

—People like the honourable member for Throsby and me. We have to look to other people to do the right thing, and unfortunately they are not doing it. I recall the Treasurer saying that the Opposition does nothing but defend the cheats again and again. Of course we know the Opposition's position on the Australia Card which would have gone some way to improving the situation in terms of our ability to recoup a lot of tax. It has been reported that the Opposition will vote against the card and the changes that it would make. I am aware of some of the concerns on this side. Nevertheless, it is honourable members on the other side who have made their position quite clear because-
—Indefensible.

—It is indefensible simply because the Opposition members are defending their big business friends, the ones to whom the honourable member for Mayo referred as the ones who will be the salvation of the economy. Quite clearly, the proposition that has been put to us that the Government's tax proposals have had a deleterious effect on jobs, family living standards and Australian industry is nothing but humbug and it will be judged by the people of Australia for what it is. We on this side have clearly shown our commitment to fixing up the tax system, to making it fairer and more equitable and to stopping the rorts in it and and we are going a great deal of the way towards ensuring that the economic future of this country is secure. (7) Where is Mr Watkins now stationed, and what role and authority did he have in Mr Watkins' appointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Following my visit to Rome in October 1985, and initiatives I took during my visit for the expansion of Australia's trade with Italy, I asked the acting Director of the Trade Commissioner Service, Mr P. A. Hartigan, to review all our Trade Commissioner staffing in Italy. On 2 December Mr Hartigan recommended that the Senior Trade Commissioner, Milan be withdrawn and I accepted his advice. In order to attract a wide field of candidates with specialist Italian background I directed that the position be advertised.

The advertisement was drafted by the acting Manager, Personnel (Overseas) of the Interim Australian Trade Commission in consultation with the Europe Branch, Market Development Division of the Department of Trade. Prior to publication the draft was cleared by my office. The Acting General Manager, Corporate Services Group of the Interim Australian Trade Commission arranged for the placement of the advertisement.
The advertisement was placed on 16 December 1985.

(2) to (5) Responsibility for the Trade Commissioner Service passed to the Australian Trade Commission on 6 January 1986 and I have played no further part in the selection process since that time. The Australian Trade Commission has provided the following advice in response to various elements of the questions asked:

(a) Twelve applications were received for the position. Nine applicants were excluded from further consideration because they either did not speak fluent Italian, did not have suitable high level management experience, or had no commercial or export experience. Two of the remaining three applicants were interviewed on 31 January 1986 by Mr D. Quirk, Chief Operating Executive, Pioneer Concrete Services and a member of the Australia/Italy Joint Working Group; Mr G. Bellchambers, Acting Manager, International Operations, Australian Trade Commission; Mr J. Hemphill, Acting General Manager, Corporate Services Group, Australian Trade Commission.

Each Commission applicant's fluency in Italian was tested at that time by Mr Palumbo, Italian news reader for Radio Station 2EA. One of these applicants was excluded from further consideration as a result of these procedures. The third applicant, who is temporarily resident overseas, was interviewed in Frankfurt on 5 February 1986 by Mr Quirk who was in that city on private business.
A decision has not yet been taken on which applicant will be appointed.
(b) Expenses incurred by the Commission in the selection process were $1450; applicants' expenses are unknown.
(c) The starting date of the successful candidate is to be determined after consideration of the candidate's personal and business commitments.
(d) the Commission is not prepared to divulge information which would identify candidates.

(6) and (7) On 13 August 1985, I agreed to a proposal by the Acting Director of the Trade Commissioner Service, Mr P. Hartigan, that Mr Watkins be appointed as Senior Trade Commissioner Rome to take up duty in January 1986; and that he move to Milan in June 1986 to take over from Mr T. Walton on conclusion of the latter's scheduled term. However, as indicated in answer to question (1), following my visit to Rome in October 1985 I asked that Mr Hartigan review all Trade Commissioner staffing in Italy. Mr Hartigan expressed reservations about Mr Walton's capacity to follow up the initiatives for expansion of our trade with Italy and proposed that Mr Walton be brought out early and Mr Watkins proceed directly to Milan, i.e. without first going to Rome. Initially I accepted this proposal. On further reflection, I decided that the head of our operation in Italy should be a specialist, in particular someone fluent in the Italian language. Mr Watkins was not an Italian speaker and whilst he could have been placed in either Rome or Milan in a subordinate position I did not consider that fair to him, given his seniority. I therefore accepted a proposal by my Department that he be given an alternative senior posting, namely to Los Angeles.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1985-86[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1985-86 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1985-86]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Hurford:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos. 2 and 3. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government's request to the Parliament for the appropriation of moneys to continue the administration of government presents an opportunity to examine the stewardship by the Government of the nation's affairs. The Hawke Labor Government has now been in office for three years and one month-quite long enough to form judgments about its overall shape, direction and performance to date and to forecast the likely forward results of its actions or, indeed, its failure to act. After three years of economic recovery Australia now faces a testing time. The Hawke Government has enjoyed three years of good luck with the economy, which it has oversold as good management. I suggest that the real test is about to begin. I shall argue that because of the way the Government has behaved during the economic recovery it has created significant problems for itself and for all of us. We shall suffer because of its stewardship. I shall also argue that the reality of the Government's performance falls short of its salesmanship.

SPEECH.PARA: First, a little history: The economic recession of 1982-83 was the main cause of the downfall of the Fraser Government. It followed a broader world recession, with the usual Australian time lag, but its severity was increased by a series of disastrous droughts and by a wage explosion in 1981-82 resulting from trade union militancy. That militancy was supported by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who was then industrial relations spokesman for the Labor Opposition. Although it was not as damaging as the wage breakout of 1974-75, during the period of the Whitlam Government, which was directly led by the Prime Minister as the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, it nevertheless destroyed jobs and eroded the value of people's savings. The Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, has since admitted that part of the purpose of this trade union militancy was to destroy the Fraser Government. It succeeded, at the cost of the jobs of a few hundred thousand of the workers Mr Kelty and the Prime Minister claimed to represent. Those gentlemen have since had the effrontery to blame the Fraser Government for the wage breakout. The Hawke Government inherited the fruits of two policy decisions taken by the Fraser Government which were to stand it in good stead-the stimulatory 1982 Budget, a recession Budget, and the wage pause. It also benefited from the upturn in the world economy and the breaking of the drought. Thus the economic recovery of 1983 to 1986 thrust itself on the immodest and self-congratulatory Prime Minister, whose government played no part whatsoever in bringing about that recovery.

The question now is: What of the stewardship of the Hawke Government in regard to making the most of the recovery to secure Australia's economic future? It is an old axiom that in good times one stocks up the larder for the leaner times ahead. A prudent government would take advantage of the upswing in the economy to lay sound economic foundations for the more difficult conditions that inevitably arise. Let us look at the record. The first thing we notice is that the Hawke Government has been a big spending government. It squealed long and loud about the Budget deficit left behind by the Fraser Government and grossly exaggerated its size. At the same time, as I have already remarked, it benefited from the stimulus to the economy, at the height of the recession, in the 1982 Fraser Government Budget. Yet in the first two years of the upswing in the economy the Hawke Government joined the ranks of the big spenders. Federal Government spending went up by an average of nearly 7 per cent, after allowing for inflation, over the first two Labor Budgets. After three Budgets the annual average real increase in spending is 4.9 per cent, versus an average over seven years of only 2.1 per cent for the Fraser Government.

In other words, the Hawke Government has spent taxpayers' funds at more than twice the rate of the Fraser Government, and the Fraser Government was in office for seven years while the Hawke Government has been in office thus far for only three years. The Hawke Government has not put aside for a rainy day. It has spent more than we have earned and has added to government debt. Fraser Government deficits, despite the Whitlam inheritance and despite the need to spend more during the recession, totalled $17.6 billion over seven years; Hawke deficits add up to more than that in only three years. They add up to $19.6 billion over three years, versus $17.6 billion over seven years for the Fraser Government. Each year's deficit under Hawke has been higher than the highest single year under Fraser.

Instead of building up the larder the Hawke Government has been raiding it and it has had to resort increasingly to overseas borrowings. Australia is now in hock to the extent that it is close to the top of the list of international debtors. For the first time international bankers have begun to discuss the level of our debt. Our triple-A credit rating in world financial markets cannot last indefinitely if we continue to run up debt without the means to service it, to repay it. Yesterday we had yet another report of a balance of payments deficit of over $1 billion-the figure for the month of March. The total deficit in the balance of payments for the first nine months of this financial year is now equal to the whole deficit for the full 12 months of the preceding year-$10.4 billion. For month after month the Government has been predicting that the benefits of the massive devaluation of the Australian dollar during 1985 will begin to show up in a reduction in the balance of payments.

It is interesting that the Government claims the devaluation of the Australian dollar to be a great benefit for Australia. In fact, after this devaluation Australia is 25 per cent the poorer in the eyes of the rest of the world now than it was 12 months ago. Anybody travelling overseas who finds that his dollar is worth only 75 per cent of what it was a year ago will understand this perfectly. But despite these problems, month after month the improvements have failed to appear and the Government has continued to punish home owners, farmers and small business with higher interest rates in a desperate struggle to maintain the value of the dollar even at its reduced rate. Meanwhile our overseas debt mounts inexorably. Our total overseas debt, public and private, has doubled from $35 billion to $70 billion over the last two years. The extent of this debt is brought home when we note that it represents $4,500 for each man, woman and child in Australia. It now takes over 40c out of every dollar of our export earnings to service this debt-that is, to meet interest charges and capital repayments. Government overseas debt, as opposed to private, has more than doubled under the Hawke Government, from $14 billion to $29 billion. Unlike private overseas borrowings, where the enterprises doing the borrowing earn money to service the loans, government borrowings place a direct burden on the taxpayer.

Australia is like the family that borrows, say, $40,000 to add to the house and to buy a car, but instead of paying back $500 a month to the bank, it goes back each month to borrow another $500, thus adding to its debt. Like the big spending family that borrowed the $40,000 from the bank, we can feel good while we are doing the spending, but the day of reckoning is not so pleasant. The Hawke Government has been frittering away the benefits of the recovery, leaving us ill-equipped to face economic difficulties. Had the Hawke Government restricted its spending to the average annual increases of the seven Fraser years, we would have had a small Budgetary surplus this year instead of a deficit of $5 billion-and we would not be spending over $6.7 billion in interest charges on Federal debt, more than we spend on education, health or even our national defence. In our Federal Budget we are spending more on interest charges than we are on defending ourselves from external attack. No wonder we pay more tax than we ever have before in the postwar period.

This financial year the Government will not even meet its own commitment with regard to taxation under its trilogy of promises on taxation, government spending and the Budget deficit. It has promised this year to ensure that taxation revenues will not rise beyond the 25 per cent of gross national product reached in the 1984-85 financial year. Yet a 1986-87 Budget strategy document produced for the Cabinet by the Treasurer and leaked to the Press shows that the Government will break its promise this year to the extent of $600m to $700m. Thus, it will increase by this amount the already record levels of taxation. All Australians this year will be paying more tax. The Government's propaganda machine, greatly expanded at taxpayers' expense, tells us every day how successful the Government has been at economic management. What in reality has been happening is that not has it been riding piggyback on top of the economic recovery which would have happened any way, but it has also been spending and borrowing at a rate beyond our capacity to pay.

Its most trumpeted achievement, the creation of 600,000 jobs in three years, invites closer examination. During the 1979-81 economic recovery during the period of the Fraser Government, 465,000 new jobs were created without substantially increasing public expenditure or building up overseas debts. This time, during this recovery-and we are talking about parallel cycles within the business sector-about one-third of the increase in employment has been in the public sector, and therefore dependent on increased taxation and government charges. Private investment in industry has been much less significant during this economic cycle and it still lags very badly. As we all know, secure future employment will not be obtained through government spending, so this aspect of our economy, this overreliance on government spending to produce jobs, is very worrying.

Also the level of unemployment we are left with is far too high. At the end of the Fraser Government recovery in September 1981 and before the world recession, the unemployment rate was 5.8 per cent, 2.2 percentage points lower than the current rate of 8 per cent. The Government likes to compare its present unemployment level with that at the height of the recession, but that is a false comparison. The fact is that unemployment under this Prime Minister has been higher than for all but the last five months of the 86 months of the Fraser period of office, and youth unemployment is still over 21 per cent. It is worth recalling that yesterday was the third anniversary of the conclusion of the National Economic Summit, at which the Prime Minister stated that the first objective of his Government was to arrest the explosion in unemployment and then move towards its steady reduction. Honourable members will remember that all the television cameras of Australia were focused on the speakers in this very chamber when the Prime Minister made this commitment on behalf of his Government. Also at the summit the New South Wales Premier, Mr Wran, who is also the National President of the Australian Labor Party, said that the overriding objective of the summit was `Jobs, jobs, jobs'. Three years down the line we still have an unemployment level of 8 per cent, and in the latest set of figures for March youth unemployment rose again to 21.8 per cent, the highest level since July 1985. In other words, there has been some minor improvement in unemployment figures during the period of economic recovery, but now unemployment figures have started to rise again, and are still more than two percentage points higher than they were at the end of the economic recovery during the Fraser period of office.

Judging this Government, therefore, by its own lights, I believe that it has clearly failed to tackle the problem of unemployment. Its Priority One program of youth traineeships, publicised at monumental public expense by the Prime Minister earlier this year, with television appearances and youth phone-ins and other such gimmicks, is an abject failure. The 10,000 traineeships promised by July this year have simply failed to appear; the target is nowhere near being met. Under the dead hand of its senior partner in government, the trade union movement, this Government has failed even to begin to dis- mantle the restrictive practices and dated industrial frameworks that are keeping Australia's youth in the dole queue. Of all the Government's broken promises-and they are legion-this is the most heartbreaking. All the signs are there of an increase in unemployment in the course of this year. For example, the situation in the housing industry, despite the panic measures taken recently, is still very serious. In January the number of loans approved for the purchase of newly built houses was the lowest on record. The number of home loans approved by the major institutions has fallen by over 30 per cent since July last year.

The motor industry is another important indicator of economic activity and the health of our Australian economy. In the first three months of this year passenger vehicle sales were down by over 20 per cent on those of last year. The combined effects of high interest rates, depreciation of the dollar, new emission controls, an increase in sales tax and the disastrous new fringe benefits tax on company vehicles are widely expected to send motor vehicle sales diving further throughout 1986. It is estimated by the industry and by independent economists that some 10,000 jobs will be lost in the motor vehicle industry this year.

High interest rates-the highest real rates, after allowing for inflation, since the Great Depression-caused by the Government's over-reliance on monetary policy to prop up the Australian dollar and its inability or unwillingness to cut government spending and restrain trade union wage demands, are biting heavily into rural industry and small business activity. They are increasingly halting investment and sending business broke. There is a real risk of the economy being thrust into recession

Another major factor facing Australia this year is a deterioration in the terms of trade. This means that the prices that we can obtain on world markets for our rural and mineral products are falling. We have to run faster just to stay still. Every rural producer will understand this situation only too well. The drop in world oil prices will also have its effect on our coal, gas and oil exports. Of course, in Australia we always have to worry about drought. There is already evidence of drought in many regions of Australia and it is causing considerable concern. A very large number of rural districts have been declared drought areas by State governments and I think that this is a factor to which people ought to devote serious attention in the coming months.

In summary, Australia faces more difficult times this year, some of which are of our own creation and others are due to uncontrollable factors. It is a time when we should have a feeling of security arising from our prudent management of our resources during a period of recovery and growth. This is clearly not the case. We are heavily over-borrowed overseas and our balance of payments is heavily in deficit. Australia's inflation rate is, at 8.2 per cent, twice the average rate of our major trading partners and over five times that of Japan. The inflation rate in West Germany has now dropped below one per cent, and that is before the effect of the fall in world oil prices. Other countries competing with us are taking advantage of the world-wide fall in oil prices to pass on the full price reduction to consumers and producers, thereby reducing their already low inflation rate even further. By contrast, the Hawke Government has taken back, through extra tax at the petrol pump, 8c of the 15c fall which the public should have received if the full price drop had been passed on. That is hardly a sensible action for a country already suffering twice the rate of inflation of its competitors.

The Government has also committed itself to adjusting wages upwards in line with prices and to adding an additional 3 per cent under the productivity superannuation deal which was agreed to by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. On the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's past history, the possibility of the Commission rejecting this proposal is quite remote. The Government has also introduced a new package of tax measures which is anti-entrepreneurial and will discourage new business ventures, yet our new private business investment has still not recovered from the levels to which it fell during the period of recession. A great deal of the expansion of the economy during the recovery over the past few years has been due to private housing investment and to government investment, whereas business investment in new jobs and new enterprises has still not recovered to the level that it was at before the 1982-83 recession.

The Government has not conducted itself well during the period of recovery. It has not set aside sufficient of Australia's produce to sustain us during periods of difficulty. Parliament has been told how brilliantly the Government has been performing, when its performance has been based on the artificial and risky stimuli of government spending and excessive borrowing. What should we do to try to get Australia's economy back on a satisfactory course? Unfortunately, we cannot undo overnight the damage that has been caused by the Australian Labor Party's first two big spending Budgets. We cannot turn back instantaneously the effects of the excessive influence of the trade union leadership over this Government. However, there are several things that we can do to get Australia back of a sensible course.

The Opposition has put forward proposals consistently over a period, but the audience has been limited. Now, as the economy moves into a more difficult phase, our voices are more likely to be heard. We have proposed a five point plan. Firstly, there should be an early mini-Budget to cut back on government spending and make a start on reducing the Government's deficits and borrowings. Secondly, the Government should make an urgent application to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to defer until further notice the so-called productivity case and should call on the unions to cease industrial action in support of superannuation claims. Thirdly, the Government should take action before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to obtain full discounting of wages to offset the inflationary effects of last year's devaluation of the Australian dollar. Fourthly, the tax package should be revised to remove all the anti-business and anti-rural elements that will have the effect of inhibiting investment and depressing economic activity. Fifthly, there should be a significant relaxation of foreign investment controls in order to encourage equity investment and to reduce our dependence on overseas debt.

These are the urgent actions that are required to get the economy on to a better course and under the influence of a more balanced economic policy. The Opposition would then be in a position to address some of the more fundamental problems of the economy, such as the inflexibility of the labour market and the excessive regulation of business. That is a lot to do, but at least we would be able to make a start. However, considerable doubts are emerging as to whether the Government has the leadership and resolve to face up to making these important decisions. The Prime Minister is exerting no authority in Cabinet over the expenditure cutting process. Only $200m to $300m in cuts have so far been agreed out of the Government's own target of $1.4 billion. The Treasurer has gone overseas for two weeks at a critical time in the discussions. The gang of seven big-spending Ministers, led by the left wing Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), has been openly rebellious against spending cuts. Mr Howe publicly attacked the Government's economic strategy and referred to the Government as `a mule'-that is, having no offspring-yet he received no rebuke from the Prime Minister.

A public dispute has been raging between the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) over the balance of payments crisis, with the latter saying that the economic strategy being pursued by the Treasurer is based on a total misunderstanding of Australian industry. Again the Prime Minister has done nothing to resolve this serious dispute on a fundamental issue between senior Ministers. The incipient revolt among groups of Ministers and the Caucus over the Government's decision-making process-for example, over the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd decision-the interest rate ceiling decision and the Builders Labourers Federation deregistration, is now further fuelled by the revelation that the original decision to tighten monetary policy and send interest rates through the roof has not even been discussed by the Cabinet.

Unless the Government pulls itself together, introduces a mini-Budget and changes its stance on wages policy before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, we will all be in major financial trouble by the end of the year. Accordingly, on behalf of the Opposition, I move an amendment to the second reading motion for Appropriation Bill (No. 3), as follows:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-
(12) draws attention to the failure of the Government to fulfil its promises-
(a) to reduce interest rates;
(b) to bring the rate of inflation down below 5%;
(c) to hold taxation down at least to the level of the 1984-85 financial year as a percentage of Gross Domestic Product;
(d) not to introduce a capital gains tax;
(e) not to raise the interest rate ceiling on housing loans, and
(f) to bring about sustained reductions in unemployment particularly youth unemployment;

(2) notes the deterioration in the Australian economy as evidenced by the continuing balance of payments crisis, an inflation rate twice that of our trading partners, excessively high interest rates, rising unemployment, lagging private investment in new productive capacity and the severe downturn in the housing and motor industries, and

(3) calls on the Government to arrest the alarming deterioration in the balance of payments, the threat of a further fall in the value of the Australian dollar and severe hardship for Australian families by taking urgent steps to-
(a) introduce a mini-budget in May to reduce Government expenditures to take effect from the beginning of the 1986-87 financial year, and thereby reduce government borrowing;

(b) make an application to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to defer the productivity wage case and to discount fully the indexation of wages for the effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar;
(c) withdraw the anti-business and anti-rural elements of the tax package of 19 September 1985 that has the effect of inhibiting investment and depressing economic activity, and
(d) significantly relax foreign investment controls to encourage job-creating equity investment in Australia.
If we follow that plan we can get out of this appalling economic mess into which the Hawke Government is increasingly leading us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—Before calling the next speaker, I remind honourable members that the honourable member for Scullin was recently elected and he succeeds the very distinguished former member for Scullin and Speaker of the House, Dr Jenkins. Honourable members will appreciate that it is the honourable member's maiden speech and I am sure that they will extend to him the usual courtesies on such an occasion. I call the honourable member for Scullin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. While some time has transpired since Madam Speaker's elevation to the speakership, I feel that it is still appropriate for me to commence my remarks by offering my congratulations to her as her elevation to her high office and my arrival in this place were both made possible as a consequence of the resignation of my predecessor. May she have a long and successful term as Speaker. I make the observation that at times I have been dismayed at the way in which this House has demonstrated its co-operation towards her, but I add that she has certainly served her first two months of office with distinction. It is my hope that, in the future, the House displays to her the high degree of respect which her office so richly deserves. Mr Deputy Speaker, would you also please convey my congratulations to the Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate of Scullin was first created in 1955 to commemorate James Henry Scullin, Leader of the Parliamentary Australian Labor Party from 1928 to 1935 and, during the period 1929 to 1932, the fourth Labor Prime Minister of Australia. The boundaries of the division of Scullin have meandered the northern suburbs of Melbourne but the seat has never lost its fundamental working class nature. This is appropriate as, except for one term as the member for rural Corangamite, James Scullin represented the working class electorate of Yarra, which included the suburbs of Richmond, Collingwood and parts of Fitzroy.

The first member for Scullin, the late Ted Peters, was a great Labor stalwart. During his time as the member the electorate encompassed Carlton, Fitzroy and Brunswick. Ted Peters was a member of this House from 1949 to 1969 and he served the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party with distinction during a most tumultuous period of its history. At the time of the great ructions of 1955 he was the only member of the then executive to remain with the Australian Labor Party. On the occasion of the condolence motion of this House upon the death of Ted Peters in 1980, the then member for Wills, Gordon Bryant, observed:
Ted Peters always showed exceptional personal and moral courage, and political strength in standing his ground. He was a person who over the years became more radical than he had been in his youth.
It is a pity that a member such as Ted Peters should spend his 20 years in this place on the Opposition benches.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't.

—I thank the honourable member. At the 1969 redistribution the boundaries of the Scullin electorate became centred upon the suburbs of Preston and Reservoir. At that election my predecessor and father, Dr Harry Jenkins, was elected as the second member for Scullin. My fellow members are in a better position to comment on the service which my predecessor gave to this House. Suffice for me to say that he is highly regarded in the electorate, having first worked in the area as a local general practitioner, then as a local State member, followed by his 16 years in this House. In an article in the Melbourne Herald during the run-up to the by-election, a local resident, who was asked to comment upon my prospects, was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I think the kid'll do a good job if he's anywhere near as cunning and shrewd as his old man.
Of course, to bring some balance to the situation, another resident commented:
The Labor Party could stand silly Dave out this way and still win.

I contend that silly Dave did not get preselection! All this aside, I am extremely proud to have succeeded my father as the member for Scullin and, more importantly, I am extremely proud to stand here today as the third Labor member for Scullin. It would be remiss of me not to take this opportunity to thank again the many Party members and supporters who came from all parts of Victoria and interstate and worked so hard during the by-election campaign and who assisted in making the Party's outstanding victory possible, ensuring that the people of Scullin so decisively demonstrated their continuing support for the Hawke Labor Government. I would like also to acknowledge publicly the support given to me by my wife, Michele, and my two sons, Benjamin and Emlyn. Without their patience and understanding I would not be here today.

Since the redistribution of 1984 the electorate of Scullin has straddled the major portions of two municipalities on Melbourne's northern urban fringe-the City of Broadmeadows and the Shire of Whittlesea. The electorate includes the suburbs of Glenroy, Hadfield, Fawkner, Campbellfield, Jacana and Upfield from Broadmeadows, and Thomastown, Lalor, parts of Epping and Bundoora from the Shire of Whittlesea. Both these fine municipalities, with their Labor majorities, have displayed their ability and willingness to co-operate with both State and Federal governments in many joint initiatives-such things as successful community employment projects, provision of aged care and children's services and, in the traditional areas, the provision of physical infrastructure. Often the economic value of the provision of infrastructure is overlooked. As the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) said this morning, this Government has a fine record in providing record levels of road funding. The municipalities of both Broadmeadows and Whittlesea have characteristics indicative of their many needs. Broadmeadows has vast areas of public housing, badly planned and set up, with little or no support services. The Shire of Whittlesea is the fastest growing municipality in metropolitan Melbourne. The rapid growth has brought with it the difficulty of finding resources to provide essential services, further compounded by the growing expectation of local government to be involved in the provision of a widening range of services. I am proud to add that I have served the Shire of Whittlesea as a councillor since 1979 and I had the honour of serving one term as Shire President. I therefore note with interest that a large number of my colleagues on both sides of the House have served as either councillors or aldermen prior to entering this place.

Unashamedly, I bring with me a strong commitment to the further strengthening of local government and an understanding of the need to ensure that local government is recognised as a partner and treated as such in the planning and implementation of beneficial community projects and services. It has been my experience that too often local government is dismissed as some form of underlining subservient to other spheres of government. This serves only to denigrate the important contribution made by local government. That is not to say that local government does not need to ensure that it keeps its own performance and relevance under review. I am saddened that in my home State of Victoria the present process of restructure has deteriorated to an emotional and emotive free for all, with the opponents of restructure not willing to allow logical debate and discussion of the various options open. I welcome the statement made last week by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) announcing the Government's decision to continue with the program of untied grants to local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good Minister.

—He is a good Minister, indeed. I especially applaud the emphasis that the principal objective of the new arrangements will be to provide financial assistance to those councils most disadvantaged with respect to their ability to raise revenue and provide services. Another important aspect of the announcement which has been well received is the guarantee that in real terms the overall funding will be at least equal to the present level of funding. Without the important untied grants from the Commonwealth, municipalities such as Broadmeadows and Whittlesea would have to forgo many services and forestall their present increasing role in the area of community development.

SPEECH.PARA: One extremely important topic I would like to raise tonight is the Government's intention to provide 20,000 full-time child care places between 1985 and the end of 1988. To many families quality child care is a fundamental requirement, not only through choice but in many cases through necessity, and I refer to single parents and families whose financial circumstances require both parents to take employment. At present, within the Scullin electorate there are only two community-based child care centres, providing 92 places. They are supplemented by family day care schemes and four privately run child care centres. With over 7,500 children under five years of age, the demand far outstrips the available places. The provision of child care is an important aspect of this Government's commitment to promoting equal employment opportunity.

I mentioned earlier the need for proper consultation with local government in regard to policy implementation. The Victorian experience with the introduction of new child care centres last year and the subsequent modification of funding arrangements, which were implemented at the start of this month, is an example of the need for more adequate discussions by all spheres of government and interested parties to ensure that all are aware of what is required. Much of the confusion that arose was in part as a result of misinformation that was bandied around and was in part due to difficulties that the Municipal Association of Victoria as an umbrella body had in co-ordinating the individual councils. To the credit of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), the Office of Child Care, local government, and the relevant State authorities, a successful consultative mechanism has been put in place. This group will review the performance of the new arrangements with regard to both the fee structure and quality of service provided. In the meantime, the Government is now in a position to continue to facilitate additional places, in a climate where all involved are aware of what is required of them.

One of the most striking aspects of the demography of the Scullin electorate is the high percentage-some 38 per cent-of the population born overseas; an outstanding majority of these people having been born in non-English speaking countries. Some 69 per cent of the population either was born overseas or has one or both parents who were born overseas. The major ethnic communities represented are Italian, Greek, Macedonian and Turkish. In addition, there are many other communities with smaller numbers. These migrants have made a major contribution to the development of Australia. In passing, I congratulate the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) for his statement last week announcing a modest increase in the annual migrant intake. This decision is based on sound economic assessment of the positive effect of such levels of intake, and it should be welcomed.

It should be remembered that the Government must continue to be alert to the special needs of migrants and ethnic communities in general. In particular, I would like to turn my attention to one aspect of this matter, and that is care of aged migrants. Many of the migrants who moved to areas in my electorate, such as Thomastown, Lalor and Fawkner, came to Australia as part of the post-war immigration surge. They are now approaching or entering retirement. Last month the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs released a study entitled `Research Findings: Community and Institutional Care for Aged Migrants in Australia'. This detailed study made many pertinent points about the special problems encountered by the ethnic aged and their special needs. The findings showed that the ethnic elderly were more inclined to favour community-based facilities rather than institutionalised care. Fortunately, this Government's general policies for aged care support this notion, and much will be done through initiatives such as the home and community care program to increase access to community-based care. As the report indicates, we must be careful not to provide and deliver services which lack cultural sensitivity and diversity. To avoid this problem, co-operative action by governments and ethnic communities will be required.

Another matter raised by the report is the lack of knowledge about the services available. Much of the problem is caused by information not being made available in the various community languages of the target groups. Therefore, the importance of the ethnic media, especially print and radio, must be emphasised. Ethnic radio and television must continue to be supported. Migrant resource centres are also important in the dissemination of information, and they warrant our continued support. As the number of ethnic aged rapidly increases, government agencies and community groups would be well advised to use the research findings to ensure that services they provide are of relevance and meet the needs of the groups to which they are targeted.

Another topic I wish to raise is directly relevant to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) which, amongst many other things, allocates additional money for compensation in various government departments. From my experience before coming to this place, having worked in the Public Service and having visited regional offices of various departments in my electorate, I contend that a good portion of this compensation relates to repetition strain injury-RSI-which within the Public Service if unchecked will reach epidemic proportions. In recognition of the increasing costs as a result of RSI, a task force of the Public Service Board was set up to investigate the problem. Last year, after thoroughly studying the situation, the task force made a series of recommendations. A number of these recommendations were based on the need for change in work practices and arrangements, by way of altering work patterns and paying more attention to the ergonomic requirements of work stations. These types of changes can be implemented only with proper consultation between management and Public Service staff associations, that is, the relevant unions. There is a need to emphasise this point not only as fundamental in the implementation of industrial democracy but as a practical way to achieve solutions. For the Government's part, I hope that economic restraint will not be used as an excuse not to continue the speedy implementation of sound occupational health and safety measures such as the provision of ergonomic furniture and adequate levels of staffing to allow for appropriate rest periods for keyboard staff.

In the general area of occupational health, the Government has a fine record. The establishment of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is a major step forward. The Commission, with its participation of government, employer groups and unions, has an important task in working to heighten the awareness of health and safety issues within the community and, through this, in making Australian work places healthy and safe.

It is a pity that the time allotted for me to speak is so relatively short, especially when one has such an attentive audience. For that and for showing me the usual courtesies, I thank the House. There are many other matters that I would like to canvass but I will address myself to only a couple more.

Peace and disarmament are important topics: Witness the many people in the streets of our capital cities and at other venues on Palm Sunday. In this, the International Year of Peace, Australia should take the opportunity to use the various world forums at her disposal to push for greater understanding between nations. Such events as those that occurred in the Mediterranean today are very distressing, especially to our young people who live in horror and fear of possible nuclear holocausts as a result of escalating world tension.

Australia, as it approaches its bicentenary, has the opportunity to exert its independence on the world stage. This acquisition of independence is very much a gradual process. I was interested when researching James Scullin's life to read of the difficulties of the 1930s when he, as an Australian Prime Minister, recommended our first Australian Governor-General, Sir Isaac Isaacs, and encountered much opposition from a patronising British Government. Fortunately things have changed, albeit gradually.

Finally, I would like to congratulate the Victorian Government on its social justice strategy. I join with many others in urging the Federal Government to develop a national social justice strategy. Much has been done by this Government to engender economic recovery, and this is widely acknowledged except perhaps by people such as the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) tonight. It seems to me that it would be appropriate to build on this sound economic strategy and work for equity in and access to resources for the disadvantaged and needy. We must ensure that, in sustaining this economic growth, steps are not taken by way of spending constraint that affect the lower paid and underprivileged in our community.

In my electorate, which in various areas and using various criteria is highly disadvantaged, there is a great need to protect those who find themselves entrapped in the tentacles of poverty. The many people to whom emergency relief has become a necessary source of additional income, instead of a source of assistance in times of crisis due to unexpected emergencies and expenses, look to this Government to use this economic growth actively to their advantage. Thus, in conclusion, I leave the House with this very apt quote from the writings of James Henry Scullin, the words of which are inscribed on his memorial. They read:
Justice and humanity demand interference whenever the weak are being crushed by the strong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my comments on this debate on the Appropri- ation Bills, firstly, by congratulating the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) on the speech that he has just given. Certainly, he is a very fine son and heir for the seat of Scullin in all aspects and I wish him well for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight, I wish to address my remarks to the appropriations relating to the Australian Federal Police within the Department of the Special Minister of State. In doing so, I wish to raise several matters of concern in relation to the resources available to the Australian Federal Police and their subsequent capacity to perform properly their national law enforcement role. Furthermore, I intend also to deal with related issues that go beyond the immediate issue of AFP resources and which have much wider implications for government revenue and expenditure.

At the outset, it is appropriate to remind the House of what this Government perceived as the role of the Australian Federal Police before I assess the capacity of the AFP to execute that role. I, therefore, quote from the statement of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) of 15 August 1985, determining AFP objectives and priorities as a direction under section 13 (2) of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. He stated:
The Australian Federal Police Act 1979, section 8, charges the AFP to undertake the following functions:
(a) provision of police services in relation to the Australian Capital Territory;
(b) provision of police services in relation to-
(1) laws of the Commonwealth;
(2) property of the Commonwealth (including Commonwealth places) and property of authorities of the Commonwealth; and
(3) the safeguarding of Commonwealth interests; and
(c) anything incidental or conducive to the performance of the foregoing functions.
Further, the statement defines the role of the AFP as follows:
The Government sees the long-term role of the AFP as that of an effective Federal investigative body, functioning as the Commonwealth's primary law enforcement agency.

Of particular interest to us in this debate on the appropriations is the significant priority given in that statement to fraud. It is in fact ranked third out of eight clearly defined priorities. I quote from the statement:

Large scale fraud against Commonwealth revenue. To maintain an appropriate capability to investigate large-scale fraud against the Commonwealth revenue (for example, in the social security, taxation and health payments areas).
On the matter of fraud, the House will recall my asking the Special Minister of State on 13 February 1986 the following question:

My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Can the Minister confirm that the report on fraud against the Commonwealth, commissioned following the Review of Australian Federal Police Resources, details precisely the $300m per annum that is lost through social security fraud and the fact that 1,000 new fraud cases are being perpetrated each week against the Government, which is now proposing amnesty, albeit the reduced amnesty operating from today? How does the Minister reconcile the report with recent statements made by the Minister for Social Security suggesting that social security fraud is not a serious problem? Will he table the report?

The House will no doubt remember that the Minister declined to answer the question which led to a very vigorous exchange between the two of us. This is not surprising given the embarrassing nature of the report to which I referred. The report to which I refer, the report on fraud against the Commonwealth, actually went to the Special Minister of State in January this year and was signed by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Major-General Ron Grey, and the permanent secretary of the Department of the Special Minister of State, Mr Darcy McGarr. The report is apparently most exhaustive and was commissioned after the quite separate review of AFP resources which demonstrated a significant lack of capacity within the AFP to perform its role. The total estimated fraud against the Commonwealth arrived at in the report is a staggering figure of $4 billion. The estimated $300m of social security fraud referred to in my earlier question to the Special Minister of State is in fact part of that $4 billion figure.
