The remainder is primarily fraud against government income, most especially customs revenue plus company and personal income tax. It is also worth pointing out that fraud against various forms of government expenditure is also detailed in the report.

The report also reflects very poorly upon the performances of the two major bodies involved, that is, the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Customs Service. One of the principal reasons for the poor performance of those two bodies is that investigative work against fraud by them is beyond the competence of the public servants to whom responsibility has been given on these matters. It is also worth noting that as yet no reaction or plan has been formulated in response to the report, which is now several months old.

I find it quite extraordinary that a government with such severe financial problems as this Government has at the moment has not acted on a possible solution to those problems. No action by the Australian Federal Police has been ordered in relation to the report. In any case it does not have the resources to take such action. The significant shortfall in Australian Federal Police resources was very clearly identified and detailed in the earlier review of AFP resources conducted during 1985. Since that time this Government has done very little to redress the problems and shortages detailed in that review of AFP resources.

It is also worth noting that the Government has covered its inaction in this area by misleading the community about the actual strength of the Australian Federal Police. In various reports this Government has claimed that the staffing level of the Australian Federal Police is 3,034. This figure is based on a device which the AFP uses called the average operative staffing level, or AOSL. It is not unlike the implicit price deflator we used to hear about in relation to the defence estimates. It sounded very good but no one really knew what it meant. It is no wonder that Disraeli, on one occasion, was reported as saying: `There are three kinds of lies-lies, damn lies and statistics'. He was right because the actual number of police in the AFP as of 14 March 1986 was 2,580. This is 454 AFP members below the so-called AOSL level of 3,034.

I call upon this Government to take action immediately on the $4 billion fraud report and to provide the AFP with the resources necessary to do that. The extra resources devoted to the AFP would be more than recovered through action taken against the various areas of fraud which are so well defined in the $4 billion report. This would also end the erosion of the national law enforcement role of the AFP that this Government has so systematically embarked upon.

The $1 billion estimated cost for the quite useless Australia Card-it is a sledge-hammer to crack a nut-would be better allocated, in part, to the AFP so that it can properly do its job. I think that we can view the proposed Australia Card only as an absurd and unnecessary device to cover the whole population in order to scrutinise the dishonest few. It is a fact that, based on experience elsewhere, the dishonest few would abuse the card anyway. This has certainly happened in the United States with the social security card. The Mafia has taken over much of the fraud against the card. It is expected that the joint committee of this Parliament examining the Australia Card proposition is likely to recommend against its implementation because of its serious reservations about its value. Apparently it sees more merit in the systematic computerisation and integration of the birth, death and marriage certificate files held by the registries in all States. I think that they are most commendable directions for the committee to be heading in.

I conclude my remarks by again calling on the Special Minister of State to table the $4 billion fraud report and, more importantly, to take action in relation to it. Failure to do so is gross neglect of his responsibilities as Special Minister of State to ensure that the laws of this Commonwealth are fully enforced by the national law enforcement agency, that is, the Australian Federal Police. Failure to take urgent action on the report is also an act of neglect by this Government at large to protect adequately the revenue and expenditure of this great Commonwealth. Both failure to enforce national laws and failure to protect revenue and expenditure are a betrayal of the national interest of the Australian people. Therefore, I trust that we will have no further procrastination by the Minister and the Government on this vital matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1985-86 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86 gives us a chance to consider where the economy is at present and where it is going. We are at about the beginning of the second stage of economic policy. The first stage, of course, included great achievements of economic growth, employment growth, lower inflation and improvements in the social wage. The second stage begins with substantial difficulties. This year the current account deficit is likely to be at least 5 per cent of gross domestic product or 12 per cent. The growth in Australia's overseas debt, from about $7 billion in 1979-80 to over $60 billion now, has increased the difficulty of reducing this deficit because of the cost of debt servicing.

SPEECH.PARA: The historically high interest rates are used to attract capital from overseas and are ameliorating the balance of payments problem in the short term at the cost of intensifying the difficulty of achieving a long term solution. The more capital which is attracted now the greater the invisible payments deficit in the future and the greater the trade surplus needed to achieve current account balance. As well, over 600,000 people are still unemployed, a massive level by post-war standards, involving enormous human suffering and economic waste. Of course the number of unemployed has come down very sharply but it is not sensible not to take account of the present level.

Tightening of fiscal policy to depress demand for imports would reduce growth in economic activity and so the growth of employment opportunities, which must be the Government's highest priority. So despite this severely constrained situation some additional constructive policies are available, and it is on those I wish to concentrate tonight. One step is to urge other countries to reflate their economies. A co-ordinated global expansion would lift economic growth rates in all countries and provide a general stimulus to the volume of Australia's imports and exports. Each of the countries which have gone for growth in the 1980s-Australia is one and France and the United States are others-has found that without complementary expansionary policies by its trading partner countries its current account deficit rises and constrains continued growth.

Japan's recent depreciation corrects a major currency imbalance but a more expansionary macroeconomic stance there would increase growth rates of output and imports faster. West Germany is another country that could afford to expand at present because it has a substantial current account surplus and an extremely low inflation rate. Other countries in western Europe could also adopt similar policies because of their current favourable situations. If the United States were also discouraged from pursuing mechanistic expenditure cutting, the combined effect would be a global expansion of the rate of economic growth. Another policy which would contribute to that goal is renewed lending and aid to developing countries so that they can expand their imports. One current development that provides a favourable setting for those policies is the fall in oil prices, and that provides the opportunity for much more expansionary economic policies which would have, as I have said, the effect of stimulating growth everywhere.

A number of policies are needed to reform the international monetary system and would contribute to the same goal. Amongst those would be a global financial conference, which the American President said in his State of the Union message that he was seriously considering. Increased lending by international financial institutions or a new issue of special drawing rights would also contribute to the same goal.

Within Australia a third step which would have a favourable impact would be to encourage the Reserve Bank of Australia to intervene more actively in the foreign exchange market. Appropriately timed, selective action using Australia's unnecessarily large currency reserves would discourage further downward pressure on the exchange rate. Such action could be considered when the current account balance starts to improve. All countries intervene to some extent in their foreign exchange markets. The only question is how much to intervene. A strong case can be made for more active intervention by the Australian Reserve Bank. The Government intervenes by the use of monetary policy. The tight monetary policy of recent months has been aimed at keeping up interest rates and so attracting overseas capital. A more direct approach might be more cost effective.

A fourth step would be to continue with the steady relaxation of monetary policy that has been begun in the last month or two, allowing a further reduction in interest rates and assessing whether it really made any difference to capital inflow. The difference between interest rates in Australia and those overseas is very substantial. Perhaps that differential could be narrowed. If so, there would be great benefit to the whole Australian economy, not only to private sector investment but also to housing and consumption.

The large devaluation of the Australian dollar since the beginning of 1985 is providing a window of opportunity for Australian manufacturing to re-establish competitive production. So a fifth step would be to involve ourselves in more active manufacturing industry policy, possibly including a targeted, selective industry policy which would assist this development. This could be applied in industries such as industrial equipment, knowledge-intensive machine tools, whole plant construction, heavy industry, motor vehicles and white goods. One of the most important elements of manufacturing industry policy is to establish linkages between industries. There might be scope for using the public sector more effectively by expanding the role of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, for example.

A sixth approach to coping with the current problems in the medium term would be to increase the role of the public sector. Setting a fixed proportion of national income for public expenditure constraints the Government's capacity to apply effective counter-cyclical policies. The Commonwealth's responsibilities for macro-economic stabilisation requires the use of expansionary policies when growth is slow. Such constraints also severely limit the opportunity to use the public sector inventively to stimulate activity, fill gaps, provide services or contribute to equity. No Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development government has achieved in the three years up to 1983 what we are attempting. Only two-those of Britain and Germany-stopped the public sector share from rising. Therefore, we should be careful about setting too tight targets and should avoid applying rigid formulae in the future. We should allow the public sector to play its proper role in stabilisation, stimulating growth and so on.

A fresh approach to the public sector would contribute to the provision of needed services, providing employment opportunities and increasing the rate of economic growth. Australia has one of the smallest public sectors in the Western world and this may be one reason for the deterioration of our relative economic performance during the last 30 years. Many activities can be most cost effectively undertaken in the public sector. Public investment in infrastructure is essential to economic efficiency. Efficient transport and communications increase productivity, for example. Expansion of the public sector gives the community greater control over resources. One of the main determinants of whether a function should be in the public or private sector is where it could be provided most efficiently at minimum cost. That will often be in the public sector, where there will be no abnormal profits through the exploitation of market power.

Another group of policies relates to distribution. An indirect benefit of distribution from rich to poor is that consumption demand increases, stimulating economic activity. Employment growth is the most important means of reducing poverty but redistributive social security, taxation and community service policies also contribute to increasing the rate of economic growth through the multiplier effect of increased spending.

I have outlined what I think is a comprehensive strategy for stimulating growth in the next three years. That will be a much more difficult task than it was in the first three years of the term of this government. Therefore, there is a need for innovative activity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of my speech is not to recite a litany of wrong decisions made and policies put forth by the current Government but to ask why the increases in the Budget appropriations sought are cost and price increases since the Budget. In the second reading speeches of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1985-86, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1985-86 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1985-86, the Minister speaks of the need to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1985-86. Whilst I can understand the need for additional revenue to be paid out by the Government because of court and tribunal decisions, I cannot but question other factors under the control of the Government which have led to the additional cost in these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: We, as a nation, are in a process of change, of restructuring our economy from trade-based minerals and farming exports to manufacturing and servicing. There is no need to be afraid of this change and restructuring if we see it for what it is: An opportunity to make our country stronger and more prosperous in the fastest growing region of the world-the Asian Pacific region.

As a nation, we have a comparative advantage in the production of medium technology products such as agricultural, manufacturing and mining machinery, as well as the supply of services, including education and training. These services are required by many of the Asian countries to further their economic development and industrial and social infrastructure. Our ability to exploit these opportunities will be critical to our economic performance during the remainder of this decade. However, to take advantage of this situation we must be prepared to open up our markets to regional trade. A start towards progressive reductions in protection is a vital ingredient in a medium term strategy for building Australia's future prosperity. The process of opening up our markets to regional trade should not be one way.

Australia could benefit significantly from a liberalisation of trade in agricultural and processed or semi-processed minerals in return for freer trade in manufactures. To achieve this, we will need to see a resurgence of investment, led primarily by domestic, not international, influences. This resurgence has to be based on confidence in the profitability and competitiveness of manufacturing and service industries. We need to build on our domestic markets and at the same time take advantage of growing opportunities in regional markets.

For our businessmen, large and small, nothing is more important than securing adequate business returns from their investment. Investment returns have improved significantly over the last year, from record lows in 1982-83. However, they remain below the levels prevailing in the 1960s and early 1970s. To improve upon investment returns flexibility is needed in several areas: Wages, industrial policy and government spending. It is widely accepted that the prices and incomes accord may have contributed to a reduction in the incidence of industrial disputation over the past three years and to a degree assisted in restraining wages growth. Nevertheless, wage costs must be stringently contained if Australia's inflation rate is to be pulled back into line with international trends. The accord mark 2 as it stands is not a sufficiently strong anti-inflationary instrument to ensure that inflation will come down. Nor is it flexible enough to allow changes in our standard of living following adverse movements in our terms of trade and the real exchange rate depreciation.

The current push for productivity-based increases in superannuation benefits is inappropriate in our economic situation. The fundamental imbalances in the economy have to be corrected before any productivity distribution can reasonably be considered. It can be argued that the benefits of productivity increases achieved thus far in our economy have already been distributed in the form of lower price increases and/or in the creation of new jobs. If these labor costs are not contained, two consequences will result. First, inflationary pressures will increase and profitable investment and job prospects will be reduced. Secondly, a reduction in business cash flow will cause greater business demand for borrowing through the capital market resulting in higher interest charges. I repeat: Productivity growth is the key part to increased real economic growth and rising living standards.

Our industrial policy area needs greater flexibility to maintain this growth in our economy. The Government has taken the first step towards this by floating the Australian dollar and deregulating the financial markets as well as restructuring the motor vehicle industry. However, other areas need to be considered to provide greater competition, thereby taking advantage of our current market trends. Two industries which fall into this category are transport and communications. The two-airline policy is restrictive and not competitive. The communications industry is monopolistic and favours those with the most financial punch to make a running for new licences. These two sectors are vital to a more dynamic economy because of the spin-off into other areas. I call upon the Government to consider this proposal.

Following this proposal, the Hawke Government needs to give the private sector more incentive, for it is in the private sector that our economic strength lies. However, because of the high interest rates prevailing the Government has in effect crippled the private sector to the point that private investment did not provide any stimulus to economic growth in the December 1985 quarter. A recent survey by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation found a number of manufacturers are planning to cut capital expenditure, employment and output levels over the next 12 months. The high cost of obtaining finance has also led businessmen to forecast a cut in investment on buildings, plant and equipment. The declining value of the dollar has not been translated in increased levels of production and investment.

Economic forecasts are suggesting the economy is likely to turn down further by mid-year. Our current accounts figure is almost 25 per cent higher than Budget estimates, heading for a record $13 billion, providing proof that the downturn in the private sector has already commenced. Yet, the Government knows that economic recovery is crucial for ensuring a solid growth performance in the lead-up to the next Federal election. Therefore, it is imperative for the Government to follow its own Economic Planning Advisory Council advice and budget for spending cuts.

According to EPAC, cuts in government spending are required in the short term to head off an upward spiral in interest payments which add to our debt burden. EPAC also claims that public sector borrowing is in danger of increasing at an unsustainable rate and has called for a reduction in borrowings over time. Such a strategy would reduce real interest rates without adding to tax rates or inflationary pressures. However, this restraint must be across the board involving both the Commonwealth and State governments. EPAC notes in its report that public sector outlays have outstripped receipts at an increasing rate for several decades. By the end of 1985-86, gross debt is expected to rise to around 45 per cent of gross domestic product, but if public sector borrowings continue unabated this figure could rise to around 60 per cent of GDP in the next 10 to 15 years. A debt service rate of 25 per cent is regarded as high by international standards.

Therefore, the States must be persuaded to reduce the growth of their taxes, expenditure and borrowings significantly in order to contribute to reduced pressure on the credit market and hence interest rates. Improving the cost efficiency of State government services through rationalisation of State and Federal programs would be a worthwhile project, leading to more efficient use of available resources. The elimination of duplication on State and Federal levels would be the obvious starting point. Education, housing, health and transport are areas in which the Commonwealth could hand over significant powers and authority to the States. This would have a dual effect on curtailing expenditure on the bureaucratic level and at the same time give the States more financial responsibility for the running of their departments. Our nation needs less government imposition, not more.

Our current high interest rates have had an adverse affect on all sectors of our economy but none more so than the housing industry. I pause to congratulate the Government-it has done one decent thing in government-on its decision to adopt the Opposition's housing interest rates policy. By this wise move it has saved the jobs of 50,000 Australians, provided for an estimated additional 33,000 jobs, and given more people the opportunity of home ownership. As well, this has increased the estimated housing starts by 7 per cent to 130,000 for 1986-87.

However, in reality the Government has just moved sideways to accommodate the inordinately high interest rates pressure on the housing industry. It must now begin to move positively towards reducing interest rates across the board. The first step is to initiate a tight fiscal policy so interest rates begin falling.

Next, the Hawke-Keating Government could seriously consider reversing its regressive capital gains tax and negative gearing policy which has lead to a disastrous decline in private investment in the housing sector. If this Government does not take this action, fortunately for the nation the Opposition will soon be back on the Treasury benches. The flow-on effects of these two moves are obvious-reduction of the burden of repayments for borrowers and a greater number of prospective home purchasers able to fulfil their dream. However, as it stands now, the consumer price index figures over the last two years show an 11 per cent increase overall with rents escalating by 17.4 per cent. The average loan from a savings bank now takes up almost 25 per cent of the borrower's income compared with just 21.3 per cent in the March quarter 1983-when we left government.

This represents a significant increase in monthly repayments and evidence supports the proposition that people now have less money to live on after accommodation costs have been paid out. In other words, the poverty level in our suburbs is increasing. While the Government has initiated policies to assist people to buy their first home, there is no such policy to help these same people keep their home when interest rates reach astronomical levels. The solution to this and other problems outlined always comes back to the same proposition: Stabilise the economy and interest rates will fall. Instigate a firm fiscal policy, thereby generating more confidence in our trading partners and in our domestic market. With this type of action, we as a nation will see sustained growth over the long term and a drop in inflation and in unemployment. A new wave of nationalism is needed in Australia, not in the superficial sense of the America's Cup or the Paul Hogan advertisements, but a pride in what this country has been able to do over the last 200 years and what we can do in the next 200 years. However, if we do not stop to think of where we are going as a nation and how we want to get there, we will lose our way and with it our collective spirit.

A need to succeed is of the utmost importance in each and every one of us, and as a nation we need to reinvigorate this spirit and initiative. When this spirit is rekindled, this country will prosper and grow beyond our expectations and ambitions. But this requires all of us working as a whole unit, not as individuals each pursuing our private goals regardless of others. Our individual goals should become our national goals, our national goals our private goals. It is only with this community spirit that we will look forward to the twenty-first century with confidence and hope for a better life for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the passage of Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). The items included in the Bills demonstrate quite clearly the range of programs and activities in which the Government finds itself involved. They all represent key components of ongoing aspects of this Government's successful economic management of Australia. I will mention briefly some special items of note which, again, outline a range of activities. An amount of $21m is to be allocated to assist the Queensland and Western Australian governments for relief following their recent cyclone disasters. Another $52m has been allocated for the final tidying up of the Medicare arrangements with the States. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for persevering with the belief that Medicare arrangements could be successfully negotiated with the States. Everyone in this House would acknowledge that attempting to negotiate an Australia-wide deal with the States is a very difficult task which required a lot a persistence and negotiating skill. I commend the Minister for his efforts in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Of special interest to my electorate is the additional $70m being provided to assist Australian industry in the development of export incentives. We all recognise that the turnaround of Australian industry, and particularly Australian manufacturing industry, cannot be achieved overnight and cannot be achieved with quick band-aid measures. Long term structural problems have to be addressed. These programs, these incentives, to assist Australian industry find a niche, particularly for high quality specialist places in the market, is something to which this Government is strongly committed. A further $16m is provided for the further medical services for our veterans' community. I take this opportunity to reiterate once again, and very firmly, that the record of this Government on providing improved and expanded services for the veterans' community is unmatched in the history of government in Australia. I am particularly keen to point to the allocation of expenditure for the Government's national drug offensive, and I will make further reference to that later tonight. It is a program well worthy of further comment. I point particularly to a further $95m being allocated to defence purchasing. This expenditure is for the purchase of capital equipment and falls within the Government's strategy for using government purchasing to assist the rehabilitation of Australian manufacturing industry.

I want to turn briefly to what I would describe as the intelligent use of government capital works expenditure within the economy. It is no coincidence that when this Government came to office Australia had experienced a period of record bankruptcy in the small business sector. We often hear people in the small business sector calling for government cutbacks. We often hear honourable members on the other side of the House calling for cutbacks in government expenditure, but they never explain where those cuts should be. It was very clear where those cuts were during their term of office. They were particularly in the area of government capital works, in areas such as roads, airports, hospitals, police stations and schools; the sorts of community capital works projects that are not undertaken by government contractors but by small business proprietors who are contractors to the Government. It is no coincidence that after the Hawke Government came to office the increased boost for government capital works produced a very buoyant period of business for small business contractors. It has played a substantial role in the successful boost to employment in Australia since the Hawke Government came to office.

The same principle is being applied to the purchase of defence equipment. No longer do we have the policies of the Opposition-just to buy off the shelf from an ally to whom we feel beholden. This Government is insisting that if countries around the world want to sell to Australia they can come out here and transfer the technology and show our industry how to compete at world standards. The Government's offsets policies and the transfer of technology being insisted upon as part of this program are in my view a very beneficial use of government capital works expenditure, and provide a much needed boost to our economy. I have in my electorate, in the city of Castlemaine, a factory which employs 350 people. That factory-Thompsons- Byron, Jackson-was a key supplier to the Australian Government during World War II. Following World War II that factory has consistently missed out on government contracts and has run down its heavy engineering capacity. Now I am hopeful that in the lead-up to the new submarine contracts Thompsons in Castlemaine may be a beneficiary of the program. I am even more hopeful for the factory, given the announcement in the past few weeks by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, that we have completed a purchasing agreement with the States which will mean a genuine preference for Australian industry in the purchasing of government materials at both the State and Federal level. I commend the Minister for being able to put that package together. It has taken far too long to come about, and in fact the old arrangement, given the mess it was in, should never have been foisted upon this Government.

I also note in the Bills an allocation of funds to make possible the Government's policy to provide a further 20,000 child care places. There is no dispute, certainly on this side of the House, that the Government has a leading role to play in assisting women to make their way back into the work force, providing them in particular with quality child care to assist both the short term and long term needs of the families of Australia. I know that our commitment to providing an additional 20,000 child care places is welcomed out in the community and I am glad to see this provision in this Bill.

It is appropriate in this debate to recapitulate some of the achievements of this Government in its short period in office-short when one considers the long period of government since World War II of those on the other side of the House. They had the opportunity to establish in Australia a soundly based, soundly structured economy. What has happened to the economy? The short period of three years since March 1983 has produced a remarkable turnaround. Over half a million new jobs have been created in Australia. As of this week, the figure is 620,000 new jobs. Unemployment has been reduced substantially since this Government came to office. The deficit-the figure everybody seems to focus on around Budget time-has been reduced from a projected $9.6 billion when we took office to $4.9 billion in the current Budget Estimates. There have been record business profits of $6.5 billion. There has been a substantial cut in inflation from 12.3 to 8.2 per cent. There has been a substantial slow-down in the rate of increase of farm costs-as was announced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) today in a ministerial statement on rural Australia-to a projected 3 per cent in the year to come. That is a fantastic achievement and the Government is not embarrassed in claiming it.

Australia is enjoying a period of strong and sound economic growth under sound economic management. It has taken hard work and commitment on the part of members and supporters of the Government to bring this about. Other speakers in the debate have mentioned the prices and incomes accord. The Government can but acknowledge the role of the trade union movement in agreeing to the prices and incomes package-the most successful social package of its kind in the Western world since the Second World War. In that regard one can honestly say that Australian trade unionists have been prepared to forgo short term wage advantage to assist the Government in sound economic restructuring and to help those less fortunate to make their way back into the work force. That should not be forgotten.

I wish to mention briefly the launching in the last two to three weeks of the Government's national drug offensive. I know that on the weekend many homes, particularly in metropolitan areas, received the new booklet for families. As a parent of teenage children, I know that the problem of communicating with teenagers and understanding how one talks about these issues is soundly addressed in this publication. I commend all those who have been responsible for its preparation, and call on everyone in the community, particularly those parents throughout the country who are worried about the way in which to approach this problem, to support the Government in this initiative and to read the publication closely. It is one of the best publications I have seen from government in many years.

Because I represent an electorate with a significant rural component, and along with a substantial number of my colleagues I am a member of the Prime Minister's country task force, I want to make brief mention of the ministerial statement made today by the Minister for Primary Industry. I support the view that this is an historic statement, because it is the first time that any government has made such a broad and wide-ranging contribution to rural Australia. The Government recognises that rural Australia is an integral part of our history, culture and environment. As the Minister said, no government can afford to ignore the contribution made by the rural community, and certainly this Government does not ignore it. It is also acknowledged by the Government that short term band-aid measures are not the answer and the Government will not adopt such an approach. The Government recognises that the only policies that will work are those that contribute to the long term health of the agricultural sector.

I draw attention to one aspect of the Minister's statement. The Minister highlighted the fact that the community employment program, which has made an incredible contribution to job creation, has been specifically directed to assist country Australia. I note that some 43,000 jobs have been created in rural and country Australia under that program. It has been highly successful in my electorate and I am proud to be associated with it. I conclude by quoting part of the Minister's statement:

No government has ever presented such a comprehensive, wide-ranging review from the standpoint of the rural or any other sector, and no government has given more recognition of the needs of all residents of rural and provincial Australia. Those who are interested in policies for the long term development of all Australians will find much to support in this statement, much to support in our overall and economic and social strategies, and much to be thankful for in the record of this Government.
I could not agree more, and I take this opportunity to support the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). These Bills do two things. They increase the appropriations for the Government and provide some offset savings, but the net effect of these measures is to increase expenditure financed from annual appropriations by some $678,300,000. These Bills increase government expenditure at a time when restraint is the order of the day. Perhaps there is no better person to tell us that restraint is the order of the day than the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating), who was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 March this year as issuing a blunt warning to his Cabinet colleagues the day before that the economy would run into serious problems unless the Government cut expenditure by about $1.4 billion in the 1986-87 financial year. In fact, these Bills represent a continuation of the high spending and high taxing program of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This process began in 1983-84 when outlays were increased to some $56.5 billion and tax receipts to some $44.5 billion, with a Budget deficit of nearly $8 billion, the highest Budget deficit this country has ever run. In the 1985-86 financial year outlays have risen to some $69 billion, tax receipts to nearly $59 billion, and we are still running a Budget deficit of nearly $5 billion. This Government has an extremely unfavourable record when compared with the Liberal-National Party Government. This increase in government expenditure has implications, as a number of other speakers have suggested, for the total government debt in Australia, which is about $100 billion today, and the increasing high overseas debt, which is approaching $70 billion. These twin deficits, the Budget deficit and the current account deficit, ensure that our indebtedness will continue to grow for some years to come. The accumulation of debt is an example of a nation taking the easy option and deferring the problem until tomorrow, for those who follow, our children and grandchildren. We all know that debt can be productive when used to build facilities which provide a future stream of cash flows sufficient to service and repay the debt and to give an adequate return to the risk taker. But debt that is used for current consumption is a different animal. I shall return to that point in a moment.

These Bills have implications for at least four inter-related policy areas-monetary policy, fiscal policy, taxation policy and investment policy. In the monetary and fiscal policy areas, the lack of fiscal restraint implies a continued high demand for government borrowings. In our current climate this implies higher interest rates than would otherwise be attained under a different fiscal and monetary policy. Every Australian who owns a home or is buying a car, refrigerator or television set or trying to run a small business or farm knows all about interest rates. All Australians know that when the coalition left office at the end of February 1983 trading bank interest rates were 14 per cent per annum and falling. The building society rates were 14.5 per cent per annum and falling and savings bank interest rates were 12.5 per cent per annum and falling. In fact, they had been falling for six to 12 months before the coalition left office.

What have we today? We have the highest nominal interest rates since 1902; we have the highest real interest rates since the Depression years of the 1930s; we have double digit real interest rates for the first time since 1933; we have the highest nominal interest rates in the Western world, and these compare very un- favourably with our major trading partners. By March of this year-the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) knows this-bank interest rates were 19 per cent, building society interest rates were 15.5 per cent and savings bank interest rates had jumped to 15.5 per cent. So much for the Government's fiscal and monetary policy.

Let us turn to taxation and investment policy. High outlays and high government expenditures imply simply higher taxation than there need be. Higher taxation also implies that there are less incentives for business and for individuals. I would like to address very briefly the issues of business investment and taxation. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd business indicators for September 1985 indicate the following investment ratios as a percentage of gross domestic product for Australia. In the late 1960s and early 1970s each year Australians invested something like 20 or 21 per cent of our gross domestic product in the future of Australia. In 1983-84 and 1984-85 this had fallen to about 17.5 per cent of gross domestic product. Not only has total investment fallen, but the important component of private investment has also fallen. Over a long time, right up until the 1980s, when the coalition was in office it averaged about 12.5 to 13 per cent. It has now fallen to about 8.5 or 9 per cent. At the same time consumption, which I mentioned earlier, has risen from 73 per cent to 78 per cent. Quite frankly, this Government is encouraging less business investment and greater consumption than was encouraged under the previous Liberal-led Government. These figures demonstrate that business investment is falling.

I would like to turn now to the subject of the taxation policy which is destroying incentives for future investment. As honourable members would know, investment occurs only when after-tax returns on investment are sufficient to cover the risk; in other words, the person investing the money has to get an adequate return to service the debt, to repay the debt and to earn sufficient to make the risk worth while. This Government, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), have been systematically raising taxation in Australia. I have already referred to the higher taxation of this Government compared with that of the previous Government, but let me remind honourable members of some of the things that this Government has done over the past three years to increase the impact of taxation on all Australians. The alternative home loan interest rebate scheme, which applied to interest in excess of 10 per cent per annum on the first $60,000 of a loan on a sole or principal residence, has been terminated by this Government. If that scheme had continued it would have ameliorated some of the problems that home owners are facing today.

The rebate available to individual taxpayers on up to $1,000 of dividend income included in income tax was abolished by this Government. The rebate for basic health insurance contributions was terminated by this Government. The home insulation deduction was withdrawn by this Treasurer and this Prime Minister. The threshold for the application of the special rates of tax on the unearned income of unmarried minors was reduced from $1,040 per annum to $416 per annum by this Government, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. The tax exemption for pay and allowances of part time members of the Defence Force Reserve was partially abolished. We are told that fringe benefits are to be taxed at the employer level by this Government. Entertainment deductions have been disallowed by this Government. Living away from home allowances have been tightened. The provision for negative gearing arrangements is to be removed by the Treasurer. The wholesale tax regime was supposedly rationalised, but it in fact resulted in an increase in the taxes being collected by this Government and the Treasurer. We are told that there is to be an increase in company tax from 46 per cent to 49 per cent.

Finally, despite the proposed tax rate reductions in personal marginal tax rates, fiscal drag has already robbed the average Australian family of any advantage of this reduction. The other changes that I have mentioned have been actually increasing the average tax paid by the Australian family. I have spoken of an incorrect monetary and fiscal policy. I have outlined the lack of incentive for business investment. I have spoken about the lack of incentive for families. I am afraid that this situation is well summarised-and perhaps the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), who is sitting at the table and who I know is a student of history, might recall this-by the comments of the distinguished historian Sir Arthur Bryant. I think that his thoughts on the decline of the Roman Empire are very applicable to Australia today. He said:

Rome had grown out of greatness of individual character. It became a community in which individual character counted for nothing compared with an abstraction which proved, in the hour of testing, capable of nothing. By sacrificing the individual to the state the rulers of the Roman world undermined the real virtues which sustained it. They turned active and self-respecting citizens into inert and selfish ones. They discouraged the capitalist from thrift and foresight, the trader from enterprise, the craftsman from his hereditary skill, the husbandman from pride in the soil, the mother from maternity, and the soldier from courage and self-sacrifice. They made the moral shell which protected society so soft that it could protect it no longer. A creeping inertia paralysed everyone and everything.

I ask honourable members, people who are listening and even people who might read the Hansard record of this debate, to reflect upon those words and to decide whether or not it reflects the current malaise in Australia that this Government has helped to create.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to raise particularly an issue which affects the State of Queensland and one which I feel will interest all members of the House of Representatives. I want to refer to a project that has been described as the greatest agricultural venture that this nation has ever seen. I refer to the jojoba plantations that have been established in central Queensland in the township of Raglan. Many years ago, when I was a State member of parliament, the then Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, Mike Ahern, raised serious questions about this project and I supported him to the hilt when he did so. Mike, who is a very dedicated member of parliament with a degree in agricultural science, questioned Mr Miller about the potential that was presented in all sorts of documents in relation to this jojoba plantation. He warned people and stressed that they ought to be very careful, because the projections that those behind this project were putting forward, as he said, simply had little validity.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Neil Turner, the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries who followed Mr Ahern-I regret that he has seen fit to retire-also expressed great concern about this project, and for good reason. Recently I had the unfortunate experience of meeting with one of the ex-employees of the jojoba plantation. He brought with him documents that were of grave concern to me. I believe it is important that I raise these matters in this chamber in the hope that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) will be able to act, that the Corporate Affairs Commission in Queensland will act and that together, using the justice systems that prevail, we may be able to bring those who are behind this rort and this fraud to justice. Raglan has something like 1,400 acres; it involves 3,000 investors, and those investors have paid between $10,000 and $12,000 per acre.

The idea is a good one in many ways. It was simply a matter of setting up plantations. The idea was to encourage people to buy an acre, or units thereof, in this plantation. Some people might buy 10 units or 10 acres and for that they could pay $100,000, the concept being, as the prospectus I have shows, that after about five years, when the jojoba plants would bear, they would make considerable profits and these plants would go on bearing for many years. I bring to the attention of honourable members a prospectus that I have. At the time the Chairman of Jojoba Management Limited was Sir Rupert James Hamer, KCMG, LLD, ED. His message as the Chairman stressed the potential of this important new industry for Australia. Pages 19, 20 and 21 of the prospectus set out the sorts of concepts that are involved in developing, for instance, a 2,800 unit or 700 acre plantation and the benefits to be derived from that project.

One looks also at the types of people who were behind Jojoba Management Limited and one finds some very important people. We find Sir Wallace Rae who was previously a Minister in the Queensland State Parliament, a man who also went to London as Queensland's Agent-General, a man very well known and highly respected. So Jojoba Management Limited put around it some very competent people. It also selected the best agronomists that it could find. Again, this gave it some status and credibility. It set out some years ago-approximately five years ago-to sell these plantations, but it would seem that, right from the outset, it was determined to rip off the investors and it has done that in a very smart way. Plantation 1, which is portions 19, 23, 33 and 104 of the parish of Langmore, a plantation that involves 412.25 acres, was sold to the investors but only 230.8 acres were developed and planted. There was a shortfall of 180 acres. But this company still sold these acres, telling the people that the cost of maintaining an acre for five years-that is to plant and develop-was about $6,000. It was selling these, on average over the five-year period, for between $10,000 and $12,000. So honourable members can see the profits involved. In fact it is believed that the total investment for the 1,400 acres amounted to around $14m. Yet today the phone bills are not being paid and those who are still left working for this company are struggling to get their wages.

The various plantations, be they plantations 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6, are no longer being maintained. The irrigation schemes that were promised did not come about. Instead, we have a fiasco, with major shortfalls-shortfalls, I might point out, that have been admitted by the management. I refer to a document which is a copy of the minutes of the meeting of the Jojoba board of management dated Wednesday, 5 February 1986. Present at that meeting were F. H. Mader, Managing Director; M. Mader, a Director; J. Willcox, plantation manager, and K. Gattenhof, S. Bell and L. Henderson who represented administration. Business item No. 3, which is headed `Acreage shortfall sold in plantations 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5', states:

The Managing Director, Fred Mader, agreed to make up the shortfall of approximately 280 acres in Plantations 1 to 5 by purchasing equivalent acreage, planting and maintaining same at the `Aintree' Plantation as soon as he has funds available from the sale of his land.

The significance of this is that that shortfall is worth something like $2m. Moreover, it has been pointed out to me that the honourable gentleman does not hold title to the land that he intended to sell. If we look at the actual figures we find that it is not just a matter of a shortfall of 280 acres, as has been suggested in the minutes. In fact it is more like a shortfall of somewhere around 800 acres. When we multiply that figure by about $10,000 per acre, we start to appreciate that we are talking about the greatest rip-off in Australian agricultural history-a rip-off of about $8m. I am told that Mr Mader drives the most exotic cars that one can think of. For instance, he has a Rolls Royce, he has Volvos and he has a fleet of 8 or 9 cars. I am told that he has a magnificent home on the Gold Coast-but the wages are not being paid, the phone bills are not being paid and the investors will not be paid. We find that, instead of people counting on a return after four or five years-honourable members can check that through in the information that has been provided, which I will be willing to table-most of the promises have never been met.

Let us look, for instance, at plantation 1. We find that 180 acres have not even been planted. If we go back and look at other plantations, we find that the same is true everywhere. Plantation 2 was sold around 1981. It was not even planted until 1985, and the plants are only 12 months old. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will appreciate, coming from central Queensland, that the jojoba plant needs something like four to five years to bear. The investors were supposed to get a return next year and that certainly will not take place. Plantation No. 2 was sold as 400 acres and as an irrigation plantation. Yet an investigation that has been carried out shows that only 9 acres have trickle irrigation. Surely this must be misrepresentation at the highest level. It must be fraud. Plantation No. 3, which consists of 100.25 acres, again was sold in 1980-81. It was pointed out that it was very important to have irrigation, that irrigation was necessary to establish that plantation. To date, five years later, there is no irrigation system. What we have is 80 acres that were seeded just before Christmas. It has been pointed out in information provided to me that Mr Mader was concerned that the Corporate Affairs Commission in Queensland may be on to him so he ought to start doing something with the land and, therefore, he seeded 80 acres, knowing full well that it would not work. At this point, there is still a nil growth. The acreage involved was sold for between $8,000 and $10,000 an acre. We are talking again of $1m-another rip-off.

Plantation No. 4 consists of 238 acres, of which 225 acres were developed but only 80 acres were planted. Quite obviously one does not get any jojoba plants bearing unless one plants them. Two years ago 80 acres were planted and there has been no return to date. On plantation No. 5, 58 acres were sold and nothing was planted. On plantation No. 6, lots 1 and 2 of portion 127 were sold without a prospectus. Surely that is not condoned by any system of justice or corporate structure in any State. It was sold without a prospectus by a company known as East West Securities. The sales manager is a man called Peter Webb. No wonder he was willing to sell it because he was receiving a retainer of $3,000 per week plus a commission. This acreage was sold at $15,000 an acre and the company sold 153 acres, which amounts to around $2m. Mr Deputy Speaker, you see that we have here a rort of mighty proportions and I believe that it deserves a thorough investigation at the highest possible level.

The State Ministers in Queensland whom I have mentioned-the present Minister for Primary Industries and a former Minister for Primary Industries-warned people about it. I ask at this point why the Queensland Government and the Minister for Justice have not acted on this matter, because there have been plenty of warnings. It would seem that the Corporate Affairs Commission was aware that something was going on, but again nothing was done. I see the situation being now that 3,000 Australian investors are going to lose anything between $14m and $15m. What is worse is that a scheme that could have been so important to the future economic growth of central Queensland will have its reputation totally ruined. One has only to read the prospectus and material that has been supplied by the Department of Primary Industries to realise that jojoba plantations have a great potential to provide a secondary income for many on the land. But there can be no income when the crops are not planted, when the irrigation schemes are not implemented, when there is no maintenance, or when those who are to carry out the work are not paid and resign. That is the case. If one looks through the correspondence one can see that many points are made. Unfortunately, I do not have time to raise all these matters and to bring them to the attention of honourable members.

The minutes, the letter from Mr Hamer and the correspondence that has been delivered to me that is of a personal nature, back in August 1985, in October 1985, in the early part of January 1986, all warned of the seriousness of the situation, but nothing was done. Instead, those involved continued to represent this as a going project. Just before Christmas they even made out that they had received about a tonne of the jojoba bean, while in actual fact it was about 100 kilograms. They put out that information because they wanted people to believe that the crops were bearing and to ensure that there were no troubles. I believe that we need to have a thorough investigation, and I call for that. I will make all the information that I have here available to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). As I have said, I am prepared to meet with Mr Harper, the Attorney-General in Queensland, in the hope that something can be done. I believe that right now the money that Mader and his cohorts have ought to be frozen, because I suspect that he will disappear very, very quickly now that this whole rort has been exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly in the adjournment debate because I am reminded that it was one week ago tonight that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) arranged a bipartisan trip to Mount Stromlo to observe what will be for all of us a once in a lifetime experience, namely, an opportunity to see at first hand Halley's comet. So it was that the majority of members of this House journeyed by bus to Mount Stromlo and were able to observe either by binoculars or through the quite remarkable viewing facilities provided at Mount Stromlo something of the magic and the wonder of Halley's comet. Those people who were not able to view the comet as adequately as they had hoped, either through binoculars or the telescope, were able through the miracles of modern science to see the comet on the television monitors. I rise to address the House in this manner because this is a once in a lifetime occurrence, as the comet returns only every 76 years. What is generally not appreciated is that, in fact, the oldest astronomical society in Australia is the Astronomical Society of South Australia, which was formed in 1892 and which currently has a membership of 380 people.
—All in Wakefield.

—I shall take up the interjection, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think it is appropriate that I rise here tonight and make this point, because the Astronomical Society of South Australia has constructed in the electorate of Wakefield, at a small place called Stockport, 80 kilometres north of Adelaide, the new viewing facility known as the Stockport observatory. The Astronomical Society of South Australia faced the same dilemma as Canberrans in that it found that the viewing platform the Society once had in the grounds of the Marion High School became increasingly ineffective as a viewing area because of the increasing light pollution in the city of Adelaide. So the Astronomical Society thought it would be appropriate in South Australia's jubilee 150 year to construct a new viewing platform and telescope at the town of Stockport. Stockport was chosen not only because it was in the electorate of Wakefield-although I have no doubt that that was something of a determining factor-but also because it is both convenient to Adelaide and far enough to the north of the city to be protected from light pollution. I pay a tribute to the Astronomical Society not only for the site it chose for the new observatory but also for the foresight it showed in deciding to coincide the opportunity to view Halley's comet with the Jubilee 150 celebrations that have been so much a part of South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: At a cost of $50,000 the Astronomical Society of South Australia has constructed at Stockport an entirely new observatory, and I pay a tribute to South Australia's Jubilee 150 Board, which made available a $28,000 grant. I am sure the House would agree that it is very appropriate that the Jubilee 150 year coincided with the arrival of Halley's comet. The generosity of the Jubilee 150 Board in making this $28,000 grant available has made it possible for the Astronomical Society to construct this observatory at Stockport. However, we should not underrate what members of the Astronomical Society of South Australia have done themselves, in finding from Society funds $17,000, and managing to raise from Astronomical Society members' loans an additional sum of $5,000 so that the new observatory could be completed. It was opened one month ago by the Deputy Premier of South Australia, Dr Don Hopgood.

I make the point, too, that a 20-inch Jubilee telescope has been installed at this new Stockport observatory. Further, over the current two-week period, which was expected to be the best time to see Halley's comet, 1,600 people have booked to visit the Stockport observatory to view Halley's comet. I think that the observatory is a tribute to the foresight of the people of the Astronomical Society of South Australia and the Jubilee 150 Board. I pay a tribute to them tonight and point out how pleased I was both to attend the opening of the observatory and to congratulate them for what they had done for the people of South Australia and the astronomical societies of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight on an issue to which I feel all parliamentarians should pay heed, and that is the issue of Aboriginal health in this country. I would also like to pay a tribute to the Aboriginal health services, which are mainly managed and controlled by Aboriginals themselves, for the part that they are playing to overcome the problems of ill health amongst Aboriginals in the community. I wish to refer to an article in the Readers' Digest of April 1986 written by a very well known Aboriginal, Neville Bonner, who of course was a Liberal senator in the other place until a few years ago. Neville Bonner points out that there is a need for more Aboriginal health services in this country today. Innumerable surveys have shown that the state of Aboriginal health is a national disgrace. The following facts should be considered. Aboriginal babies are almost three times as likely as as white babies to die at birth. One study shows that in Western Australia Aboriginal children are four times as likely as white children to need hospitalisation, and for twice as long. In New South Wales life expectancy among Aboriginals in country areas is only 48 to 49 years for men and 55 to 57 years for women, compared with the non-Aboriginal expectancy of 71 years for men and 78 years for women. The death rate among Aboriginals aged 35 to 39 years is 14 time higher than average. One in five males who reach the age of 20 years will be dead before his fortieth birthday.

SPEECH.PARA: In remote desert communities-I have visited a number of those in recent years-three children out of every four will contract the potentially blinding disease, trachoma. This slow scarring disease had been virtually eliminated as a cause of blindness in white people. Yet 1,450 of Australia's 160,000 Aboriginals are blind because of trachoma and other causes. Experts say that proper medical attention could be prevented some 80 per cent of the cases.

Diabetes strikes 3.4 per cent of the total population but up to 19 per cent of Aboriginals. Gastroenteritis, inflammation of the stomach and intestines, is caused by food poisoning, parasites, allergies, viruses or infections, and usually produces diarrhoea, abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting. Among Western Australian infants, Aboriginals are 11 times more likely than whites to need hospitalisation for gastroenteritis. Sometimes the disease is a killer.

Leprosy, which many non-Aboriginals feel is a disease of the past, continues to ravage. Of some 230 cases that were reported and notified in Australia between 1980 and 1984, more than one-third were Aboriginals. Hearing loss due to middle ear infection is 200 times greater in Aboriginals than among white people. Dental hygiene is generally poor. As Mr Neville Bonner states, justifiable panic and outcry would sweep across Australia if the same level of sickness affecting his people were being suffered by whites. Yet some non-Aboriginals challenge the need for a separate black-controlled medical service. Is not the plight of the Aboriginals, those people ask, caused largely by their reckless refusal to utilise mainstream facilities? Should Australia, they say, foster this form of medical apartheid? Such questions reveal an ignorance of the problem and a failure to understand the anxieties of Aboriginal people about the circumstances under which they live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The family structure as we know it is at risk. One of the causes is a lack of family counselling to try to keep families together. Much more money is currently being spent on Family Court of Australia matters which are the last step in family breakdown. I submit that more funds need to be made available for family counselling. In my electorate of Groom, marriage counsellors have joined together in a call for more government help to save marriages. They cite the price of family breakdown costing the nation $1,500m in 1985. This costing will increase to about $3 billion this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party of Australia and I believe that the family is paramount if our society is to prosper and to go forward. The amount of government resources spent on supporting parent and deserted wives benefits is staggering. It has been estimated by the Queensland Marriage Guidance Council that, if marriage counselling organisations were effective in diverting a mere 3 per cent of the couples who use their services away from supporting parent benefits, the total expense of the Government's investment in marriage counselling would be saved. This is a mere $4m.

A significant percentage of marriage conflict resulting in divorce can be resolved through skilled intervention counselling and marriage education programs. In a society where a degree is practically needed to stand any real chance of getting a job, it is slightly unreal to expect young people to enter a marriage without any formal education about the impact it will have on their future and that of their children. However, because of the limited resources available, many couples are unable to be helped. Queensland is a huge State, with many far-flung cities and towns. Yet throughout the State there are only 13 marriage guidance agencies. These 13 offices are stretched to the limit. Many requests for help from both serviced and unserviced areas have had to be turned down because of the lack of or limited resources available.

There is an acute shortage of counsellors in both Townsville and Brisbane, which has resulted in a corresponding fall in interviews conducted, while in areas such as Mount Isa, Mackay, Ipswich, Cairns, Gladstone and Toowoomba, where offices are fully staffed, there has been a dramatic growth in use of the service. Reports indicate that over three-quarters of those who attend counselling say that the counselling was helpful. We need more if the country is to shed some of its social security costs for more productive revenue raising activities. Needless to say, the cost of marriage breakdown is felt most acutely by the children, the young innocents who lives are altered dramatically by the departure of a mother or father. Their suffering cannot be measured in dollars and cents. However, the impact is most profound, not only on the emotional level but also economically.

It has been estimated that about 20 per cent of Australian children are living below the poverty line, and unfortunately the percentage is rising. The pain and trauma caused by marital and family breakdown can have life-long consequences for the children involved. Who amongst us can tolerate any child spending its life in poverty and insecurity unnecessarily? Help is readily available to separating couples in the form of pensions, legal aid, Family Court divorce counselling, subsidised child care, and so on. But little interest has been shown in supporting marriage counselling.

The current trends indicate that between 30 and 40 per cent of Australian marriages will end in divorce. About 50,000 children will be affected. These are the innocent victims. There is a growing opinion that separation is far from desirable when children are involved. Counsellors are constantly seeing the grief and suffering of separation, the trauma associated with access and custody and later the entanglements of step-families. Yet in the present atmosphere the unhappy wife or husband will more than likely seek legal advice rather than make contact with a marriage counsellor.

Experience has proven that much of the marriage conflict can be resolved through skilled intervention counselling and that many divorces are unnecessary and preventable. It is not unreasonable to assert that if more community resources were made available in this area beneficial effects on the quality of life in Australia would result. It is the pay as you earn employees who are contributing the most to welfare funding. Their middle class values and family unit lifestyles cost them approximately $500 a year for each welfare recipient. About 83,000 of the recipients are deserted wives, but 43,000 are unmarried mothers drawing a supporting parent pension. There are also 9,000 men.

In a recently leaked memo to Cabinet, Treasurer Paul Keating spoke of the nation's finances being in a tailspin primarily caused by welfare payments. Something needs to be done. The first logical step is to educate young people about the seriousness of marriage before they make the commitment and then afterwards to help couples who are having difficulties to sort through their problems and resolve them rather than walk away from them.

I call upon the Government to take a closer look at its priorities. A conscious effort must be made to rearrange funding so that more resources are made available for counselling couples in conflict. A tripling of funding to marriage guidance councils will have a dual purpose of keeping families together and decreasing our social security payouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I was privileged to travel with the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to the Ranger uranium mine in the Northern Territory. The primary aim of the Committee's visit was to investigate adverse Press reports relating to accidental spillage at the Ranger mine. When one arrives there, the first thing that one notices when one goes in the gate of the Ranger uranium mine is the large sign which shows the safety record of the mine for the previous month. We were there in February and I think there were 29 accidents in February; that is one for every day.

SPEECH.PARA: The safety record of this mine is abysmal. Recently 250 production workers at Ranger went on strike because a discharge of sulphur dioxide spread throughout the plant, or part of the plant, which made a number of workers ill. Recently there was also a fire in a rod mill which crushes uranium ore. There have been reports of leakages and various accidents occuring at this mine. I believe that some of the causes of the accidents are the harsh conditions under which the workers have to work but one of the main causes is management of the mine. The management does not act as it should in a heavy industry.

When I arrived there one of the first things I noticed was a huge pile of sulphur. It is a bright yellow and many people think that it is yellowcake. It is not; it is sulphur. It is in a large concrete basin and is spread throughout the plant just through bad work practices. Tractors go into it and one can see it spread over the surrounding ground by the wheels of the tractors-Paper bags of chemicals had been left out in the open. The paper had been washed off by the rain and the chemicals were leaking on to the ground.

Large plastic containers of a highly corrosive acid called ferric chloride, which was used in a water treatment plant which is not being used and had not been used for some time were in the open. After the heavy rain piles of mud had built up against the plastic drums of ferric chloride. Forty-four gallon drums had been rusted through. Radioactive tailings were over the top of the drain which ran on to the surrounding landscape.

There is a new method of processing the tailings there. An effort is being made to get away from covering them with three or four feet of water. The tailings were in an open dam-like situation. This was very good because the tailings did not take up such a large area. If one looked at the slurry one could see that birds and animals had walked across it. It is highly radioactive. The animals then proceeded into the bush. I have photographs of this if anyone is concerned and wants to look at them.

Plastic pipes, which transferred the radioactive tailings to this dam which was being tested as a new method of containing the tailings, were held in place by fencing wire and fence posts. This is not proper engineering practice. It is a disgrace to anyone who calls himself an engineer. The main tailings pipe which transfers the tailings to the dam had burst some weeks before we got there. Part of the pipe that had burst and was worn out had been put back into the pipeline. One does not do these sorts of things if one is transporting highly radioactive material to another site.

The unions there were concerned. They claimed that some workers had died through something to do with the plant. The unions want a proper computer register of the people who work there. They want to be able to trace them all through their life-not just for the next six or 12 months-so that in years to come they will know who worked there and who worked in what particular area so that if a worker does get any sort of cancer or disease he can be traced quite easily. This company must improve its management. As I have said before, it is not good for an industry like this to be spoilt by bad engineering practices.
