SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the privileged position of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. The Corporation is effectively an arm of government. It reports to the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) and it is in the market-place competing with private sector companies. I should make it clear from the outset that the private sector relishes competition. Competition is the life- blood of the private enterprise system. However, that competition should be seen to be fair-scrupulously fair! Unfair competition from a government agency, an agency spawned by government itself, is unacceptable. Governments make the rules and, quite properly, act as umpires too. However, it is obviously not appropriate for the Government to make the rules, act as an umpire and also enter the field as a player. When the Government blows the whistle, one can be sure it is not to give the private enterprise competition a free kick!

SPEECH.PARA: That, Mr Deputy Speaker, is exactly what happens in the case of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. In the last annual report, that for the year ended 30 June 1985, it was readily acknowledged that it `operates as a business undertaking in competition with other insurers'. Elsewhere in the report it is stated that the Corporation is self-financing, services capital and is liable for taxes levied by the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories. I suggest that these statements are intended to deceive, to give the Corporation a facade or respectability, to imply that the Corporation competes fairly with its private enterprise competitors when the truth is otherwise.

Therefore let me dispel any thoughts this House may have about fair competition as practised by the Corporation. Firstly, in an industry where security is paramount, the Corporation has had bestowed upon it a government guarantee. Secondly, the Corporation has all the benefits associated with government ownership conferred upon it. The Corporation has an arrangement whereby the Commonwealth Government act as reinsurer for certain insurance covers required by the Corporation, albeit for a fee. Honourable members should also not be surprised to learn that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is not required to comply with the requirements of the Insurance Act 1973-its competitors are. That gives the Corporation a number of advantages which I shall not particularise here. Suffice it to say that if the Corporation were required to comply with the Insurance Act the Commonwealth Government would have to inject $20m to $25m of extra capital.

It should be noted that the Review of the Australian Financial System recommended in its final report that the Corporation should pay an appropriate fee to offset the competitive advantage associated with its government ownership and guarantee. That recommendation has not been followed.

There are other advantages inherent in the arrangements covering the operations of the Corporation-benefits, privileges and subsidies. The full range and depth of those various hidden subsidies will be determined only when the operations of the Corporation are subjected to objective scrutiny by a commercial auditing and costing firm from the private sector-an organisation which is sensitive about the realities of business life, which can identify and quantify the full cost to taxpayers of the Corporation's generous superannuation scheme, which can establish the commercial worth of the services the Corporation draws on from a number of government agencies ranging from the Australian Government Actuary to the Auditor-General's Office.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established in 1965 to meet what was then seen as a need to create a mortgage insurance market in Australia. A substantial market in mortgage insurance has since been developed. The Corporation has served its purpose as an arm of the government and it should now be sold, as proposed by the Fraser Government. The sale of the Corporation to the private sector would ensure that all companies competed on equal terms and that taxpayers were not compelled to provide hidden subsidies to a government agency. All Australians would benefit from the proceeds of the sale; Australians would have a stake in the private sector purchaser for all of us are shareholders in private enterprise. We provide no capital yet collectively share through taxation receipts a dividend equivalent to 46c in the dollar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In late February and early March the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and I were afforded the opportunity to visit Kampuchea as guests of World Vision. It was indeed a unique opportunity and I would like to thank Mr Roger Walker and his organisation for the invitation. It gave us the opportunity to look first hand at some of the non-government organisations in that country and the work that they were doing. Kampuchea flashed across our television screens during the 1970s as the horrors of the Vietnam War spilled across the borders, when bombings occurred and the infamous Pol Pot and his regime cut a swath through that country. Of course all of us were aware of the invaluable role of emergency assistance to overcome the famine and trauma of Pol Pot in 1979 and 1980. It was appropriate that we should look at the non-government organisations and whether or not they were fulfilling the needs and priorities of Kampuchea. It is a pleasure to report that the clear impression we received was that Australia's contribution was not only effective but also very much valued by that country.

SPEECH.PARA: The precarious state of Kampuchea is a result of a tense political situation which is destabilised by the existence of Vietnamese occupying forces, a Western blockade and active Khmer Rouge guerrilla insurgency. Kampuchean society is characterised by poverty, disease, malnutrition and reliance on tenuous subsistence agricultural production. Rightly, I believe, the first priority of the country is food production. This rich country, which was a net exporter of agricultural products in the past, is suffering because of population losses, massive social dislocations caused by war and Pol Pot, and the present insecure situation. All of these factors are diminishing and frustrating efforts in the area. Simple techniques of irrigation and hydrology seem to be beyond the Kampucheans in many areas and adequate fertilisers and pesticides are lacking. It was heartening to see the work of the Australian Freedom from Hunger group in the Kandal province where many of its irrigation projects are providing the capability for arid land to be made fertile and for two crops to be grown where only one was previously possible.

Another of the priorities of Kampuchea is the provision of adequate health care. On visiting hospitals, medical schools and district health centres, the diabolical legacy of Pol Pot became only too clear. Hundreds of doctors, pharmacists, dentists, students and medical facilities were destroyed during the time of Pol Pot. The training and equipment that is now available to the Kampucheans is rudimentary, to say the least, yet it is a credit to their ingenuity that Kampuchea is able to produce competent medical graduates and people in paramedical fields. Again, the non-government organisations are doing very important work. The best patronised and clearly the finest facilities for paediatric hospitals in Pnom Penh are those provided by World Vision, whose hospital does an overwhelmingly good job in providing assistance to large numbers of children and in educating their parents so as to stop the needless suffering that can be avoided by the provision of the most basic facilities. The work of the Australians in World Vision is outstanding.

The legacy of Pol Pot in the area of education remains. While the Government is endeavouring to make progress in that area, it was disappointing to see that the Western blockade and the isolation the country is suffering have meant that the English language is not being taught sufficiently. Again, we found that a project initiated by the Australian Quakers was beginning to have an effect in this area and that English language teaching was taking increasing hold. It would be absurd to suggest that in one week one can become an expert, but we were afforded the opportunity of speaking with large numbers of workers from international agencies from all over the world. We had the opportunity to meet a number of government officials. We saw as much as we possibly could of the country under the security arrangements that were made. It was impossible for us to investigate human rights issues as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) was only too keen to do. The clear impression with which we came away from the country was that the country is struggling to get back on its feet against difficulties that are unimaginable for us in Australia. Although we may not be ideologically aligned with the Kampuchean Government, it seemed to have its priorities right in the areas of food production, education and health.

The future for a political solution in the country seems bleak as long as the West, the Soviets and the Chinese continue to play power politics and the Khmer people remain pawns in the game. The experience for me was very sobering in that it put the problems we have in Australia in perspective. We should all count our blessings in this country for we are, indeed, very fortunate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House to yet another of the fallacies perpetrated by the Hawke Government in its `attempts' to help the rural sector out of the dire straits it finds itself in today-the great farce of the petrol price reduction. Speaking of great farces, I do not think many of us in the chamber have witnessed any farce greater than that which the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) made us witness this afternoon in his expulsion of what can be described only as hot air. He will have to go down in the history of the Federal Parliament as being the only deaf and blind Primary Industry Minister we have ever had, because he would have to be deaf and blind to have brought out the sort of rural aid package he brought out this afternoon. He travelled around Australia and listened to farmers right across the country, to the wives of farmers-to the people who live in rural communities. He has completely and utterly ignored the message those people have been crying out with.

SPEECH.PARA: The message those people have been crying out with is that rural Australia wants some assistance in the form of a reduction in interest rates. People have been calling upon the Government to get out of the interest rate market, to stop inflating interest rates. They have been calling upon the Government to allow the full benefits of the world wide reduction in the price of fuel to flow not just to farmers but to every Australian so that our transport costs can come down, therefore reducing production and input costs for farmers and other people right across the country.

These things were completely ignored. We were told that capital gains taxes would be good for us. We were told that fringe benefit taxes would be good for us. We were told that we would still have to undergo the ALP-ACTU 3 per cent superannuation deal, even though it might be delayed for a couple of years. These things are not what rural Australians want. The package that was brought out this afternoon is a farce and will be seen as such in the community. It will live for ever in the mind of the Minister for Primary Industry as one of his great failings in that role.

Tonight I want to speak about a fellow in my electorate called Mr John Mood, who owns a farm in the town of Koorawatha, in the western portion of the electorate of Gilmore, called `Burlington Heights'. Mr Mood contacted me last week to ask what had happened to the 10.6c per litre price reduction he had been led by the Hawke Government to expect after the middle of March for the diesel he uses for off-road purposes. Mr Mood has sent to me his fuel accounts for March and April. On 5 March the price he paid per litre for his diesel was 53.3c. On 2 April he paid 49c per litre for his diesel, a reduction of only 4.3c per litre-some 6c short of the 10.6c per litre he thought, and was informed, he was going to get from the Prime Minister.

Where has the 6c per litre gone? It has been gradually whittled away by many things-by the difference between the prices offered to the company and the price the company then offered to the local dealer, by the additional freight charges that were placed on diesel immediately after the reduction was announced and by factors such as the cost of filling drums, which is $2 per 200-litre drum.

These are the sorts of `additional costs' not taken into account by the Government, which have quickly added up to reduce the reduction of 10.6c per litre to the 4.3c per litre actually received in the hand by Australian farmers-yet another deception by the Government.

These are the facts. This is why the fuel price adjustments, so loudly announced by the Hawke Government, have failed to be fully realised at the farm gate. Despite the scandalous difference between the diesel price reduction offered and that which has actually eventuated, the reduction in the price of super has been much more in line with what was expected. No doubt, city dwellers, who have received the price reduction on their petrol that the Prime Minister told them to expect, share the assumption of the Hawke Government that farmers received a full 10.6c per litre reduction on diesel. We have just seen that such an assumption is grossly inaccurate. How can the Hawke Government pretend to make all important policy decisions resulting in the rural package that is supposed to rescue farmers from their current state of emergency if it is so badly informed and if it is working on assumptions that are clearly incorrect? I suggest that, if the Government were more aware of the huge differences between price reductions offered and those received at the farm gate many of the problems facing rural Australia at the moment could be overcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most people in this Parliament would be aware, because of widespread media comments, of the real crisis that we have in the Mallee area of Victoria, particularly in the central Mallee part of my electorate. SPEECH.PARA: Distance is a massive problem as the 2,000 farms and seven or eight towns about which I am speaking are spread over an area of about 200 kilometres by about 240 kilometres. Much has been done by the local communities. A Mallee crisis committee has been formed which represents all community groups and relevant government departments. Its aim is to co-ordinate the work of self-help groups in local communities, discuss needs and policies for the Mallee with government and seek resources to help alleviate financial and social stress in community members and their families. One of the great problems with declining profits on our farms is that farmers' sons and daughters cannot be retained on the farm. It is warranted to retain people within our community and to maintain the community structures. It is warranted to maintain a cash flow within our community for the survival of businesses within that community. I urgently request the Minister to take the submission into account and see that the criteria for the community employment program is adjusted to meet the needs of the crisis in our rural areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What specific qualifications or contributions has each member of the committee that will be making recommendations on who should receive peace awards made in the field of international relations.
(2) Do recipients of the medals have to comply with criteria such as that applied to International Year of Peace grant applications regarding non-criticism of Government policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I appointed the seven members of the Australian Peace Awards committee on a personal basis. They are all prominent Australians and represent a cross-section of the Australian community.

The Australian Peace Awards are not intended only for persons who have made a contribution to peace in the field of international relations. In line with the United Nations objectives for the International Year of Peace, nominations are sought of individuals and organisations that have made an outstanding contribution to the cause of peace in one or more of the following categories:

(a) by work that stimulates concerted and effective action by the United Nations, its member States, inter-government organisations, non-government organisations, educational, cultural, academic institutions and the mass media in:
(i) promoting peace, international security and co-operation on the basis of the UN Charter;
(ii) resolving conflict by peaceful means
(b) by work that strengthens the United Nations as the principal international system devoted to the promotion and maintenance of peace by:
(i) encouraging member States to renew their commitment to the principles of the Charter and to implement these principles effectively;
(ii) resolving conflict by peaceful means
(c) by work that strengthens the United Nations as the principal international system devoted to the promotion and maintenance of peace by:
(i) encouraging member States to renew their commitment to the principles of the Charter and to implement these principles effectively;
(ii) enhancing the effectiveness of the Security Council in fulfilling its primary responsibility for the maintenance of international peace and security;
(iii) increasing public awareness and support for United Nations activities.
(d) by work that focuses attention and encourages reflection on the basic requirements of peace in the contemporary world, in particular:
(i) the inter-relationship of peace, economic development and social progress;
(ii) the urgent need for disarmament and the prevention of nuclear catastrophe;
(iii) the elimination of racial discrimination and apartheid;
(iv) the exercise of human rights and freedom as an essential element of peace;
(v) peace as a requirement for the satisfaction of such human needs as food, shelter, health, education, labour and a beneficial environment;

(vi) preparation for life in peace, seen as a process in which education, science, culture, religion and the mass media play important roles, and which requires the effective participation of various social groups, especially women, youth, the elderly, war veterans and professionals;
(vii) the role of international co-operation, dialogue, mutual understanding and trust in the maintenance of peace with the involvement of Governments, parliaments and non-government organisations.

(2) No. The Awards, which will consist of medallions inscribed with the United Nations International Year of Peace motif, will be made to individuals and organisations in the light of the criteria described above. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made with negotiations for a minerals regime in Antarctica.
(2) What action has the Government taken to (a) preserve Australia's claim to sovereignty within these negotiations and (b) protect the environment in the development of the minerals regime.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1982, there have been seven rounds of negotiations between Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties aimed at developing an agreement which would govern any future minerals activity in Antarctica. A revised draft regime prepared by the Chairman of the Special Consultative Meeting, Mr Beeby of New Zealand, has assisted negotiations during the past three rounds.

During the negotiations to date, progress has been made in the search for generally acceptable solutions to the central issues of the objectives and principles, and the composition and functions and decision-making procedures, of the institutions of the regime, and in clarifying a number of detailed issues. It has become clear that many accommodations will ultimately need to be found within such a regime between: the interests of claimant states and those of non-claimants; the perceptions of market economy countries and those of non-market economies; the concerns of those interested in developing Antarctica's resources potential and those interested in the protection of the Antarctic environment; the interests of the super-powers and other parties; and the special interests of developing countries as well as the overall interests of the international community. This process will be continued at the eighth round of the negotiations which will be hosted by Australia in Hobart from 14 to 25 April.

(2) The Government supports the maintenance of Australian sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory. Australia's position in this regard is protected by the terms of Article IV of the Antarctic Treaty. The Government is acting to preserve Australian sovereign interests in the context of the Antarctic minerals negotiations. This will require an Article similar to Article IV and some special position in regard to any exploration for, or development of, minerals in the Australian area. Australia is also working actively to ensure that principles are established and mechanisms are put in place within an Antarctic minerals regime which will ensure that the Antarctic environment is stringently safeguarded.
